**Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group**

The Target has not prepared consolidated financial information and operates its business through the KM
Group. The financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of the KM Group, unless
otherwise indicated. As of and for the nine months ended July 31, 2021, the total operating revenue, operating
profit, total assets and total (current and non-current) liabilities of the Target represented 100%, 47%, 100% and
102% of that of the KM Group, respectively.

**_Administrative Expenses_**

The consolidated administrative expenses of the Target were £96.9 million for the nine months ended
July 31, 2021, whereas the administrative expenses of the KM Group were £89.8 million for the same period. The
Target’s consolidated income statement includes certain expenses that are recognized and affect cash flows at the
Target consolidated level only, and which are not recognized at the KM Group level because they are not incurred
within the KM Group. These expenses include an exit related Long Term Incentive Plan (“LTIP”) charge of £6.9
million which has been classified as exceptional. The Target operates an exit related LTIP, open to our executive
directors and senior management with awards being made at the discretion of the board of directors of the Target.
Awards under the plan are subject to being in service and an increase in the value of the group up to an exit event
occurring.

**_Finance Income and Expense_**

The Target recorded finance income of £1.1 million and finance expense of £20.5 million for the nine
months ended July 31, 2021, whereas the KM Group recorded finance income of £0.5 million and finance expense
of £19.6 million for the same period, respectively. The difference was due to additional interest expense of £0.9
million (in respect of a loan granted by Keystone JVco Limited to the Target in the amount of £7.5 million) and
interest income of £0.6 million (in respect of preference shares issued by Keystone Midco Limited to the Target)
recognized by the Target. The latter transaction is eliminated in the Target consolidation.

x


-----

**_Indebtedness_**

The Target and the KM Group account for liabilities recorded on their respective consolidated statements
of financial position in the same manner. As of July 31, 2021, the KM Group’s external debt for bank loans,
finance leases and loans from others amounted to £178.8 million.

The Target’s external debt of £187.7 million also includes the £7.5 million loan from Keystone JVco
Limited to the Target, with interest accrued thereon of £1.4 million.

**_Consolidated Equity_**

As of July 31, 2021, the consolidated equity of the Target was £9 million less than the consolidated equity
of the KM Group. This was caused by certain differences recorded in the nine months ended July 31, 2021, as
well as in past reporting periods, relating to variances in annual profit/(loss) results between the Target and the
KM Group, including notably the £6.9 million LTIP charge in the nine months ended July 31, 2021 and a £2.0
million LTIP charge in previous periods.

**_Intercompany Receivables and Payables_**

As of July 31, 2021, the Target recognized an intercompany receivable of £8.7 million (primarily
representing a £3.5 million investment in 12% preference shares issued by Keystone Midco Limited and £4.2
million of dividends owed thereon) as well as an intercompany payable of £0.5 million (representing a balance
owed to Keepmoat Limited).

**_Current liabilities_**

As of July 31, 2021, the Target also recognized a share-based payment liability of £7.9 million, an
associated employer tax liability of £1.1 million in respect of the LTIP and accruals of £0.2 million.

**_Deferred taxation_**

As of July 31, 2021, the Target recognized a deferred tax asset of £0.4 million related to the LTIP liability.
The KM Group recognizes a net deferred tax asset of £7.9 million.

**IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers)**

IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) was issued in 2014 and was endorsed by the EU in
2016. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) establishes a comprehensive framework for determining
whether, how much and when revenue is recognized. It replaces existing revenue recognition guidance, including
IAS 18 (Revenue). IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) is effective for annual periods beginning
on or after January 1, 2018, with early adoption permitted.

We adopted IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) from April 1, 2018 in accordance with
the fully retrospective transitional approach without using the practical expedients for completed contracts or for
modified contracts. We have applied the expedient allowing both non-disclosure of the amount of the transaction
price allocated to the remaining performance obligations, and an explanation of when it expects to recognize that
amount as revenue for all reporting periods presented before the date of initial application.

Under IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers), revenue is recognized based on indicators of
control, rather than solely when risks and rewards are transferred. This can lead to differences in revenue
recognition on certain sites, based on the specific contractual arrangements in place. The majority of our revenue
and profit, including revenue from open market sales, continues to be recognized on legal completion. For those
sites in respect of which stage payments are received from Registered Providers of housing, revenue is recognized
based on stage of completion rather than on legal completion.

IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) also sets out the requirements for recognition of noncash consideration as revenue. Previously, where we entered into arrangements to provide housing to Registered
Providers at below open market value in exchange for discounted land from partners, the associated housing unit
revenue was recorded at open market value. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) does not permit
this, as the exchange transaction (land discount from partner) is not received directly from the customer (the
Registered Provider) and so does not meet the criteria of non-cash consideration. This change has the impact of
reducing reported revenue. Accordingly, the revenue recognized in respect of these housing units will be equal to
the cash consideration received from Registered Providers, with no open market value adjustment. There are a
limited number of developments where the eventual buyer of the affordable units is the same entity as the land

xvi

vendor. In these instances, the discount received represents non-cash consideration, which continues to be
recognized as revenue.

from the restated comparative information contained in the audited financial statements for the year ended October
31, 2018 as restated to give effect to IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers).

**IFRS 16 (Leases)**

Our consolidated financial statements are prepared and presented in accordance with IFRS. On January
13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) on November
9, 2017. IFRS 16 (Leases) replaced IAS 17 (Leases) and the related International Financial Reporting
Interpretations Committee’s and the Standards Interpretation Committee’s interpretations, and results in almost
all leases being recognized on the balance sheet, as the distinction between operating and finance leases is
eliminated. Under the new standard, the lessee recognizes an asset (the right to use the leased asset) and a financial
liability to pay lease payments. The only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases. IFRS 16 (Leases) is
effective for fiscal years commencing on or after January 1, 2019, with early adoption permitted if IFRS 15
(Revenue from Contracts with Customers) has also been applied.

We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) from November 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective approach. Under
this approach, comparative information is not restated and the cumulative effect of initially applying IFRS 16 is
recognized in retained earnings at the date of initial application. In particular, as a consequence of IFRS 16
(Leases) our total assets and liabilities are expected to increase as the right of use asset associated with leases and
the corresponding liability, which were previously treated as operating leases, are recognized on the balance sheet.
In addition, operating lease expenditure has been reclassified and split between depreciation and finance cost, and
as a result, our EBITDA is expected to increase. Prior to November 1, 2019 we accounted for Leases under IAS
17 (Leases). As a result the audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the seven months ended October
31, 2018 and as of and for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2018 are not directly comparable to our audited financial
statements as of and for the fiscal year ended October 31, 2019 with respect to the treatment of leases.

IFRS 16 (Leases) was effective for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. The impact of adopting
IFRS 16 (Leases) for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was the recognition of right of use assets of £8.0
million and lease liabilities of £8.6 million on transition in respect of offices, company vehicles, site plant
equipment and show homes. The impact on adjusted EBIT for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was £0.6
million. This information may not be indicative of the impact of the adoption of IFRS 16 (Leases) on our total
assets, total liabilities and EBITDA for the next financial year or any future period.

**Overview**

We are one of the UK’s oldest and most experienced partnership housebuilders, with “5-Star
Homebuilder” status awarded in 2021. We are focused on creating sustainable communities in places where
people want to live, and we specialize in the delivery of affordable and high quality homes, principally targeted
at first-time buyers. Headquartered in Doncaster, England, we operate across England and Scotland through nine
operating regions. We are a top ten UK housebuilder, measured by the number of homes sold, including delivering
4,035 homes in our financial year ended October 31, 2019.

Unlike traditional housebuilders, our business model is based on partnerships with entities interested in
seeing an increase in supply of homes as well as those with demand for our product. These partners are primarily
land owners (such as Homes England, Local Authorities and private land owners) or Registered Providers, which
include the traditional not-for-profit and the newer for-profit entities that are registered with the Regulator of
Social Housing to provide affordable housing. We engage each of our key stakeholders in residential projects by
establishing, aligning and prioritizing their needs and successfully delivering their objectives. We have built our
reputation by aligning our approach to our partners’ objectives regarding the sourcing, procurement, planning and
delivery of successful, affordable housing developments that create significant social value. We believe that we
are the original partnership-focused housebuilder in the United Kingdom, having worked with over 200 partners
to date, with many of these relationships enduring for over 20 years.

Our partnership model allows us to have a high degree of certainty over our land pipeline, with sufficient
land secured for six years of development based on our future development plans and on 2019 home deliveries,
while also typically allowing us to defer payment until milestones are met. We are also able to minimize
development and planning risks by partnering with land owners through the early stages of a development project.
Coupled with the relatively low land costs for the affordable homes that we target, we are able to operate a capitallight business model relative to traditional housebuilders, and generate relatively strong cash conversion and return
on capital employed (“ROCE”). In the financial year ended October 31, 2019, the last full financial year prior to
the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, our ROCE was 32.8%.

We focus on developing urban and suburban locations where there is an inherent demand and supply
imbalance for new homes. We aim to meet this demand through our five core standard house type ranges. This
standardization allows efficiency in procuring materials and construction, increased certainty of cost and timing
of delivery, and assists in establishing optimal site layout mix based on demand and our partners’ preferences. We
are continually working with new technologies that underpin and refine our designs.

We are committed to deliver a range of affordable housing, predominantly for open market sale, social
housing and shared ownership – which provides us with a higher degree of market resilience over the long term
due to generally consistent demand from first-time buyers and well-funded Registered Providers. In the financial
year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 74% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to
private customers as well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a
site), with the remaining approximately 26% of our sales comprising sales to Registered Providers that are
contracted at the outset of development of a site, including but not limited to those contracted to satisfy Section
106 obligations. Approximately 87% of our open market sales in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 were
to private sale customers, of which approximately 76% were to first-time buyers (first-time buyers accounted for
76% during the financial year ended October 31, 2019). In the financial year ended October 31, 2020,
approximately 45% of our total sales, including 67% of sales to first time buyers, involved the use of the United
Kingdom government’s (the “Government”) Help to Buy (“HTB”) scheme. We believe that first-time buyers
provide more resilient structural demand than the typically discretionary and cyclical home-mover segment.

Our focus on partnerships provides us with an attractive financial model, benefitting from typically lower

Registered Providers (beyond sales in connection with Section 106 affordable housing obligations) and access to

**Our Strengths**

**_Strong Fundamentals Underpinning the UK Housing Sector, Supported by a Favorable Government Policy_**
**_Environment_**

The supply of housing in the UK market has lagged behind demand and the regions where we operate in
particular are characterized by a structural supply-demand imbalance. The UK Government’s position has
historically been that everyone should have the opportunity to own an affordable, decent home within a sustainable
and mixed community. To this end, support for the housing market and first-time buyers has been a target of
government policy over recent years, starting with the introduction of the National Planning Policy Framework
(“NPPF”) in 2012.

In its 2021 annual budget, the Government reiterated its pledge to increase the number of new homes
built per annum, with the goal of delivering at least one million additional homes through this parliamentary cycle.
Overall, the Government has a target to build 300,000 homes per year through the mid-2020s (as announced in
the Budget 2017), and we expect there to be continued support for the housebuilding sector as the Government
seeks to achieve this target.

The following chart shows the number of homes completed by private sector and public sector funding,
as compared to the Government target of 300,000 per year.

In particular, the first-time buyer market outside of London, our core target market, is aided by a
supportive structural and political backdrop promoting both home ownership and affordable housing, including
through UK central Government funds, loans, grants and subsidies, which assist in both the viability of schemes
and also pace of delivery. As demonstrated by the recently launched “First Homes” program, which offers firsttime buyers a minimum 30% discount on the purchase of a new build home, we expect this segment to continue
to be a key focus area for the UK government in the future. This has contributed to a rise in housebuilding
completions to 178,310 in England in the year ended December 31, 2019, the highest level since 2007. This is,
however, far below the 300,000 per year needed in England as estimated by the UK Government in early 2021
despite the macro-economic uncertainty created by the pandemic. As household formation continues to rise and
the pandemic has reinforced buyer preferences for houses over flats, we have experienced a strong recovery in
2021 to date.

While it is not currently known whether the HTB scheme will be extended after 2023, what modifications
to any extensions may be, or if other government support for the sector may be put in place, we believe the
Government will remain focused on supporting those purchasers who form our key customer base. For instance,
when the HTB scheme was modified and extended to March 2023, reforms were implemented to restrict the
scheme to support only first-time buyers from April 1, 2021 onwards and with regional price caps from £186,100
in the North East to £600,000 in London. As our ASP was £162,000 in the year ended October 31, 2019, we
believe this modification will have little to no adverse impact for our business. Our ASP compares favorably for
entry price point customers when compared to our listed peers.

Further, based on our ability to navigate recent changes to the Scottish equivalent of the HTB scheme,
we do not believe that any termination of the HTB scheme would have a material effect on the demand for our
homes in England. In Scotland, the “Affordable New Build Scheme” remains available to larger housebuilders
(including Keepmoat), though it stopped accepting new applications on February 5, 2021. The suspension of new
applications has had no major impact on our performance in the region, which we believe is primarily a result of
our target market dynamics, competitive entry price point and strong reputation as a 5-Star Homebuilder.

**_We Operate in those areas of the UK Housing Market with the Highest Levels of Affordability and Resilience_**

We believe that we are strategically positioned in the most attractive segment of the UK housing market,
from both a demographic and a geographic perspective. Key attractions of this market segment include resilience
in adverse macroeconomic environments, the greatest affordability levels in terms of income/price ratios and one
of the strongest growth rates in historical and forecast volumes. This segment is also conducive to strong
partnerships with land owners such as Homes England and other local authorities, as well as delivery partners,
including Registered Providers, in their role as agents for the implementation of Government housing policies
driven by social objectives.

As a result, we have achieved consistently strong sales rates in recent years, outperforming more broadly
focused housebuilders. From April 2017 to July 2021, Keepmoat has achieved an average open market sales rate
per outlet per week of 0.82, which is above the broader housing sector’s average open market sales rate per outlet
per week of 0.66.

underpinned by strong customer demand and high growth rates. Each of these regions is characterized by belowaverage house prices and mortgage payments as a percentage of take home pay for first-time buyers. The average

2.0x to 2.5x for London and the South East or approximately 3.3x for the UK as a whole. Additionally, in each
region, our ASP is below the regional average, leaving room for price inflation while remaining at the affordable
end of the spectrum.

**_Our Partnership Model Carries Inherently Less Risk than the Traditional Housebuilding Model, with High_**
**_Barriers to Entry and Partners that are Structurally Aligned_**

We are one of the UK’s leading dedicated partnership-focused housebuilders with a proven track-record
and a strong reputation of delivering large scale, multi-faceted, residential-led regeneration schemes throughout
England and Scotland. Unlike traditional housebuilders, we primarily develop in collaboration with partners that
have some form of long-term continuing interest (either through ownership or social responsibility) in the relevant
development. We are a partner of land owners such as Homes England and other Local Authorities, as well as
delivery partners, including Registered Providers of affordable housing, strategically catering to structural demand
driven by social objectives and Government housing policies.

Partnership relationships promote effective and capital light land sourcing and site development (often
with deferred payment terms correlated to the pace of site development and unit sales), as well as the ability to
unlock development sites often inaccessible to traditional housebuilders. Unlike the traditional model, the
partnership model offers an attractive financial profile with lower land acquisition costs, favorable (often deferred)
payment terms, cash generative and competitively priced deals with Registered Providers, access to grant funding
and accelerated delivery, enabling us to pursue investments with an attractive ROCE.

Over the past 25 years, we have developed strong relationships with many of the largest land partners in
the UK, which are predominantly public land owners but also include private land owners, and have built a strong
reputation for delivery, quality and place making (i.e., creating thriving, sustainable communities where people
genuinely want to live, work and play). Relationships are maintained at multiple organizational levels, which help
identify future projects and facilitate successful tender processes. This results in a high volume of repeat business
and a strong visibility of the order book. Long-standing partner relationships such as ours are inherently difficult
to replicate for new entrants.

We believe that the partnership model also has a reduced risk profile, as it is fundamentally based on a
structural alignment of objectives among ourselves and our partners, which results in pragmatism and flexibility
when required. As demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic, working with our partners, we were able to
agree a deferral of 80% of committed land spend and 97% of forecast uncommitted land spend, without losing
any site investment opportunities as a result.

**_Operating Model with Best-In-Class Processes and Cost Structure_**

We have specialized in offering a standardized product range of family homes as the optimal means of
building affordable and high quality housing units, while minimizing execution risk and improving predictability
of costs as well as improving construction build times. This focus on product standardization is a key
differentiating element of our business model and commercial proposition to our partners, contributing to the
creation of a strong brand.

To facilitate standardization, we typically utilize our five standard house type ranges, catering to the
requirements of private sale, sale to Registered Providers and local authorities, future mobility standards and
Scottish building standards (where applicable), which assist in establishing optimal site layout mix based on
demand and partner’s preferences. Although it varies from year to year, in the financial year ended October 31,
2020, 88% of our homes were built using standardized housing types.

The in-house development process of our portfolio of core standard designs is based on internal feedback
for saleability, buildability, customer feedback and land/commercial optimization, and is a key driver of the
continued operational improvements across the Group that have resulted in enhanced operating margins.


-----

Standardization of house types has enabled us to accurately reflect third party designs (such as heating,
roofs, furniture and kitchens) for space and accessibility standards. These standard details allow us to promote
best practices for quality, safety and precise material scheduling, optimizing waste as a result. Importantly,
standard specifications facilitate forward demand planning, purchase leverage and rebate maximization. It allows
contractors to bid aggressively on our projects as they have greater confidence around deliverability on cost and
on time. The standardization process has also enhanced the quality of our products which, in turn, has increased
customer satisfaction and reduced aftercare costs.

The efficiencies across the supply chain and cost control and optimization have strengthened our ability
to maintain strong margins and provide a partial defense from cost inflation pressures. This is further enhanced
by our disciplined approach through all stages of capital allocation, acquisitions and cost control. Standardization
has also enabled us to continue to maintain a low ASP, providing the potential to benefit from sale price increases
during inflationary periods.

**_Proven Ability to Source Land through a Disciplined Acquisition Process_**

We have implemented a structured and agile land acquisition process, enabling a continued
replenishment of our land pipeline that has contributed to sustained margin improvement over the last few years.
As there is a lag between the securing of land and the ultimate delivery of finished product on that land, we may
see benefit from this focus on land acquisition being realized over time.

We have a controlled and disciplined internal land acquisition approval process, working within defined
control gateways each requiring senior executive and/or Capex Committee approval. Our land approval protocol
involves three stages. The Pre-Bid Capex proposal establishes the nature, suitability and targeted financial returns
(for gross margin and ROCE) of the opportunity. The Capex 1 Proposal includes a review of planning, title and
legal reports, site risks/mitigants and required approvals, with continued focus on delivering in line with the
threshold financial returns. Finally, the Capex 2 proposal is the region’s final proposal to develop the site
(including financial plan) once all legal matters and major approvals are received. We believe this rigorous land
sourcing process, together with sales price optimization, build and sales management and the resulting increasing
mix of higher quality and better procured sites, may all be contributing factors driving continued margin
expansion.

For example, for sites under development that were approved between 2017 and 2019 (excluding the
North West MCI region), average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for each year of approval
range from approximately 22% to 23% by year, whereas for sites either approved since 2020 or within our secured
pipeline and to be approved, average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for each year of
approval or for the “to be approved” category, range from approximately 24% to 25% by year or category. This
is an increase from the average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for sites under development
that were approved in 2016 and pre-2016, for which average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins
are approximately 21% and 18%, respectively.

**_Strong Management Team with Proven Operational Experience_**

We have a strong management team with a proven track record in UK housebuilding, including expertise
in land acquisition, construction, planning, development and partnering with housing associations, local
authorities, and Registered Providers. This has been instrumental in helping us to achieve 5-Star Homebuilder
status in 2021 with a 92.6% customer satisfaction score.

Since the formation of our executive management team in 2018, we have delivered consistent year-onyear revenue growth, Gross Development Margin and EBIT growth (excluding the COVID-impacted financial
year ended October 31, 2020). The team has accomplished this primarily through an increase in scale, improved
operational efficiency and a disciplined land acquisition process spearheaded by the divisional management team
which has extensive knowledge of the selected regions in which we operate.

**_Strong Financial Track Record of Growth and Returns_**

We have a strong track record of growth and increase in profitability in recent years, resulting from the
combination of our geographical expansion process and strong focus on operational improvements and margin
expansion. From the financial year ended March 31, 2015 to the financial year ended October 31, 2019, revenue
grew by a CAGR of 22% and home completions grew from 2,133 to 4,035 (representing a CAGR of 15%), driven


-----

by methodical expansion in established regions and into new regions, including in January 2017 the acquisition
of MCI Developments Limited in the North West, as well as benefiting from ASP increases.

The KM Group’s Adjusted EBIT increased 47.7% from £41.4 million for the financial year ended March
31, 2018 to £61.1 million in the financial year ended October 31, 2019. Inevitably, the effects of the COVID-19
pandemic had a negative impact in the KM Group’s financial performance in 2020. However, illustrating the
strength and resiliency of our business model, we generated revenues of £628.5 million and Adjusted EBITDA of
£73.8 million in the twelve months ended July 31, 2021, representing a decrease of 3.3% and an increase of 18.3%,
respectively, as compared to the financial year ended October 31, 2019.

Concurrently with this growth, we have made significant investments in structure and personnel at both
regional and head office levels, creating a national platform optimally crafted to support our future growth in our
target geographies. Margins have remained stable over this period, proving our ability and further potential to
continue investing and increasing scale.

**Our Strategies**

Our strategy is to maintain and strengthen our position as one of the leading partnerships-focused
housebuilders in the UK, while delivering enhanced margins and returns from our maturing regional platform. To
achieve this goal, we are focused on the following key strategic priorities.

**_High Visibility on Medium Term Revenue Growth, Risk Mitigation Opportunities and Margin Improvement_**

Our current land pipeline reflects a strong level of land security to deliver on the business plan and
continue to drive future growth, providing us with excellent forward visibility. As of July 31, 2021, there were
24,654 plots in our land pipeline, of which approximately 81% were legally secured, meaning that we have a
contractual right to develop or a conditionally exchanged contract. This equates to a land pipeline of six years at
pre-pandemic annual volumes. We intend to continue to leverage our strong land pipeline and high near-term land
visibility to increase delivery volumes.

We currently characterize five of our nine regions (the East Midlands, South Midlands, North West MCI,
Scotland and West Midlands regions) as “growth regions,” and we believe these regions have significant potential
to deliver additional plots within the existing regional management structure as they mature. We will target both
continued growth in volume and margin improvement, as the business delivers on regional management team
investments that have been made in these growth regions and benefits from the continued realization of land
acquired through improved sourcing processes.

Approximately 86% of our land pipeline has agreed deferred land payment terms with our partners. Of
our land pipeline plots that have been legally secured as of July 31, 2021, approximately 37% represents projects
that were not legally completed and there remained conditionality (e.g., planning and groundworks survey) prior
to finalizing the contract. There are further risk mitigation opportunities available to us within our partnership
model such as land payments made by Registered Provider partners, overage agreements, pace and tenure delivery
flexibility and multi-tenure development.

The benefits of these risk mitigation features have been demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic,
with our strong relationships with partners providing flexibility to recalibrate land and delivery obligations during
this challenging period. Altogether, we were able to either defer or pay in alignment with plot delivery £58.4
million of £65.5 million total forecast land payments (89%) from April 1, 2020 to August 31, 2020.

**_Continued Development of Our Large and Strong Land Pipeline_**

In addition to building out our strong land pipeline of over 24,000 plots, we intend to continue to pursue
new land opportunities to maintain the secured land pipeline, particularly increasing the amount of higher quality,
better procured sites (reflecting our enhanced requirements and processes prior to approval for an opportunity
being granted). We expect to continue to have a structured, disciplined and agile approach to land acquisitions to
facilitate securing suitable land opportunities across all of our regions, who each have dedicated land acquisition
teams focused on high quality land opportunities within each region’s geographical area of operation.

**_Strengthen Relationships with Key Stakeholders_**

We intend to build on our long-standing relationships with key stakeholders such as Registered Providers,
Local Authorities, and Government agencies, such as Homes England. These relationships have been nurtured


-----

over two decades and are held throughout our organizational structure and that of our partners, from executives
to regional management and staff.

We have a proven track record for delivery, quality and placemaking resulting in winning repeat business.
Going forward, we will continue to align objectives with key partners in areas such as climate and biodiversity
emergency targets, in addition to the growing need for affordable homes. We will also seek to develop new
relationships through our new business teams.

**_Continue to Focus on Delivering Best Services while Maintaining Strong ESG Benefits and H&S Standards_**
**_at our Sites_**

Customer satisfaction is at the heart of our business and we strive to deliver high-quality homes and
customer service, reflected by our 5-star customer status. We intend to continue to focus on ensuring that our
customers are supported throughout their house buying journey, meeting their expectations, and providing them
with a high-quality new home.

Sustainability is core to the partnership business model and we are committed to prioritizing ESG
initiatives. Key stakeholders are aligned in their focus with approximately 74% of Local Authorities in the UK
declaring a climate and biodiversity change emergency, with regeneration areas often more vulnerable to climate
and environmental impacts. We are working with Wildscapes, which is a wildlife trust consultancy, to develop
methodologies to support the delivery of a net gain in biodiversity for future developments. We are responsible
for placemaking and regeneration which in turn helps create direct and indirect employment opportunities within
low-income communities. We are focused on providing affordable, low carbon homes to contribute to delivering
on our and our partners’ objectives of improving the environmental sustainability of the UK’s homes.

We have committed to a number of near term ESG targets, including: introducing science-based carbon
targets aligned to limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius along with carbon performance metrics (currently
anticipated to be set in late 2021); setting our decarbonisation roadmap within 12 months from July 2021, with
the aim of achieving a net zero carbon position by the mid-2040s; mitigating supply chain risks and supporting
our supply chain to become more sustainable; and updating our sustainability structure, providing greater
oversight and focus on sustainability with the function reporting directly to the CEO and receiving greater focus
from the Board.

Additionally, we have well-developed and structured H&S policies, certified to ISO 45001:2018, and
training programs, as reflected in our health and safety track record. We have clear policies, best practice guides
and robust standards and operate a number of forward looking and backward looking metrics.

We continuously seek to improve our H&S performance and approach, focusing on risk throughout all
phases of a development. Our strategic objectives are centered around (i) keeping people safe and healthy every
day; (ii) protecting and enhancing the environment; and (iii) being assured and informed. Each of the these
strategic objectives contain a number of initiatives focused on achieving the objectives and cover, amongst other
matters, active and visible leadership; managing risk effectively and proportionately; accountability, behavior and
culture; capability; contemporary management systems; and key performance indicators. As initiatives are
implemented, they are reviewed for effectiveness by our executive EHS committee and monitored.

**The Transactions**

**_The Acquisition_**

On August 4, 2021, the Company entered into a share purchase agreement (the “Acquisition
**Agreement”) with the Sellers pursuant to which, among other things, the Company agreed to indirectly acquire**
100% of the share capital of the Target.

Completion of the Acquisition Agreement was conditional on a number of third party consents, all of
which have now been obtained. The Acquisition will be consummated on or about October 27, 2021 (the
“Completion Date.”)

The estimated cash consideration payable by the Company on the Completion Date is approximately
£517.1 million. The estimated cash consideration payable to the Sellers represents the agreed base consideration
payable to the Sellers pursuant to the Acquisition as adjusted for our estimates of an agreed ticker fee accruing
until the Completion Date and certain notified cash leakage items, certain payments arising as a result of the
Transactions and certain other adjustments required under the Acquisition Agreement. See “Use of Proceeds.”


-----

Certain members of management will settle and subsequently reinvest their shares into the Company in lieu of
receiving cash.

The Company will also be liable to: (i) repay the Target Group external debt of approximately
£159.9 million (the precise figure will depend on break fees as of the Completion Date) (the “Existing Target
**Indebtedness”); (ii) procure the repayment by the Target of certain transaction costs of the Sellers and disclosed**
transaction bonuses (net of estimated corporate tax savings)(to the extent that these costs exceed this amount, the
amount of consideration for the Acquisition will be reduced to reflect this increased liability); (iii) repay certain
debt-like items and adjustments to be repaid as part of the Transactions, including intercompany loans and other
similar items; and (iv) pay certain fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions.

The Acquisition will be financed as follows: (i) the Issuer will issue the Notes offered hereby in an
aggregate principal amount of £275.0 million; and (ii) Aermont and certain members of its management will make
an equity contribution in an estimated amount of £476.1 million, which will be downstreamed through a series of
intermediate holding companies to the Company (the “Equity Contribution”). The purchase price for the
Acquisition is subject to customary purchase price adjustments in accordance with the Acquisition Agreement.

The purchase price set forth in the Acquisition Agreement includes a profit ticker component, which is
an agreed daily amount that accrues from and excluding April 30, 2021 to and including the Completion Date. As
a result, the ultimate purchase price under the Acquisition Agreement will also be dependent on the timing of the
Completion Date. In addition, the purchase price for the Acquisition Agreement will be reduced by the amount of
leakages, being actions resulting in the loss of cash or other value from the Target in favor of the Sellers, such as
the payment of any dividends, any other payments or disposals, assignments or transfer of assets or any payments
made pursuant to any guarantee, indemnity or similar obligation, among other things, in each case to the extent
not expressly permitted by the Acquisition Agreement (collectively, the “Leakages”).

**_The Refinancing_**

A portion of the cash proceeds from the offering of the Notes will be used to make the Proceeds Loan in
order to repay substantially all of the Existing Target Indebtedness (which amount excludes accrued and unpaid
interest thereon, prepayment and/or cancellation fees and/or redemption premia) expected to be outstanding on
the estimated Completion Date, assuming the Completion Date occurs on or about October 27, 2021, comprising:
(i) a senior term facility, between, among others, Keystone Bidco Limited as company and original borrower,
certain GSO funds as original lenders, Elavon Financial Services DAC, UK Branch as agent and U.S. Bank
Trustees Limited as security agent (the “Existing Senior Term Facility”); and (ii) the super senior revolving
credit agreement, between, among others, Keystone Bidco Limited as company and original borrower, Barclays
Bank Plc, Lloyds Bank plc and Royal Bank of Canada as original lenders, Lloyds Bank plc as agent and U.S.
Bank Trustees Limited as security agent (the “Existing Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility” and, together
with the Existing Senior Term Facility, the “Existing Debt”).

On or about the Issue Date, the Issuer and the Company, as co-borrowers, will enter into the Revolving
Credit Facility Agreement which provides for the £70.0 million Revolving Credit Facility. If the amounts of debt
outstanding under our Existing Debt on the Completion Date exceed the amounts set forth above and in the event
that freely available cash on the balance sheet on the Completion Date is lower than our estimate due to, among
other things, a negative movement in working capital, we may draw down amounts under the Revolving Credit
Facility on the Completion Date to fund any shortfall to complete the Transactions.

**_Escrow Account_**

To the extent the Acquisition will not complete on or shortly after the Issue Date, pending the
consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from the Offering of the
Notes into the Escrow Account in the name of the Issuer on the Issue Date. The Escrow Account will be controlled
by the Escrow Agent and will be charged on a first-priority basis in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the holders
of the Notes. See “Summary—The Offering—Collateral.”

The release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts is subject to the satisfaction of certain
conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly
(and in any event within three Business Days). See “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special
_Mandatory Redemption.” If these conditions are not satisfied on or prior to December 31, 2021 (the “Escrow_
**Longstop Date”) or upon the occurrence** of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory
redemption (the “Special Mandatory Redemption”). The special mandatory redemption price for the Notes will


-----

be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts,
if any, to, but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Escrow
_of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—_ _If the_
_conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuer will be required to_
_redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Account will not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying_
_on an additional equity investment from the shareholders.”_

**Recent Developments**

**_COVID-19_**

Our financial performance during the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was affected significantly
by the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result of program disruption and the costs of operating with COVID-19 working
practices and social-distancing measures, our delivery volumes declined significantly given construction activity
was significantly stalled from April through August 2020, our margins declined slightly compared to the financial
year ended October 31, 2019 and our EBIT and ROCE performance eroded significantly.

However, as demonstrated by our performance for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 and our forward
order book, we recovered strongly from the COVID-19 pandemic by the first quarter of our fiscal year 2021 and
believe that we are well positioned to deliver on our planned growth in the medium term. We have benefitted from
a robust UK housing market, with a favorable mortgage environment, ongoing government support and strong
demand, against the resilient economic backdrop during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Despite the strict lockdown measures that were imposed through April 2021, for the twelve months ended
July 31, 2021, our Adjusted EBIT and ROCE increased 12.8% and 150 basis points, respectively, as compared to
the financial year ended October 31, 2019. We believe our financial results in recent quarters demonstrates the
resiliency and strength of our business model. The COVID-19 lockdown restrictions imposed in March 2020
caused our financial performance to decline but did not stress our overall financial profile given the lower risk
inherent in our partnership model. In addition, during the financial year ended October 31, 2020, £24.4 million in
partner payments were deferred, representing approximately 80% of our total commitments, which illustrates the
flexible land creditor profile we maintain.

deposited in the Escrow Account will be subject to the satisfaction of
certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the
consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any
event within three Business Days). Upon delivery to the Trustee and the
Escrow Agent of an officer’s certificate stating that the conditions to the
release of the proceeds from escrow are satisfied, the Escrowed Property
will be released to the Issuer and utilized as described in “Use of
_Proceeds,” “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special_
_Mandatory Redemption.” If the conditions to the release of the Escrowed_
Property have not been satisfied on or prior to the business day
immediately following the Escrow Longstop Date (as defined in
“Description of the Notes— _Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory_
_Redemption”), or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes_
will be subject to a special mandatory redemption.

The special mandatory redemption price of the Notes will be equal to
100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid
interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, such special
mandatory redemption date. If the conditions precedent to the release of
the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuer will be required to
redeem the Notes and, if the Escrow Account alone does not have
sufficient funds to cover such redemption and, as such, the Issuer will be
required to obtain the necessary funds elsewhere, such as equity
investment from shareholders.

In addition, the conditions applicable to the special mandatory
redemption may be waived by holders of the Notes representing a
majority in aggregate principal amount of the Notes outstanding.

See “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory
_Redemption” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—_ _If_
_the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not_
_satisfied, the Issuer will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow_
_Account will not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without_
_relying on an additional equity investment from the shareholders.”_

**SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA**

The tables below set forth the summary historical consolidated financial information and other data of
the KM Group as of and for the dates and for the periods indicated. The Issuer was formed on September 7, 2021,
for the purpose of issuing the Notes offered hereby. The Company was incorporated on July 23, 2021 for the
purposes of facilitating the Transactions. The Issuer is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company.

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Company has no material assets or liabilities, does not
have any revenue generating activities of its own, and has not engaged in actions other than those related to its
incorporation and in preparation of the Transactions. As a result, no historical information of the Company is
included in this Offering Memorandum.

The Issuer conducts no business operations of its own and, as of the Issue Date, will have no material
assets and its only material liabilities will be its outstanding indebtedness (including its obligations under the
Notes) and, as of the Completion Date, its only material assets will be its rights and claims under the Proceeds
Loan. The Issuer has not engaged in any activities other than those related to its formation and the issuance of the
Notes.

The Target has not prepared consolidated financial information and operates its business through
Keystone Midco Limited and its subsidiaries. Furthermore, neither the Issuer nor the Company has any material
assets or liabilities and neither has engaged in any activities other than those related to their formation in
preparation for the Offering and the Transactions. Because of the limited historical financial information available
for the Issuer, the Company and the Target, unless otherwise indicated, the financial information presented in this
Offering Memorandum is the historical consolidated financial information of the KM Group, which is generally
representative of the financial information of the Group. See “Presentation of Historical and Other Information—
_Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group.”_

In 2018, the KM Group changed its financial year end from March 31 to October 31. As a result, the KM
Group’s financial year ended on October 31 for the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020, and on
March 31 for the financial year ended March 31, 2018. In addition, in connection with the change in financial
year, the KM Group presented audited financial statements as of and for the seven months ended October 31,
2018.

The summary consolidated income statement, balance sheet and cash flow information for the KM Group
set forth below (i) as of and for the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020 were derived from the audited
consolidated financial statements as of and for the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020; (ii) as of and
for the seven months ended October 31, 2018 was derived from the audited consolidated financial statements as
of and for the seven months ended October 31, 2018; (iii) as of and for the financial year ended March 31, 2018
was derived from the audited consolidated financial statements for the seven months ended October 31, 2018; (iv)
as of and for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 was derived from the unaudited condensed consolidated interim
financial statements as of and for the nine months ended July 31, 2021; and (v) as of and for nine months ended
July 31, 2020 was prepared in accordance with IAS 34, Interim Financial Reporting.

31, 2018 has been derived from the restated comparative information contained in the audited financial statements

“Presentation of Financial and Other Information—IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers).”

In addition, information below includes certain unaudited condensed consolidated financial information
for the KM Group as of and for the twelve-month period ended July 31, 2021. The historical consolidated financial
information of the KM Group for the twelve-month period ended July 31, 2021 is unaudited and has been
calculated by adding the unaudited results of operations of the KM Group for the nine months ended July 31, 2021
to the audited results of operations of the KM Group for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 and then
subtracting the unaudited results of operations of the KM Group for the nine months ended July 31, 2020. The
unaudited financial information for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 has been prepared solely for the
purpose of this Offering Memorandum, is for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of our
results of operations for any future period or our financial condition at any future date.

As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and the confinement measures imposed by the Government,
construction and home sales activity slowed significantly in the period which continued during the three months


-----

ended October 31, 2020. As a result, our historical results of operations for the three months ended October 31,
2020 do not reflect what the performance of our business would have been had such confinement measures not
been implemented. In order to assist in the comparability of our results of operations for the twelve months ended
July 31, 2021 as compared to prior and future periods, we present herein “Normalized EBITDA” for the twelve
months ended July 31, 2021. We believe that Normalized EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 is
a measure that assists in understanding our performance during a period impacted by the market disruption caused
by COVID-19 by substituting the October 2020 Management Adjusted EBITDA for the October 2019
Management Adjusted EBITDA, comprising the months of our last calendar equivalent financial quarter prior to
the market disruption caused by COVID-19. Our operations during the three months ended October 31, 2020 were
negatively impacted following the government imposed lockdown and the subsequent delayed ramp up on home
construction and sales, before resuming normalized operations during the three month period ended January 31,
2021. As a result, we believe Normalized EBITDA is more representative of our Adjusted EBITDA performance
for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 and takes into account, on a highly illustrative basis, the cyclicality of
our business. Normalized EBITDA presented herein is for informational purposes only. Normalized EBITDA for
the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 might not represent what our Adjusted EBITDA would have been for the
same period had the confinement measures not been implemented. In particular, Normalized EBITDA does not
(i) give effect to any other event, favorable or unfavorable, that happened or could have happened during the three
months ended October 31, 2020, other than the events directly related to the COVID-19 pandemic or (ii) adjust
for the positive or negative effect of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic during the nine months ended July 31,
2021.

**RISK FACTORS**

_An investment in the Notes involves risk. You should carefully consider the risks described below together_
_with all the other information contained in this Offering Memorandum before making an investment decision. Any_
_of the following risks could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations._
_The risks below are not the only risks facing us. Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or_
_that we currently consider immaterial may also materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition_
_or results of operations which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on the Issuer’s ability to pay interest_
_and repay the principal amount in respect of the Notes._

_This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and_
_uncertainties. Our actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in those forward-looking statements_

**Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry**

**_We are dependent on the UK housing market and subject to deterioration of the UK economy, brought about_**
**_by uncertainty, loss of consumer confidence, higher interest rates, increasing unemployment or other factors,_**
**_which could lead to decreased affordability, reduced demand for housing and falling house prices._**

We operate and generate our revenue exclusively in the UK. As such, our results are highly dependent
on conditions in the UK housing market and general macro-economic conditions in the UK. Historically, the
strength of the UK housing market has been linked to that of the UK economy as a whole, which in turn is
influenced by both European and global macro-economic conditions, all of which have been cyclical in the past.
The following factors (among others) could lead to decreased affordability, reduced demand for housing and
fluctuations in house prices, which could have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial
condition and/or prospects:

      - changes in the economic environment (for example, following Brexit) and macro-economic
uncertainty created thereby;

      - reduction in gross domestic product (“GDP”) growth;

      - increases in unemployment rates;

      - reduction in consumer and business confidence;

      - changes in Government housing support and other regulations;

      - social and industrial unrest;

      - adverse changes in the availability and cost of credit;

      - changes in interest rates; and

      - tax rates (for example, income tax, value added tax (“VAT”), stamp duty and council tax).

Historically, significant changes in the UK economy have had a significant effect on demand for housing.
For example, the economic weakness experienced in the UK following the global financial crisis in 2008 caused
a significant decline in demand for residential property. The declining demand led to a sharp decrease in the
number of residential property transactions in the UK, with the value of new housing construction orders in the
UK (in constant prices and seasonally adjusted) falling by approximately 51% between the first quarter of 2008
and the first quarter of 2009, according to the Office for National Statistics (the “ONS”). Furthermore, the average
UK house price decreased from £259,699 to £216,000 between 2007 and 2009, according to Nationwide.

Adverse changes in the macroeconomic climate of the UK could negatively affect our sales volumes or
the prices for which we sell houses. The UK economy has and may continue to be affected by periods of political
and market uncertainty in Europe and globally, driven by, for example, weaker manufacturing output, ongoing
trade tensions, the US/China trade war and global health pandemics, such as COVID-19. The longer that any such
changes or uncertainties continue, the more likely it is that UK economic growth will slow. Global GDP is
estimated to have fallen by 3.5% in 2020, due in part to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, with UK GDP


-----

declining 9.9% in the same year. There continues to be significant uncertainty with respect to the impact of the
COVID-19 pandemic on UK GDP growth and unemployment rates, particularly as furlough and other support
measures wind down over the course of 2021. A deterioration of the UK economy could negatively affect our
ability to achieve our targets and could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations,
financial condition and/or prospects.

While macroeconomic factors broadly affect the UK construction market as a whole, housing trends in
the UK have also varied significantly by region due to various other factors including regional employment trends,
regional differences in the cost of living, regional differences in population growth and demographic trends, the
perceived desirability of living in different areas of the country and differences in land and house prices. In the
future, should the UK economy stagnate or contract, the variations between regions in the UK may become more
pronounced, and housing projects in any of the areas in which we operate may suffer a greater adverse impact
relative to those in other regions. For the financial year ended October 31, 2020, we derived 63% of our revenue
from our North Division and 37% of our revenue from our South Division.

While decreases in house prices can have an adverse effect on our revenues, increases in house prices
can also have an adverse effect on revenues to the extent that they result in a deterioration in affordability, as our
operations are primarily focused on serving first-time buyers and building homes on the more affordable end of
the housing market.

Additionally, the segment of the UK housing market in which we operate and the success of our
partnership model is largely dependent on investments undertaken by third parties in both the public and private
sectors. The level of investment by the public and private sectors is in part connected to general economic
conditions. There can be no guarantee that current investment trends in our industry will continue in the coming
years, that market conditions will not stagnate or deteriorate or that future austerity measures will not negatively
impact the budgets and spending decisions of our clients. If conditions limit investment by the public and private
sectors, they may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or
prospects.

**_A majority of our business is secured or supported either directly or indirectly from various Government_**
**_sources, and changes in local or Government funds, loans, grants or subsidies, or changes to or the_**
**_discontinuation of mortgage assistance schemes or equity loan schemes (including in particular Help to Buy)_**
**_could significantly impact our business._**

Our focus is to sell affordable homes, particularly to first-time buyers. We made 76% and 74% of our
private sales to first-time buyers in the financial years ended October 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. The firsttime buyer market is aided by a supportive structural and political backdrop for affordable housing outside of
London, including through UK central Government funds, loans, grants and subsidies, which assist in the viability
of our schemes.

Since 2016, the Government has increased its focus on providing additional new homes through a number
of policy statements and initiatives, including:

      - an increase in capital funding for the Affordable Homes Programme;

      - a £1 billion loan scheme to support small and medium enterprise (“SME”) home builders;

      - an extension of the Government’s Help to Buy scheme and funding; and

      - additional capital for various funds, including the Housing Infrastructure Fund, the Land
Release Fund and the Planning Delivery Fund.

Our sales have been particularly supported by Help to Buy, a Government equity loan scheme designed
to encourage home ownership in the UK. The Help to Buy program provides assistance to purchasers of newbuild homes in the UK by reducing the minimum down payment required from the purchaser to 5% of a property’s
value and providing an equity loan of up to 20% (or 40% in London) of the property value. In the financial year
ended October 31, 2020, the Help to Buy scheme provided assistance to approximately 67% of our open market
customers to purchase a new home.

The Help to Buy scheme has been modified and extended to March 2023. However, as of April 1, 2021,
the scheme now only supports first-time buyers and imposes regional price caps ranging from £186,100 in the


-----

North East to £600,000 in London. As a result of these reforms, non-first-time buyers who previously would have
been able to secure funding through the Help to Buy scheme are no longer eligible to do so, which in turn could
have an adverse impact on our home sales. In addition, the Help to Buy scheme remains subject to future
regulatory changes, including to applicable eligibility criteria. There can be no assurance that the Help to Buy
scheme will be extended after 2023 or, if it is extended, how it may be modified. Similarly, there is no assurance
that any other similar Government-backed program will continue at current levels, or at all, or that lenders will
participate in them. Any changes to the Help to Buy scheme may reduce the availability of Government funding
of mortgages, which in turn may reduce demand within the homes market.

We occasionally utilize public sector funding at some of our sites, in the form of grants and loans to
support delivery and acceleration of housing outputs. For example, we have accessed a Home Building Fund loan,
a Government fund that supports new homes being built in England. This loan arrangement was entered into in
March 2019.

We occasionally rely on public sector grants from Homes England and Local Authorities. Grants from
these sources may make certain sites economically viable to develop, where such development would not
otherwise have been economically viable without the support from these authorities. The absence of any such
grants in the future could result in a loss of certain development opportunities. Additionally, the Affordable Homes
Programme is a program created in 2010 to provide grant funding to support the capital costs of developing
affordable housing for rent or shared-ownership sale. In connection with the next round of the Affordable Homes
Programme (2021-2026), Homes England will be making available approximately £7.5 billion of funding to
deliver up to 130,000 affordable homes outside of London by March 2026. We believe that this funding will be a
key source of liquidity for Registered Providers (one of our principal customer bases for the sale of homes), and
therefore any changes to or disruption in the provision of grants under the Affordable Homes Programme could
have a material adverse effects on our results of operations. This is particularly true of our MCI business, which
works exclusively with Registered Providers.

The duration and availability of funding for all of the programs referred to above remain subject to
change. In the future, governments and/or local bodies may change their priorities and programs. For example,
authorities may reduce or amend mortgage assistance or investment support schemes, or may undertake welfare
reforms that may impact funding stability for housing associations and Local Authorities. Any reduction or
discontinuation of Government investment, Government funding or Government-backed home purchase
assistance programs may make it more difficult for our core first-time buyer customers to afford homes, which
could in turn make it more difficult for us to sell homes and may force us to either lower prices or source other
forms of mortgage support for customers, each of which could have a material adverse effect on our business,
results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

**_Our operations, including our operational performance and the welfare of our staff, may be impacted by the_**
**_spread of COVID-19._**

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, and measures imposed by the Government to restrict economic and
business activity in response, have had and may continue to have a significant impact on our operations. In
particular, our business and financial performance in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was significantly
impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. We experienced a significant reduction in our delivery volumes and profit
margins as a result of program disruption and added costs resulting from compliance with government guidelines
on working practices and social-distancing.

Although we undertook certain remedial actions to address the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic,
including temporarily furloughing employees, temporarily reducing the pay of the executive board and senior
management and accessing Government support, the COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted and may continue to
disrupt our operations. In light of Government guidance, we temporarily closed our UK sites and offices from
mid-March to mid-May of 2020, resulting in significantly lower trading when compared to prior and subsequent
periods. We delivered total completions of 2,460 homes in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, which
represented a 39.0% reduction from the 4,035 homes completed in the prior financial year. Over the same period,
our revenue decreased by 37.5%, to £406.0 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020, from £649.8
million for the prior financial year. Government-mandated quarantines, self-quarantines and staff illness may also
result in key staff being absent from work going forward. Any renewed suspension of our business operations at
our trading sites may affect our overall business and results of operations. A prolonged economic downturn from
the negative effects of the COVID-19 pandemic could also result in us reducing our workforce or incurring charges
by way of staff long-term sick pay.


-----

The extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic will continue to impact our business, financial condition,
results of operations, prospects and liquidity will depend on numerous evolving factors that are unpredictable,
including the duration and scope of the pandemic, governmental, business and individuals’ actions that have been
and continue to be taken in response to the pandemic, and the impact of the pandemic on global economic activity,
unemployment levels and financial markets, including the possibility of a global recession and volatility in the
global capital markets which, among other things, may increase the cost of capital and adversely impact our access
to capital. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition, results
of operations and prospects.

In addition, even as COVID-19 conditions begin to improve and restrictions are reduced or lifted, we
may not regain our operational momentum. Suppliers may reduce or suspend their manufacturing operations as a
result of the effects of COVID-19, and therefore may be not be able to supply our products or services in a cost
effective or timely manner, if at all. Additionally, COVID could have an impact on subcontractors ability and
speed to remobilize from the pandemic, potentially restricting the supply of labor required to deliver construction
on site. See “—Our customers and suppliers are exposed to risks associated with the current COVID-19 pandemic
_and its ramifications on the wider UK economy and the home building industry.”_

Furthermore, there may be future waves of COVID-19 or similar diseases that lead to additional
quarantines with limitations on activity and movement. During the first lockdown that began in March 2020, there
was limited guidance from the Government as to whether the house building industry could continue operations,
which resulted in many housebuilders, including Keepmoat, ceasing building activities altogether for a period of
time. The reintroduction of restrictions or a lack of guidance from the Government regarding the activities allowed
during the course of a future wave of the pandemic could have a significant adverse impact on our business, results
of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

**_Our customers and suppliers are exposed to risks associated with the current COVID-19 pandemic and its_**
**_ramifications on the wider UK economy and the home building industry._**

In addition to the direct impact on our operations, the COVID-19 pandemic has had a significant impact
on the home building industry generally, as well as on our customers and suppliers. For example, as a result of
the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK housebuilding industry has experienced certain material and services shortages,
including a limited supply of bricks and available subcontractors, which have in turn increased our build costs. If
these or any other shortages are sustained in any significant manner, they could result in delays to construction or
a further increase in the cost of our materials and services.

A broader economic downturn in light of the COVID-19 pandemic could result in reduced construction
activity, lower demand for homes and increased incidence of customers’ inability to pay their accounts, even after
the COVID-19 pandemic has ended. Moreover, economic hardship for some segments of the population,
combined with social distancing and quarantine orders that restrict individuals’ ability to engage in “non-essential”
commercial activity (including construction activity in some instances) could result in a reduction in sales.

Although construction and sales activity was allowed to resume in the UK in May 2020, the outlook for
the national economy remains unclear. House prices in the UK have generally increased following the first
national lockdown, however some of our partners may be reluctant to embark on construction projects in the
current market due to increased economic uncertainty, the possibility that property values will decrease (including
due to lack of availability of debt financing), low investor confidence and concern that any economic downturn
could adversely affect occupational demand and rental growth. The long term impacts of the current situation
remain unknown and could impact construction and sales through, for example, more restrictive on-site working
practices, mortgage availability, increased borrowing rates and reduced levels of government assistance and
stimulus. It is not possible to predict accurately the duration of the current market conditions resulting from the
pandemic, the extent to which COVID-19 government stimulus programs will remain in place or the timing or
strength of any future recovery of the UK economy.

Furthermore, we are exposed to the risk of default by customers who have agreed to purchase homes
from us, suppliers who have agreed to supply materials and/or pay volume-related rebates to us under framework
agreements, and others with whom we have entered into financial and other arrangements. A number of our
customers and suppliers have been and may continue to be adversely affected by the worldwide pandemic,
quarantine orders, financial uncertainty, disruptions to capital and credit markets and decreased demand for their
services. Our exposure to default by counterparties may increase if economic conditions deteriorate. Moreover,
we may be unable to procure supplies in a sufficient quantity or timely manner, especially where suppliers have
shut down manufacturing sites and furloughed employees. If such supply disruptions were to occur, we may not


-----

be able to develop alternative sources quickly on commercially reasonable terms, or at all. In the event that any
of our key customers or suppliers, or a significant number of smaller customers and suppliers, are further adversely
affected by these risks, we may face further reductions in revenue, loss of customers and disruptions in supply
which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or
prospects. There may also be significant fluctuations in our operating results and the results for any period may
not be indicative of results for any future period.

**_We rely on maintaining strong relationships with Local Authorities, Homes England, Registered Providers and_**
**_housing associations, and these entities may be subject to reduced funding and other changes to their_**
**_operations due to economic and political factors outside of their control._**

Our business is based primarily on a partnership model, we primarily develop in collaboration with
partners that have some form of long-term continuing interest (either through ownership or social responsibility)
in the relevant development, primarily land owners (such as Homes England, Local Authorities and private land
owners) and Registered Providers. As a result, our success depends on our ability to maintain strong relationships
with Local Authorities, Homes England, Registered Providers, housing associations and other public entities in
the UK. Approximately 79% of the plots in our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021 were being developed under the
partnership model.

Our partnership projects are often awarded through competitive public procurement processes and often
based on the Local Authority or housing association’s perception of a developer’s expertise, design quality,
reputation, price and value. Non-financial criteria, such as planning and design capability, customer service record,
track record of delivering high-quality homes with minimal defects, delivery capacity and proposals to address
social and economic sustainability issues, typically account for more than 50% of an applicant’s score in public
procurement processes. As a result, our reputation and relationships with partner organizations are critical to the
success of our business. In addition, Local Authorities often have oversight and authority over multiple potential
development sites and previous Local Authority clients are thus an important source of referral and repeat business
for our business.

We are one of the largest strategic delivery partners of Homes England. As of July 31, 2021, we had
directly and indirectly accessed approximately £450 million of funding initiatives to facilitate the delivery and
acceleration of housing outputs, secured approximately 9,200 plots on 38 different sites for development through
Homes England’s Delivery Partner Panel (“DPP”) and delivered or were in the process of delivering over 3,055
homes in partnership on Homes England land over the last 12 years. As a result, maintaining a strong working
relationship with Homes England is important to our operations, as a deterioration of this relationship could result
in both reputational and financial consequences for us. Furthermore, if Homes England were to make changes to
the way it conducts the DPP or otherwise change the way it disposes of public land, this could have an adverse
impact on our ability to access development opportunities through the panel or increase the competition for
development opportunities.

Homes England is currently preparing to launch its successor to the DPP on September 1, 2021, known
as the Delivery Partner Dynamic Purchasing System (“DPDPS”). The DPDPS is designed to modernize the
bidding process through the use of a digital system which encourages new entrants to the market, and thereby
simplifies the process for housebuilders to join the list of preferred developers and bid for land. With this new
system, housebuilders will still have to ‘qualify’ to be able to join the list of preferred developers, but they will be
able to apply to join at any time, rather than only upon renewal of the delivery partner panel once every four years,
as is currently the case. We have submitted our application and had confirmation we have been appointed to be
part of the DPDPS, which is not expected to be used to procure schemes until late 2021. Although DPDPS will
not change the way in which schemes are procured and the legal structure under which they will be delivered on
sites larger than 70 plots, the new system is likely to increase competition for development opportunities with
Homes England. A material decline in opportunities sourced through Homes England could have a material
adverse impact on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.
