Local authorities, Homes England, housing associations and other public entities in the UK can be subject
to reduced funding and other changes to their operations and structure as a result of both economic and political
factors outside of their control. This could, in turn, lead to such bodies curtailing their development activities,
which would reduce the partnership opportunities available to us. Any reduction in development activities by
these entities would likely have a relatively greater impact on Keepmoat than on many of our competitors given
our partnership-focused business model. In addition, governmental bodies may seek to influence or change the
scope or direction of Local Authorities’ activities for political reasons and, even without direct pressure, changes
in national Government policy may affect Local Authorities’ decisions on local planning issues. Although all of


-----

the three main political parties currently support an expansion of the supply of affordable homes in the UK, this
may change in the future. In the event that there is a change of Government or economic and political factors
which result in a loss of support for, or a major reorganization of, the public sector bodies with which we work,
we may need to rebuild our relationships or risk losing partnership opportunities with these organizations. If we
are unable to maintain our relationships with these organizations, it could have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

**_The availability, cost, quality and location of land are fundamental to our business, and failure to identify and_**
**_secure suitable land could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial_**
**_condition and/or prospects._**

Our business relies upon our ability to acquire land at appropriate prices and in appropriate locations.
We do not have any control over the volume and timing of partnership land pipeline opportunities, and if we are
unable to continue to secure land through our partnership model with housing associations and Local Authorities,
we may be unable to source land at commercially acceptable prices, on favorable terms or at all. Failure to identify
suitable land, obstacles in the purchasing process, failure to manage land purchases to meet the demands of the
business or increases in the costs of such purchases could mean that we are unable to obtain an adequate supply
of land. Consequentially, an inability to source sufficient suitable land that meets the requirements of our business
model could affect our volume growth targets. In addition, increased demand for land from our competitors may
lead to increases in the prices that we are required to pay for land, which may affect the profitability of our
developments. Our development activities are also affected by the planning status of the land we secure, and there
may be changes in law or regulation between the time when initial planning permission is given for a particular
site and the time at which we begin construction, which could cause delays, increase costs, reduce the expected
rate of return or make a proposed development financially unviable. See “—We are subject to local and national
_planning policies which have an impact on our operations.”_

The timing of our land acquisitions may also have a material impact on our financial condition, including
the returns we are able to generate from our developments. We occasionally source plots through speculative land
purchases for certain of our sites, particularly when seeking to increase presence in new regions. These speculative
purchases generally involve material upfront investments of our own capital. In such cases, we may pay higher
average prices for plots as we compete with other home builders for available land, which may in turn reduce our
margins and return on capital employed and increase reliance on our current ongoing projects. Unforeseen events
may also have a negative impact on our ability to source land, which may have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. See “—The net realizable value of the
_Group’s build work-in-progress (“WIP”) and land may decline.”_

**_The UK home building market is competitive._**

Although we largely operate a non-traditional home building business model through the use of our
partnership model, we compete with traditional home builders for sites, financing, partnership opportunities with
Local Authorities and housing associations, materials, skilled labor and home buyers. Within the wider housing
market, we also compete for home buyers with second-hand housing sales. Our competitors include other local,
regional and national home builders, and new competitors may enter the home building market. Some of these
competitors may enjoy greater sales and financial resources, lower funding costs, or lower operational costs than
us and their participation or entry into the partnerships market, in particular, could impair our ability to win public
procurement processes at economically viable levels or at all. For example, in certain invitations to tender issued
by Local Authorities or housing associations, bids that propose payment structures including deposits and/or early
up front land price payments attract higher scores. To the extent our competitors are increasingly willing to make
such deposits and/or early up front land price payments, we may be required to make bids on the same basis in
order to win these public procurement processes, which could in turn increase our up-front costs and reduce our
ability to use our preferred capital light operating model. Many of these competitors also have longstanding
relationships with housing associations, Local Authorities, subcontractors and suppliers in the markets in which
we operate.

Furthermore, in an increasingly competitive sales environment, there is increased risk that we may fail
to sell houses as quickly as anticipated, may need to increase selling incentives or marketing costs or may be
forced to sell at lower than projected prices. Any or all of these factors could have a material adverse effect on
our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.


-----

**_The inability of our customers to procure a mortgage or other form of funding, or increased costs of financing,_**
**_could lead to decreased sales and reservations and the cancellation of sale contracts._**

The growth of the housing market depends largely on the ability of customers to secure financing to buy
a home, as well as on how confident they are about their ability to make regular payments on their mortgages over
multiple subsequent years. During periods of weak economic conditions or strong house price inflation,
prospective homebuyers’ purchasing power often depends on their ability to borrow funds and access Government
stimulus programs. Our sales are therefore impacted by banks’ and other lenders’ willingness and ability to
provide financing to prospective homebuyers, and the terms on which they are willing and able to do so. In the
financial year ended October 31, 2020, 91% of our private sales buyers purchased homes with the assistance of
mortgages. Any decrease in the availability of mortgages is likely to have a negative impact on our customers’
ability to purchase new houses.

Changes to lending criteria such as increased checks on personal finances or the introduction of more
onerous lending restrictions could have a material adverse effect on the ability of home buyers to secure a
mortgage. Similarly, changes to mortgage terms, including loan-to-value ratios and other lending criteria, average
duration and interest rates are also likely to have a direct impact on demand for the housing. In particular, actual
and expected monetary policies of the Bank of England, including both the speed and magnitude of any interest
rate increases, are likely to have an impact on the interest rates that banks and other lenders provide. Increases in
the base rate have previously had a negative impact on the UK property market because mortgage interest rates
have experienced a corresponding increase, thereby making it more expensive for prospective buyers to purchase
residential property.

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Bank of England base rate was 0.1%. Despite the
current low base rate environment, levels of mortgage lending throughout the UK remain low compared to those
of certain other developed countries. Prospective buyers who can obtain a mortgage at current interest rates may
also be deterred by the possibility of increased mortgage interest rates in the future. Higher interest rates (and, in
turn, higher monthly interest payments) may also make mortgages unobtainable or unaffordable for some
prospective buyers. Investor buyers also are sensitive to interest rate fluctuations, as higher interest rates
negatively affect their investment returns. The Bank of England may raise its base rate at any time, which could
have an adverse impact on transaction volumes and prices in the UK’s residential property market, and may in
turn reduce the volume and value of property transactions facilitated by Keepmoat and the revenue that we derive
from them. In particular, the Bank of England may be compelled to increase the base rate as a result of inflation.
Any increase in the costs of mortgage financing in the future may make it more difficult for us to sell homes,
which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or
prospects.

Future changes in Government policy and stimulus programs may also adversely affect the ability of our
customers to obtain Government financial assistance and mortgages. See “—A majority of our business is secured
_or supported either directly or indirectly from various Government sources, and changes in local or Government_
_funds, loans, grants or subsidies, or changes to or the discontinuation of mortgage assistance schemes or equity_
_loan schemes (including in particular Help to Buy) could significantly impact our business.” Our focus is selling_
affordable homes to first-time buyers, and if it becomes more difficult to secure a mortgage or obtain Government
financial assistance, first-time buyers may be particularly impacted, as such customers tend to require loans with
higher loan-to-value ratios. Although we review a prospective buyer’s ability to qualify for a mortgage or other
form of funding prior to entering into a contract and reporting the transaction as a sale, this initial review is based
solely on information provided to us by the buyer, without independent verification. For reference, we do not
contract on a house sale to a customer without a formal mortgage offer from a mortgage lender. To the extent
there were a significant deterioration in the ability of our customers to obtain mortgage approvals or otherwise
finance their home purchases, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations,
financial condition and/or prospects.

**_Our results of operations are affected by the cyclical nature of the home building and construction industries_**
**_as well as fluctuations in the price and supply of materials._**

The home building industry tends to be cyclical and is dependent on the level of construction-related
expenditures in the residential sector, public investments and public and private spending on infrastructure
projects. The home building industry is particularly sensitive to factors such as GDP growth, interest rates, the
cost of mortgage financing for residential construction, inflation, consumer confidence, income growth (in real
terms), increases in the cost of living and other macroeconomic factors. Political instability or changes in
Government policy may also negatively affect the home building industry. Moreover, demand in the home


-----

building industry may be affected by demographic trends, such as ageing and declining populations in mature
markets, changes in the average number of persons living in one household and domestic and international
migration trends.

The cyclicality of the construction industry also impacts the supply of materials and labor. During periods
of market contraction, labor force participants leave the market, sometimes permanently, to retrain in other
professions or move elsewhere in search of work. As markets recover, demand for labor increases and the
associated impact on the cost and availability of labor can impact our business.

We have several key suppliers, contractors and subcontractors in the various regions in which we operate,
with whom we regularly contract to provide construction and various other services for the development of the
Group’s sites. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, our top supplier, which is a materials merchant,
represented 30.6% of our total expenditure for direct materials. If any of our suppliers fail to provide timely or
adequate services, labor, equipment or raw materials, we may be required to source these products and services at
a higher price than anticipated and may face delays at our project sites until we are able to identify an appropriate
alternative supplier, contractor or subcontractor. Although we attempt to control subcontractor rate increases on
our developments by fixing subcontractor prices over a phase, or part-phase, of a development through the use of
“all risk” contracts and by matching subcontractor agreements to our agreements with land owners, we cannot
eliminate our exposure to cyclical cost increases during development which may have a material adverse effect
on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. See “—Our customers and suppliers
_are exposed to risks associated with the current COVID-19 pandemic and its ramifications on the wider UK_
_economy and the home building industry.”_

Although we endeavor to utilize our group supply chain suppliers across all regions, our materials
suppliers vary in each region in which we operate due to the specific requirements of our projects. Although we
include materials cost estimates in our tenders, materials are subject to price as well as availability fluctuations,
such that even if we include flexibility in our tenders for an increase in costs, we still may not be able to source
the necessary materials, which could affect our ability to deliver schemes to program.

We are heavily impacted by our ability to source essential materials such as bricks and blocks. The supply
of essential materials may be delayed or interrupted due to factors beyond our control, such as materials shortages
or disruptions in the supply chain. See “—We could be adversely affected by uncertainty, disruption or other
_consequences of Brexit.” In addition, the cyclicality of the construction industry impacts the supply of materials_
so that in times of market contraction, production is scaled back and therefore when markets recover there can be
a lag in the supply chain which may lead to increased prices. Bricks, for example, can be difficult to source in the
UK during periods of increased building activity and are a necessary material for our operations. A shortage in
the supply of bricks in the UK typically results in the need to import bricks from overseas, which in turn may
result in an increase in brick prices owing to transport costs and delays in their availability, both of which could
result in significant increases in the cost of our construction projects and delay completions of sites. Any disruption
to a regular supply of materials could result in project delays and increased costs if alternative suppliers are unable
to provide timely replacements at competitive prices. Moreover, we may be unable to pass on any or all of the
increased materials costs to our customers. Any price fluctuations or supply interruptions as a result of the
foregoing factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition
and/or prospects.

**_We could be adversely affected by the current shortage of HGV drivers in the United Kingdom._**

As has been well publicized recently, the UK is currently experiencing a shortage of heavy-goods
vehicles (“HGV”) drivers, which has become more visible in the past weeks as the shortage of qualified drivers
has resulted in supply chain issues impacting fuel deliveries, forcing some petrol stations to close or limit the
supply of fuel available for purchase, and shortages of good deliveries to retailers. The Road Haulage Association
has estimated that there could be a shortage in the UK of more than 100,000 drivers, as compared to a pre-COVID
total of approximately 600,000 drivers. It has been reported that the current shortage has been partially attributable
to Brexit, in which European HGV drivers have opted to work solely within EU countries or have left the UK, in
part due to the increase bureaucracy and costs involved in travelling to and from the UK and an estimated 15,000
EU HGV drivers opting to leave the UK given travel restrictions imposed as part of Covid mitigation measures.
The shortage has also been blamed on a suspension and delay of an estimated 30,000 HGV qualification tests in
2020 due to the Covid pandemic which resulted in a reduction of an estimated 25,000 potential HGV driver
candidates passing the test in 2020 as compared to 2019. With the average age of an HGV driver in the UK of 55
years, the industry has further been vulnerable to relatively high attrition due to retirements as well as changes
that have cut earnings of some HGV drivers. The Government has responded by announcing that it is considering


-----

measures to recruit and train HGV drivers such as increasing the number of HGV driving tests taking place and
providing temporary visas for EU HGV drivers. In addition, many employers have increased salary and have
offered bonuses and new driving schemes. However, these measures will most likely take time to have an impact.

While we have not yet seen any noticeable impact from the shortfall in HGV drivers, there is a risk that
the current shortfall could impact our business in the event that the ongoing HGV driver shortfall results in delays
in the supply chain for our raw materials or the inability of our contractors to maintain their workforce necessary
to operate the heavy equipment essential for our developments, which in turn could have a material adverse effect
on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. In addition, the shortfall in HGV
drivers could increase the cost for raw materials and the costs of our contractors which could be passed on to us,
leading to a potential in decreased margins. We will continue to monitor the potential impact of the shortfall in
HGV drivers on our business and operations.

**_We could be adversely affected by uncertainty, disruption or other consequences of Brexit._**

On January 31, 2020, the UK left the EU, entering into a transition period that ended on December 31,
2020. This process is unprecedented in EU history and the effects of Brexit remain uncertain. Uncertainty also
exists over the effects of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and the UK, which provides for
the free movement of goods between the UK and the EU and which was entered into on December 24, 2020. In
particular, legal uncertainty exists around potentially divergent national laws and regulations in relation to
financial laws and regulations, tax and free trade agreements, immigration laws and employment laws which may
adversely affect economic or market conditions in the UK, the EU or globally. This uncertainty could contribute
to instability in global financial and foreign exchange markets, including volatility in the value of the pound
sterling, which could negatively affect our revenues and the broader economic environment on which the home
building industry depends. Given that substantially all of our profits are generated from the housing market, a
significant negative impact on the UK economy as a result of Brexit could have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

In addition, we may face challenges attracting non-British EU workers following Brexit, which could
impact our business and growth in the future. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 3.0% of the Group’s
employees were non-UK citizens, with the majority being citizens of member states of the EU. However, EU
nationals could comprise a part of the Group’s subcontractor workforce and their skillsets are such that, if Brexit
materially limits the ability or willingness of those subcontractors to work in the UK, it could have a material
adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Brexit may also put pressure on our supply chain. Most of our building supplies are manufactured in the
UK and therefore are not directly exposed to future trade arrangements with the EU. However, a portion of the
products procured through our network of UK based suppliers are imported from the EU. Additional requirements
associated with the importation of goods from the EU could adversely impact our supply chain and increase the
costs of imported construction materials. We continue to work closely with those suppliers to monitor the potential
impact as the UK adapts to the new trade arrangements with the EU. Any increase in the prices of raw materials
as a result of any new trade arrangements may lead to decreased margins.

**_Our business depends on the continued availability, viability and cost of subcontractors and other service_**
**_providers._**

Our business model requires us to hire third party subcontractors to provide onsite work. Although our
business model has key differences from other traditional home builders, we compete within the same labor pools
and changes in the labor market directly impact our costs. When activity in the home building market increases,
we tend to face escalating cost pressures associated with shortages of skilled labor, particularly skilled bricklayers.
Restrictions on the free movement of people as a result of Brexit and other changes to UK immigration policies
could result in tight supply due to reduced availability of skilled labor from outside the UK. Poor availability of
labor could significantly impact our ability to operate efficiently and deliver projects on time with high levels of
partner and customer satisfaction. See “—We could be adversely affected by uncertainty, disruption or other
_consequences of Brexit” and “—Our customers and suppliers are exposed to risks associated with the current_
_COVID-19 pandemic and its ramifications on the wider UK economy and the home building industry.”_

If we are unable to find or hire qualified and reliable third party subcontractors for any of our projects,
our ability to successfully complete projects on time or at all could be impaired. Furthermore if any of these third
parties fail to provide timely or adequate services, labor, equipment or raw materials, we may be required to source
these services and products at a higher price than anticipated and may face delays at our project sites until we are


-----

able to identify an appropriate alternative subcontractor. See “—Our results of operations are affected by the
_cyclical nature of the home building and construction industries as well as fluctuations in the price and supply of_
_materials.”_

Additionally, as we have experienced from time to time in the past, we are exposed to the risk that the
subcontractors that we employ may subsequently become insolvent, causing cost overruns and program delays,
thereby increasing the risk that we will be unable to recover costs in relation to any defective work performed by
such subcontractors. These risks are compounded during times of economic downturn, as subcontractors or any
other third parties that we conduct business with may experience financial difficulties or find it difficult to obtain
sufficient financing to fund their deliveries or operations.

We are also exposed to the risk of litigation or claims relating to breaches of contract by third party
subcontractors. Furthermore, substandard work by subcontractors could result in claims against us for failure to
meet required project specifications.

If a subcontractor or supplier of goods or services fails financially or is responsible for late or inadequate
delivery or poor quality of work on a project, then it could damage our reputation and result in financial losses for
us. The insolvency, poor performance or other financial distress of one or more of our subcontractors may have a
material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

**_We operate in a highly regulated industry and our businesses are subject to a complex regulatory environment_**
**_which may change._**

We are required to comply with national, local, and other laws and regulations and administrative
requirements and policies which relate to, among other matters, planning, developing, building land use, sales,
providing or arranging the mortgage market, health and safety, environment, employment, bribery (including
under the UK Bribery Act of 2010), competition and money laundering. These laws and regulations and
administrative requirements and policies that affect both the housing sector and ancillary sectors, often provide
broad discretion to the administering authorities. Any uncertainty or changes in relevant laws, regulations or
policies, or the interpretation thereof, may delay or prevent us from being able to achieve our strategic plans, give
rise to substantial compliance, remediation and other costs, or could prohibit or severely restrict us from
developing and building in certain locations.

In addition, following on from incidents such as the Grenfell Tower fire in London in June 2017,
regulation has increased around building assessments and fire safety, particularly for tall buildings. In light of
such increased regulation, and the fact that we have in the past used combustible paneling material for a limited
number of our properties (low-rise dwellings of no more than three stories), there is a risk that properties owned
and/or constructed by Keepmoat may in future be considered to have been built with materials that are assessed
to be or have the potential to be, the cause of, or a contributing factor to, the spread of fire or other destruction of
properties, or compromise residents’ safety.

There is also a risk that the Government, regulators or lenders could issue further guidelines in relation
to combustible materials, including aluminum composite material cladding, high pressure laminate, and/or wood
cladding and/or other external structures including fire safety procedures or otherwise as a result of which it may
be necessary for us to remediate our buildings. If such an event occurs, there may be significant costs and expenses
to rebuild the property and/or rectify the problem and our returns may decrease. Our brand and reputation may
also be harmed.

Each aspect of the regulatory environment in which we operate is subject to change. Changes, including
(but not limited to) in the following areas could have an adverse impact on our business and operating results:

      - building regulations;

      - labor laws;

      - health and safety regulations;

      - local and national planning policies (see “—We are subject to local and national planning
_policies which have an impact on our operations”);_

      - environmental, sustainability and land use requirements; and


-----

      - regulation regarding provision of mortgages.

In particular, we are subject to numerous laws, regulations and policies concerning the protection of
health, safety and the environment. For example, in England, changes regarding Part L of the Building Regulations
2010 (“Part L”), are currently in the final stages of consultation, relating to requirements concerning the
conservation of fuel and power. The proposed changes are currently anticipated to be released by the end of 2021
and are expected to come into effect from June 2022. The introduction of the changes to Part L as a transitional
step towards the proposed ‘Future Homes Standard’ is a direct outcome of the Government’s Energy White Paper
commitment to (i) raising the energy performance of buildings by limiting heat losses and excessive solar gains,
(ii) ensuring that energy-efficient fixed building services are installed, and (iii) ensuring that the building owner
is provided with the information required to maintain the building and its services. Reducing carbon emissions for
new build properties remains high on the Government’s and Local Authority partner’s agenda and plays a large
part in the design and construction of new build properties. The carbon emission reduction targets set by current
Part L standards, alongside the industry’s modern-day good practice standards for air quality, acoustics and
overheating, encourage building designers to consider more complex design solutions with bespoke user
operational assumptions. If these changes are not reviewed and implemented in a timely manner, there is a risk
that we may be non-compliant with the changing building regulations. In addition, changing building regulations
are likely to have an impact on our underlying construction costs, with potential additional costs incurred to meet
the requirements of increasing standards.

The proposed Future Homes Standard is in the early stages of consultation as part of a commitment by
the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government to ensure all new homes reduce their carbon dioxide
emissions by over 75%, through low carbon heating and “world-leading levels of energy efficiency” by 2025. The
Scottish Government is also going through a similar process of reviewing and consulting on proposed changes to
current building regulations to significantly reduce the carbon emissions of new homes, so the same risks apply
in Scotland as well. Local authorities are already empowered under the Planning and Energy Act 2008 to drive
local agendas for sustainability and may ask on this basis for a variety of standards to be applied, including the
Zero Carbon Emissions homes standard. This standard is higher than that of the proposed Future Homes Standard
and in advance of the current Government roadmap.

The above proposed changes could have a significant impact on housebuilder operations and will affect
new and, potentially, existing sites (to the extent existing sites are under development at the time the changes take
effect), subject to any transitional arrangements and/or accommodations for existing sites that may be put into
place. The proposed Future Homes Standard will also include the development of unproven gas free solutions and
there is therefore the risk of reputational damage for housebuilders if solutions fail to work as intended and create
high levels of energy usage and running costs for customers. Delivery may also be affected as supply chains need
to be developed for low carbon energy solutions.

In addition, the Government has introduced a set of principles and guidance for the UK construction
industry titled ‘Biodiversity Net Gain’. This initiative is designed to encourage developers to incorporate
appropriate natural habitat and ecological features to offset the effects of the development in order to stem the loss
of biodiversity through development and restore ecological networks. Compliance with these principles and
guidance could result in an additional cost to us. Furthermore, the nature of the principles and guidance could
result in a disadvantage to the development of brownfield sites, which represent a significant part of our business.
See also “—Ownership, leasing or occupation of land as well as home building carries potential environmental
_risks and liabilities, including liability under claims for damages as a result of use of hazardous materials,_
_including asbestos.”_

**_Difficulties and complications encountered in connection with the construction process and other events that_**
**_may arise in the course of construction could disrupt our business and could result in substantial increases in_**
**_total costs or adversely affect our returns._**

When securing a development opportunity and agreeing the financial terms of the development with our
partners (where relevant) prior to construction, we make cost estimates which are dependent upon assumptions,
estimates and judgments which may ultimately prove to be inaccurate. While we attempt to mitigate this risk by
taking reasonable steps to ensure that our risk management and financial and operational procedures, controls and
systems are appropriate for our businesses, there is no guarantee that significant unanticipated costs will not arise.
If we fail to accurately assess expected costs, revenue or risks on a particular contract, then we may fail to achieve
our expected returns. Our returns depend on costs being controlled and projects being completed on time. For
example, cost overruns, whether due to inefficiency, poor design, faulty estimates, insufficient oversight,
omissions, failure to use systems or comply with our processes, unforeseen technical conditions, cost escalation


-----

for materials (such as timber framing, bricks, concrete, polymer and steel) (including due to inflation), and/or cost
overruns by (or increased rates of) subcontractors or other factors, can result in a lower return on a project. Should
significant unanticipated costs arise, they could have a material adverse impact on our operating results, business
prospects and financial condition. In addition, failure to follow best practice guidelines could mean that projects
are not delivered on time or do not meet agreed quality, appropriate health and safety or environmental standards
and therefore do not meet customer expectations and may give rise to contractual or other liabilities.

Our most significant costs are our subcontractor and supplier costs, and we rely on local and regional
subcontractors from a variety of trades. Our subcontractors generally provide us with services on the basis of
fixed-term, fixed-price contracts based on agreed specifications while our suppliers generally agree to make
deliveries on the basis of pre-agreed prices. However, although we budget construction costs for each site before
construction begins, building and construction costs can increase above anticipated amounts as a result of
unforeseen events, which may result in the pre-agreed contractual prices not applying even where such
arrangements are in place.

We may face additional costs or delays related to, among other things, unexpected technical challenges,
changes in development specifications, exceptional weather conditions that delay work, labor shortages, accidents
during construction, the insolvency or poor performance of a subcontractor, environmental factors, changes in
consumer preferences (leading to the need to change design once construction has already begun) or new
regulations or legal requirements. For larger projects, these risks are inherently greater. If circumstances change,
a lower profit or a loss on a project may result. In addition, if a subcontractor’s or supplier’s cost estimates or
quotes provided to us are incorrect, we may incur additional costs or be required to source products and services
at a higher price than anticipated, as well as face delays at our project sites if the estimate is incorrect by a large
enough margin that the project is better served by finding an alternative contractor or supplier. These unforeseen
events could have a negative impact on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

A number of the contracts we enter into in connection with the development of our sites include certain
delivery milestones. If delays to these projects lead to a failure to meet deadlines, it could result in a breach of
contract for which we could be liable. The typical approach that we adopt when circumstances arise which may
prevent us from meeting delivery milestones is to negotiate with our counterparties to seek to amend the contract
as necessary. However, there can be no assurance that such counterparties would be amenable to such changes.
Failure to meet delivery milestones could affect our reputation and future prospects, expose us to additional costs
and result in contractual penalties or the calling of surety bonds, where applicable, that may impact our profit
margins and result in the termination of contracts. Furthermore, any delays or underperformance in our projects
may lead to conflicting demands on resources allocated to other projects. Also, for some projects, we may be
required to build commercial spaces and mixed-use facilities, areas that are not part of our core business and
expertise and therefore pose additional execution risks during construction. The failure to meet project deadlines
and targets, in either the construction or sales process, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results
of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

**_A major health and safety incident could be costly in terms of potential liabilities and reputational damage._**

Health and safety performance is critical to the success of all areas of our business. Worksites are
inherently dangerous places and operating in the home building industry poses certain health and safety risks.
Some of our operations are conducted at sites in which residents are in occupancy which adds additional risk to
the inherently dangerous nature of a worksite. Any significant accident or health and safety failure could result in
significant harm to any person present, including any current resident or member of the general public at or near
the worksite. There can be no assurance that a major accident or safety incident will not cause significant bodily
injury, physical harm or death of any person present or nearby.

Any failure in health and safety procedures or performance may result in penalties for non-compliance
with relevant regulatory requirements, and a failure which results in a major or significant health and safety
incident may be costly in terms of potential liabilities incurred as a result, including significant compensation
payments and fines, and may lead to operational failure. Furthermore, such a failure could also generate significant
adverse publicity and have a negative impact on our reputation and our ability to win new business (in particular
with respect to entering into partnerships with public bodies, which is a key part of our strategy), and may expose
management to personal criminal liability, which in turn may have a material adverse effect on our business,
results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.


-----

**_Our results of operations are affected by seasonal effects._**

Our business is, to a certain extent, dependent on weather conditions and is subject to seasonality.
Historically, our revenues and levels of working capital vary during the course of the year due to higher volumes
of completions taking place in certain months of the year. As a result, our debt profile has grown and contracted
over the course of the financial year, consistent with certain seasonal trends.

Typically, the majority of our reservations for open market sales are made in January to March and
August to October (with the latter correlated to the start of new school years). Our ability to manage the timeline
from the engagement and planning phase to the exchange of contract and legal completion is, therefore, one of
the factors that affects the timing of completions. Although we generally have a significant degree of flexibility
in managing the phasing of completions and typically aim to stagger the timing of our completions to the extent
practicable, the impact of weather on building activity and plot delivery has increased the likelihood of a peak in
completions in the late summer and early autumn.

In addition, prior to the change of the KM Group’s financial year end from March 31 to October 31 in
2018, divisional efforts to achieve targets and maximize sales for the financial year end led to a peak of
completions in March. This had an effect on our results of operations for the financial year ended October 31,
2019, as our incentive scheme for that financial year remained tied to an end date of March 31. However, we do
not expect this to have an impact on our financial results in any subsequent years. For the financial year ended
October 31, 2021 we have amended our incentive targets to include an additional measure tied to half-year targets,
in order to achieve a more levelled number of completions throughout the financial year.

The above factors may lead to volatility in our quarterly financial results. These factors that affect the
phasing of completions through a financial year tend to result in a peak in the number of plot completions, and
accordingly revenue and profit, to the last quarter of each financial year. Results of a single fiscal quarter or half
year might therefore not be a reliable basis for the expectations of a full financial year and may not be comparable
with the results in the other fiscal quarters or half year. Factors that affect our peak selling seasons can have a
disproportionate impact on our performance in a particular period.

**_We are subject to local and national planning policies which have an impact on our operations._**

Local and national planning policies have an impact on the financial performance of housing
development. Our ability to obtain the necessary and timely planning permissions is dependent on our ability to
meet the relevant regulatory and planning requirements, including detailed planning consents and technical
approvals. Planning policies can restrict the availability of new land for which suitable planning permission is
available and closely control how land is developed. For example, planning permissions can prescribe specific
conditions on matters including density, types of housing and availability of car parking spaces. The estimated
number of plots and the economic feasibility of development represented by our land may also be reduced due to
planning considerations. As of July 31, 2021, we did not have planning permissions (detailed or outline) for
approximately 21% of our land pipeline of 24,654 plots. Although we have generally been successful in obtaining
similar planning consents in the past, there can be no certainty that we will obtain planning permission for schemes
which currently lack them on a timely or cost-effective basis, or at all, and the final permission that we obtain may
vary significantly from the assumptions made at the time of acquisition. For example, the gross development value
of the site may be lower than anticipated, or the costs to complete development of the site may be higher than
anticipated, potentially causing significant deterioration in a project’s value. Certain planning authorities continue
to be under-resourced, affecting their capacity to manage applications and develop local plans. Additionally, the
planning processes for many of our projects involve public consultations, which may result in adjustments to the
preferred development plan, adverse planning outcomes or negative publicity.

We may also be required to make significant expenditures on community infrastructure and facilities and
provide a minimum amount of affordable housing as a condition of receiving planning permission, as well as
provide other community benefits and payments due under the Community Infrastructure Levy.

Any failure to obtain planning permissions in line with our development plans or at all may have a
material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Additionally, we are subject to the risk of non-compliance with planning conditions or planning
obligations connected with planning consents. If we are found to have not complied with these planning conditions
or planning obligations, our development could be deemed unlawful or subject to service of enforcement notices
or, in severe cases, result in an inability to sell affected plots.


-----

While the Group has developed policies and procedures to comply with existing requirements, there can
be no assurance that these requirements will not change. For example, in 2012, the NPPF was published which
was aimed at, among other matters, simplifying planning and ensuring local communities are the keystone of the
planning system. The NPPF underwent a substantive revision in July 2018, resulting in more than 80 reforms, and
was further updated in January 2021. These changes introduced wide scale updates relating to sustainable
development, including references to certain parts of the United Nations’ SDGs, which may impact our operations
and strategy in this area. Other amendments to the NPPF that have been proposed relate to plan-makers being
required to align growth and infrastructure, improvements in the environment and the mitigation of climate change
(including by making effective use of land in urban areas) and adaption to its effects. The proposed changes to the
NPPF that concern design quality, new local Design Codes and new timescale policy for larger-scale
developments may cause some practical transitional difficulties, as councils, developers and local communities
grapple with the creation of new codes and procedures, which may have a material adverse effect on our business,
results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. Furthermore, the UK has recently completed a
‘Planning for the Future’ consultation, which could lead to significant changes to the planning process. The
ultimate aim of this consultation is to simplify the process for obtaining planning permission. However, the
introduction of new planning law would be subject to the interpretation and implementation of Local Authorities
which could introduce uncertainty into the process. The planning reform is currently being reviewed by the new
Secretary of State, which is likely to delay its introduction.

Additionally, there has been significant discussion in the media and among certain politicians in the UK
relating to “land banking,” a practice whereby a person or entity obtains land but does not develop it or develops
it many years after its purchase. Detractors of “land banking” argue that the practice contributes to inflated real
estate prices by limiting the amount of land available for sale in a given area. The Company can hold real estate
for long periods before obtaining planning permission, resolving technical constraints, developing the land and
selling it. While we do not believe we are engaged in “land banking,” as we generally seek to develop our sites
immediately once detailed planning consent and all conditions are discharged (subject to market conditions and
any legal or technical impediments), developing large sites requires an extended period of time and our
development plans sometimes include developing on a phased basis. Any change in legislation aimed at forcing
land owners to develop or sell their real estate holdings within certain prescribed periods (e.g. “use it or lose it”
policies) or which impose additional requirements or taxes on outline planning consents could have a material
adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

In June 2021, the UK Government launched a new initiative called “First Homes” aimed at making home
ownership attainable for local people and key workers who are first-time buyers. This new tenure of home
ownership is expected to be incorporated into planning law in the near future and will become part of a local
authority’s affordable housing policy. This tenure of home ownership will allow people to purchase a home at a
minimum 30% discount to market value in perpetuity, subject to eligibility criteria. This requirement will be part
of the affordable housing obligations of a planning permission (Section 106 agreement) for a site and the costs
associated with it will be deducted from the land value. The same percentage discount must then be passed on
with the sale of the property to future buyers (who must also be first-time buyers). The initial sale must be at a
price no higher than £250,000 (or £420,000 in Greater London) after the discount has been applied. Changes made
to the planning system to support this initiative now require that First Homes properties should account for at least
25% of all affordable housing units delivered by developers through planning obligations. However, as this
initiative is in the early stages of implementation, the longer term impact of the initiative and any additional
changes made to the planning system in relation to it are not yet known.

**_Failure in our procedures, systems and internal controls, including with respect to due diligence and design,_**
**_could expose us to operational losses, contract and execution risk or violations of law and regulation._**

We develop a large number of sites simultaneously in different regions, which requires us to conduct a
large number of operations efficiently and accurately. These operations include, among other things, evaluating
the purchase of the site, conducting environmental, title and other due diligence investigations, designing the
layout and technical aspects of the development, sourcing consultants, materials and subcontractors and managing
subcontractors, contractual and statutory commitments. While we seek to take reasonable steps to ensure that our
procedures, systems and controls are appropriate for our businesses, errors by employees, consultants or
subcontractors, failure to comply with statutory and regulatory requirements, failings or inadequacies in internal
control processes, material or equipment failures or natural disasters or the failure of external systems including
those of our suppliers or counterparties or statutory bodies, could result in operational losses that could adversely
impact our business, results of operations, financial condition, prospects and relationships with customers.


-----

In addition, our existing compliance processes and controls may not be sufficient to prevent or detect
non-compliance, wrongful practices, fraud and violations of law by our employees, contractors, customers,
intermediaries, consultants, joint venture partners or sales agents. We may have limited control over such parties’
actions due to the nature of the business relationship. If any such parties receive or grant inappropriate benefits or
engage in corrupt, fraudulent or other unfair or illegal business practices (including, without limitation, tax
evasion, fraudulent tax schemes, anticompetitive conduct, bribery, corruption, money laundering, modern slavery
or breaches of consumer protection laws), we could incur or become subject to significant financial losses, legal
sanctions, penalties, or reputational damage. In addition, we could lose relationships with public sector entities,
our partners (including public sector partners) and customers, and those parties may therefore be entitled to
terminate their contracts with us. In particular, as much of our business involves tendering for Government
contracts that are awarded on the basis of both financial and non-financial criteria (including compliance),
compliance issues may prejudice our ability to participate in or win such competitive bidding processes for a
significant period of time. See “—Our business depends in part on a strong image and reputation, and any
_negative impact on our image and reputation could adversely affect our business.” For example, in 2019/2020 we_
conducted a record keeping audit and review of the types of our development projects that qualify as “Estate
Agency Work” pursuant to the Money Laundering, Terrorist Financing and Transfer of Funds (Information on the
Payer) Regulations 2017 (the “Regulations”) and as a result require us to conduct Know Your Customer (“KYC”)
procedures for these activities in compliance with the Regulations. We reviewed our internal anti-money
laundering processes and procedures with the assistance of an outside adviser, and found that application of the
Regulations affected a wider range of development projects than originally envisaged and approximately a quarter
of developments projects at that time. Following the review, we made a series of changes to our internal policies
and procedures which included going beyond the requirements of the Regulations and expanding our KYC
procedures to all customers, of which we notified the HMRC in June 2020.

As we expand, we may also be exposed to new clients, suppliers and subcontractors. Although we have
longstanding relationships with many of our partners, there can be no guarantee that our systems and procedures
will insulate us from errors in site valuations, failure to identify material issues in the due diligence process or
errors in the design process (including those that result in failure to comply with statutory or regulatory
requirements).

Additionally, any delay in responding to changes in these laws and regulations, particularly in light of
evolving standards and potential new implementing legislation, may result in penalties for non-compliance with
relevant regulatory requirements. Monitoring and ensuring best practices for our risk management and internal
controls may become increasingly expensive for us in the future, and such risks may be more acute when we
undertake larger-scale projects or during periods of intense activity.

Our internal controls and procedures, policies and our risk management systems may be unable to
adequately address all such risks of non-compliance, which could have a material negative impact on our
reputation, business activities, financial position and results of operations.

**_Our rights in the plots of land that comprise our land pipeline may be limited and we may be subject to_**
**_uncertainties associated with the land contracts we enter into as part of our business._**

Our rights in the plots comprising our land pipeline are generally split into three categories: (i) those sites
and plots for which we have legally completed the deal, (ii) sites and plots that are held under contract (often a
conditional contract), and (iii) those for which we have been appointed preferred developer by the land vendor,
but which have not yet progressed to contract. Our legal interest in the sites in our land pipeline can take the form
of a freehold interest in the land or alternatively take the form of a development lease or license (which provides
us with development rights and exclusivity). On sites where our legal interest takes the form of a development
lease or license and we have defaulted on that site, we could be forced to forfeit our development rights and
exclusivity over that site, retaining no residual interest in the land. Conversely, traditional housebuilders that buy
their sites and plots with an upfront land payment typically receive the freehold interest in a site, which they retain
until the individual homes are sold.

Through our partnership-focused business model, we enter into a variety of arrangements in order to
access plots for development, including conditional land purchase contracts, development agreements,
overarching framework agreements, leases and building licenses. Under conditional land purchase contracts, our
obligation to purchase the land is generally subject to the receipt of planning consent that is acceptable to us. As
there is uncertainty regarding whether the conditions in such contracts will be satisfied, and the timing thereof,
these commitments are not recognized as liabilities on our balance sheet unless or until the applicable
conditionality is removed or it becomes reasonably likely (in our estimate) that we may receive the requisite


-----

planning consents and satisfy the necessary conditions. To the extent such contracts become unconditional, we
will need to commit funds to complete such purchases.

Additionally, the plots in our land pipeline over which we hold title are often the subject of security,
including legal charges or parent company guarantees granted in favor of the vendor to secure the performance of
our obligations under a development agreement. Similarly, for the majority of plots in our land pipeline, our only
rights in such plots are those granted pursuant to comprehensive development/framework agreements that we
enter into with vendors (which do not confer rights to proceed with development without a separate development
agreement). Accordingly, in the event that we fail to deliver a scheme or otherwise breach our obligations under
our development agreements, our vendors may enforce their security or terminate our rights under such
agreements. Any extinguishment of rights in the plots in our land pipeline may have a material adverse effect on
our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

**_Changes in privacy laws could adversely affect our ability to interact effectively with third parties._**

We currently hold, and have previously held, personal data on a variety of parties, including suppliers,
employees, future employees, building users, subcontractors or potential subcontractors and customers or
potential customers who acquire or seek to acquire houses from us. We have engaged, and expect to continue
engaging, in various direct marketing activities to source customers to buy our housing units. As a result, we are
subject to data protection legislation (including the General Data Protection Regulation (EU 2016/679), as it forms
part of the law of the United Kingdom by virtue of the EUWA (the “GDPR”)) and the UK Data Protection Act
2018 (the “UK Data Protection Act”). Non-compliance with the GDPR or UK Data Protection Act, or technical
defects resulting in a leak or the misuse of such data, could result in damage to our reputation and otherwise harm
our business.

The GDPR, which came into effect on May 25, 2018, and was immediately binding across all Member
States of the EU, is a privacy regime regarding the protection of natural persons in relation to the processing of
personal data and the free movement of such data. The GDPR requires companies that process personal data about
EU subjects (either as “data controllers” or as “data processors”) to comply with a large number of obligations
related to, for example, (i) the processing of personal data including transparency, data minimization, accuracy,
storage limitation, security and confidentiality; (ii) the ability of the controller to demonstrate compliance with
such principles (accountability); (iii) the obligation to identify a legal basis before the processing; and (iv) the
rights of data subjects, such as, among others, transparency, a right of access, the right to rectification and the
right to erasure.

The GDPR requires companies to implement a number of formal processes and policies to review and
document the privacy implications of the development, acquisition, or use of all new products, technologies or
types of data. Although we have implemented measures to comply with the GDPR, we cannot ensure that we
remain fully compliant with its obligations under the GDPR. Non-compliance may be met with significant
penalties including fines of up to 4% of total annual worldwide turnover or €20 million (whichever is higher),
depending on the type and severity of the breach. The fine may be imposed instead of, or in addition to, measures
that may be ordered by supervisory authorities (such as the request to cease processing). Compliance with the
GDPR is a rigorous and time-intensive process that may increase our cost of doing business and the failure to
comply with these laws could subject us to significant fines and sanctions. In addition, we do not currently have
specific data security insurance coverage and cannot guarantee that our general liability insurance coverage will
be sufficient to cover all or any liabilities in the event of a breach of our data security systems. Should one or more
of these risks materialize, they could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial
condition and/or prospects.

**_Adverse consequences could occur as a result of changes in tax law or uncertainties in the interpretation and_**
**_application thereof or as a result of Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs (“HMRC”) challenging our tax_**
**_treatment of certain matters._**

Tax rules, including stamp duty land tax provisions and their interpretation, may change, and new taxes
may be introduced, such as the additional stamp duty recently imposed on second homes. Furthermore,
uncertainties can arise as a result of differences in interpretation or application of existing tax law. Any change in
our tax status, in taxation legislation or its interpretation, or in HMRC practice, could affect the value of property
we hold, the average selling price of homes, potential sales and post-tax returns. References in this Offering
Memorandum concerning taxation are based upon current tax law and practice that are subject to change, possibly
with retrospective effect. Any such change could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of
operations, financial condition and/or prospects.


-----

Due to the size and scope of our business, there are a number of matters that HMRC might examine in
detail for any given year. Our potential exposure and the likelihood of HMRC raising a challenge in connection
with any matters is difficult to assess. If HMRC successfully challenges any matters or if other potential tax
matters result in unfavorable outcomes, additional tax liabilities and adverse publicity may follow, which may
have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

**_Any inability to obtain additional surety bonds could limit our future growth._**

We are often required to provide surety bonds to secure our performance under construction contracts,
development agreements and other arrangements. As of July 31, 2021, we had £18.2 million in surety bonds and
£74.9 million of infrastructure bonds outstanding. We have obtained facilities to provide the requisite volume of
surety bonds to meet our current needs, and currently have substantial headroom under those facilities. However,
further growth may require that we obtain additional surety facilities. Our ability to obtain additional surety bonds,
whether from the NHBC or other providers of bond lines, primarily depends upon our financial rating, past
performance, management expertise and the capacity of the surety market. For example, when negotiating
additional surety bonds with the NHBC, consideration is given to the number of plot registrations completed over
the prior four-year period, the group’s rating with the NHBC and the ability to demonstrate how existing bonds
are being managed and released in a timely way (for example, bonds covering roads and sewers works on site are
released when they are progressed towards adoption by the Local Authority highways department and water utility
companies).

A number of factors could limit our ability to obtain appropriate levels of performance bond coverage,
including (i) our ability to maintain our current “premium” NHBC rating (ii) changes to our claims record (iii)
any changes to surety providers’ requirements or policies (iv) the failure of a surety company, particularly where
we cannot get the necessary consent from the issuer’s lenders, and (v) the market’s capacity to provide bonds
sufficient for our growth, which was restricted from 2008 to 2011, when surety bonds in the UK became difficult
to obtain and their costs increased as a result of the financial crisis. The occurrence of any of these events could
affect our ability to compete effectively for new work and may have an adverse impact on our business, results of
operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

**_We have in the past sold, and in the future may sell, certain of our homes to customers with a leasehold instead_**
**_of a freehold interest, and any potential changes to our current legal regime regarding leasehold properties,_**
**_including any retrospective application of new laws or regulations, could have an adverse effect on our_**
**_business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects._**

We usually sell our homes as freeholds. However, we have in the past sold, and in the future may sell,
certain homes as leaseholds. With a freehold property, the buyer acquires the building and the land on which it
stands. With a leasehold property, the buyer only acquires the lease from the freeholder for a fixed period of time,
often between 90 and 999 years. After the lease expires, the buyer has no further legal interest in the property.
Leaseholders are typically required to pay annual ground rent to the freeholder of the land on which the property
sits. Additionally, with the sale of apartments customers will also have to pay a service charge for maintenance of
common areas. Dependent on how much of the communal space (green areas) on a development site is adopted
for maintenance by a local authority, a customer may also have to contribute to an estate service charge on
maintained parts of the overall development. In addition, leaseholders may face restrictions in relation to, or need
to receive permission before, making certain changes to the property over and above estate restrictions, with
permission fees being payable as a result. Furthermore, the leaseholder may be required to pay fees upon the
occurrence of certain events. We sold 4% and 5% of our homes as leaseholds in the financial years ended October
31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. As a result of Government’s changes to the current Help to Buy scheme, for a
customer to be eligible to use the scheme all houses must be sold freehold and only apartments can be sold
leasehold, with the lease terms being customer and not freeholder focused. We are now selling houses freehold
on all of our sites, with the small number of apartments we sell being leasehold.

Following concerns about the fairness, clarity and presentation of some leasehold contract terms in the
consumer sector (which could lead to people incurring unanticipated costly fees over a long period or having to
abide by onerous terms), the Competition and Markets Authority (the “CMA”) launched an investigation in June
2019 to determine whether purchasers are being treated fairly when buying a leasehold home. The investigation
examined two key areas: (1) potential mis-selling, which examines whether individuals who have bought a
leasehold property are given the information they need to fully understand the obligations they are taking on
(including, for example, the requirement to pay ground rent over a certain period of time, or whether they have an
accurate understanding of their ability to buy their freehold); and (2) potential unfair terms, which examines


-----

whether individuals are having to pay excessive fees due to unfair contract terms (including, for example,
administration, service and “permission” charges and ground rents that double after a certain period of time).

In connection with this investigation, the CMA wrote to certain companies across the UK home building
sector (including certain developers, lenders and freeholders – but not Keepmoat) asking for information to better
understand about how leaseholds are sold and managed, and the terms their contracts contain. Following the
CMA’s review of the material provided by market participants, the CMA issued an updated report in February
2020, highlighting their key areas of concern in relation to leasehold sales. These areas included: (1) ground rent,
both in terms of the method of increase (in particular doubling ground rents but also increases by reference to the
retail price index); (2) the impact that ground rent increases might have by virtue of the 1988 Housing Act (as
arrear of ground rent could become grounds for a mandatory possession order); (3) the mis-selling of leasehold
houses (in particular in relation to a lack of information or the stage at which that information was provided); (4)
the level of permission and consent fees; and (5) deficiencies in checks and balances in the sales process to protect
customers.

On September 4, 2020, the CMA opened cases against certain companies in the UK housebuilding sector
(which did not include Keepmoat) in respect of possible breaches of consumer protection law in the residential
leasehold sector. These cases were based on possible instances of mis-selling and potential unfairness of certain
leasehold contract terms. On March 19, 2021, the CMA issued consultation letters to two of those companies in
relation to possible breaches of consumer protection law in the residential leasehold sector. The letters outlined
the CMA’s specific concerns regarding the potential unfairness of terms that double ground rent every 10 or 15
years and asked the developers to take steps to address this point.

The Leasehold Reform (Ground Rent) Bill, which was introduced by the Government on May 12, 2021,
will eliminate the charging of ground rents on new long residential leases and introduce civil penalties for
freeholders that do not comply with this legislation. Under the bill, the Government will reform the process of
enfranchisement valuation leaseholders must follow to calculate the cost of extending their lease or buying their
freehold. The Government will abolish marriage value (being the increase in the value of the property following
the completion of the lease extension, reflecting the additional market value of the longer lease), cap the treatment
of ground rents at 0.1% of the freehold value and prescribe rates for the calculations at market value. The
Government will also introduce an online calculator, further simplifying the process for leaseholds and ensuring
standardization and fairness for all those looking to enfranchise. The Government’s leasehold reform proposals,
when implemented, will only apply in England, although existing legislation does currently apply in both Wales
and England. Scotland operates a separate regime for interdependent units as there are very few leasehold
properties in Scotland.

Any potential changes to the current regime regarding leasehold properties, including any retrospective
application or any breach of consumer protection laws by the business in respect of leasehold properties, could
have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

**_The net realizable value of our build work-in-progress (“WIP”) and land may decline._**

There is an inherent risk that the net realizable value of our build WIP and land, which constitute part of
our inventory and secured land pipeline, respectively, may decline. As a result of our partnership model, we
typically do not hold large land banks for long periods of time awaiting development, and instead have invested
significantly in relatively lower value brownfield sites (which represented 73% and 72% of our legal completions
in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 and the nine months ended July 31, 2021, respectively). However,
we, like other home builders, are nevertheless subject to the risk of declining values. The valuation of a property
development project or land is inherently subjective due to the individual nature of each property and is influenced
by a number of factors. Changes in regulatory requirements and applicable laws (including in relation to building
regulations, taxation, mortgage availability and planning), political and economic conditions, the condition of
financial markets, the financial condition of customers, tax regimes and interest and inflation rate fluctuations all
mean that valuations are subject to uncertainty and adverse macroeconomic events and other unforeseen events
could result in write-downs of our build WIP and land. There can be no assurance that the net realizable value of
land in our financial statements, including the historical financial information included in this Offering
Memorandum, will reflect the actual sale prices achieved of either the land itself or any developments built
thereon.

Land parcels, building lots and housing inventories are illiquid assets, meaning that they may not be
easily sold and converted into cash and that any sale may not be capable of being completed quickly without


-----

accepting a lower price than may be otherwise offered, and we may not be able to dispose of them efficiently or
at all if the Group or the housing market and general economy are in financial distress.

If any of the risks described above were to materialize, they could adversely affect the value of our land
or developments, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial
condition and/or prospects.

**_Ownership, leasing or occupation of land as well as home building carries potential environmental risks and_**
**_liabilities, including liability under claims for damages as a result of use of hazardous materials, including_**
**_asbestos._**

Environmental legislation imposes strict and retrospective liability for cleaning up contaminated land,
watercourses or groundwater on the person causing or knowingly permitting the contamination in circumstances
where such contamination is causing, or where there is a significant possibility of it causing, significant harm to
people or the environment. As a result, we may be liable for the costs of investigation, remediation or removal of
hazardous or toxic substances located on, under or in a property that we currently or formerly owned, leased or
occupied, irrespective of whether we caused or knew of the pollution. The impact of such laws, regulations and
policies can vary greatly from site to site, depending on, among other things, the scope of work undertaken, the
site’s environmental condition and the present and former uses of the site. Environmental laws, regulations and
policies may give rise to substantial compliance or remediation costs and requirements, and delay, prohibit or
severely restrict development at our sites. We also could incur substantial costs, including clean-up costs, fines,
penalties and third party claims for personal injury or property damage as a result of violations of, or liabilities
under, such laws, regulations and policies.

We routinely acquire properties on the basis that we accept all contamination risk associated with the
property, and often provide vendors with indemnities covering any liabilities which the vendor may face under
environmental laws following the sale. The costs associated with the management of such substances, or the costs
of defending against environmental claims may be substantial, and our recourse to the contractors that perform
our remediation work may be restricted by contractual limitations, the lapse of time or the insolvency of such
contractors, among other factors. The presence of such substances, or the failure to remediate such substances
properly, may also adversely affect our ability to sell the land or, where relevant, borrow using the land as security.

As a substantial proportion of the Group’s developments are on brownfield sites, we are subject to an
increased risk that some of our development projects are located on land that may have been contaminated or
rendered geologically unstable by previous use.

For example, at our Nightingale Road site, where we plan to build 372 homes in partnership with the
Derby Council, a report prepared for councilors warned that land contamination could affect the project’s financial
viability and completion date. The report classified the risk as “moderate risk (remediation works to be
completed).” We are currently in the process of remediating the site under license with independent competent
consultants monitoring the work being undertaken. It is expected that following completion and verification of
the remediation in accordance with the planning permission (including remediation strategy), the site will be
classed as having been remediated to the high standard required for the sale of residential homes. However, if the
site is not classed as having been remediated to such standard, we would be obliged to undertake remedial work
to address any defective work.

Although we aim to carry out appropriate due diligence before acquiring properties, any deficiencies in
our due diligence process could result in our failure to identify all major constraints and risks. In addition,
following legal transfer of the land to us, we bear public liability risk as well as associated maintenance and health,
safety and environmental risks. Contaminants resulting from historical operations have been detected at some of
our development sites, one of which was the Nightingale Road site. This is not unusual for brownfield sites and
as such, our business approach is to acquire these sites and remediate them to the standard required for residential
development. Although we do not currently expect any remedial obligations to have a material effect on our
financial condition, we could incur substantial additional costs as a result of additional contamination that is
identified or additional obligations that are imposed at these or other sites in the future. We are particularly
susceptible to this risk where historical off-site migration of contamination has occurred prior to our acquisition
of a site, which has not otherwise been identified as part of the legal or technical due diligence process. Laws and
regulations may also impose liability for the release of certain materials from land into the air or water, including
asbestos, and such release can form the basis for liability to third persons for personal injury or other damages. It
is unlikely that such claims would be fully or partially covered by our present or future insurance. See “—We may
_be subject to increases in insurance premiums or fail to secure or maintain adequate insurance coverage.”_


-----

As a home building business with a wide variety of development related activities, we could be liable for
future claims for damages as a result of our past or present use of hazardous or potentially unsafe materials
(including materials that are not currently deemed unsafe but in the future may become known to be hazardous or
unsafe). When beginning work at a site, we are exposed to the risk of various liabilities, including negligent and
non-negligent damage to third party assets, local planning violations and health, safety and environmental
incidents. For example, when we enter a site, we may inadvertently damage third party assets such as underground
cables, sewers or pipes on a negligent or non-negligent basis. For example, certain work site vibrations may affect
properties nearby and certain excavation procedures may cause collapses on third party land. We have also been
subject to claims in which our former employees, employees of our subcontractors and third parties have
successfully claimed damages in relation to hazardous materials and other environmental and health and safety
