**_Upon an IPO Debt Pushdown, material Collateral and Note Guarantees may be released and materially reduce_**
**_the value of the Collateral and/or guarantee package, any retaken Collateral may be subject to hardening_**
**_periods, and holders of the Notes may have adverse tax consequences._**

Under certain circumstances, we may undertake the transactions described in “Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement—Provisions Following an IPO” (such transactions, an “IPO_
**Debt Pushdown”), pursuant to which the Issuers are entitled to give notice that will automatically operate so that,**
among other things, the references in the Indenture and any Intercreditor Agreement to such Issuer and Restricted
Subsidiaries shall apply only to the IPO Pushdown Entity (as defined in “Description of Certain Financing
_Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement— Provisions Following an IPO”) and its Restricted Subsidiaries (as_
defined in “Description of the Notes”). In such event, each holding or parent company of the IPO Pushdown Entity
would be released from its obligations under the applicable Debt Documents (as defined in the Intercreditor
Agreement), which would include the release of Note Guarantees and Collateral provided by such entities. There
are no restrictions on the transfer of assets to such entities prior to an IPO Debt Pushdown, and any such release
may materially reduce the Collateral and/or guarantor coverage securing the Notes. Moreover, we may elect to,
but are not under any obligation to, revoke or otherwise reverse an IPO Debt Pushdown undertaken in anticipation
of an initial public offering, or to replace any Note Guarantees or Collateral released pursuant thereto, in the event
such initial public offering is not consummated. To the extent that new security documents in respect of any
Collateral to be retaken (including a charge over the shares of the Issuer) are entered into, such Collateral may be
subject to new hardening periods. In addition, such modifications to the terms of the Notes, including any change
in the primary obligor or guarantors of the Notes in connection with an IPO Debt Pushdown, could be treated for
U.S. federal income tax purposes as a deemed exchange of (i) the Notes as in place prior to such modifications
for (ii) new Notes as in place after such modifications. If such modifications result in a deemed exchange for U.S.
federal income tax purposes, such deemed exchange generally would be treated as a taxable transaction for U.S.
federal income tax purposes in which beneficial owners of the Notes may be required to recognize gain or, subject
to possible application of the “wash sale” rules, loss. Furthermore, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, the new
Notes deemed issued in such a deemed exchange could be treated as issued with original issue discount. In such
event, holders subject to U.S. federal income taxation would be required to include the original issue discount in
their income (as ordinary income) as it accrues (on a constant yield to maturity basis), in advance of the receipt of
cash corresponding to such income. Holders subject to U.S. federal income taxation should consult their own tax
advisors as to the U.S. federal income tax considerations relating to potential modifications of the Notes in
connection with an IPO Debt Pushdown. It is also possible that an IPO Debt Pushdown could result in a taxable
event for tax purposes other than U.S. federal income tax purposes.

**_We may not be able to obtain the funds required to repurchase the Notes upon a Change of Control and the_**
**_occurrence of certain important corporate events will not constitute a Change of Control._**

The Indenture will contain provisions relating to certain events constituting a “Change of Control” (as
defined in the Indenture). Upon the occurrence of a Change of Control, we will be required to offer to repurchase
all outstanding Notes at a price equal to 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and
additional amounts, if any, to the date of repurchase. If a Change of Control were to occur, we cannot assure you
that we would have sufficient funds available at such time, or that we would have sufficient funds to provide to
the Issuer to pay the purchase price of the outstanding Notes or that the restrictions in the Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement, the Indenture, the Intercreditor Agreement or our other than existing contractual obligations would
allow us to make such required repurchases. A Change of Control may trigger a mandatory prepayment of the
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and other indebtedness. The repurchase of the Notes pursuant to such an
offer could cause a default under such indebtedness, even if the Change of Control itself does not. The ability of
the Issuer to receive cash from its subsidiaries to allow it to pay cash to the holders of the Notes following the
occurrence of a Change of Control, may be limited by our then existing financial resources. If we repay a portion
of the Notes in an amount over 50% of the principal amount of the Notes in aggregate, we will be required under
the terms of the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement to reduce the commitments under the Revolving Credit
Facility proportionately in accordance with the terms of the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. Sufficient funds
may not be available when necessary to make any required repurchases. If an event constituting a Change of
Control were to occur at a time when our group is prohibited from providing funds to the Issuer for the purpose
of repurchasing the Notes, we may seek the consent of the lenders under such indebtedness to the purchase of the
Notes or may attempt to refinance the borrowings that contain such prohibition. If such a consent to repay such
borrowings is not obtained, the Issuer would remain prohibited from repurchasing any Notes. In addition, we
expect that we would require third-party financing to make an offer to repurchase the Notes upon a Change of
Control. We cannot assure you that our Group would be able to obtain such financing. Any failure by the Issuer
to offer to purchase the Notes would constitute a default under the Indenture, which would, in turn, constitute a
default under the Revolving Credit Facility. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.”


-----

The Change of Control provision contained in the Indenture may not necessarily afford you protection
in the event of certain important corporate events, including a reorganization, restructuring, merger or other similar
transaction involving us that may adversely affect you, because such corporate events may not involve a shift in
voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do, may not constitute a Change of Control as defined in
the Indenture. Except as described under “Description of the Notes—Change of Control,” the Indenture will not
contain provisions that would require the Issuer to offer to repurchase or redeem the Notes in the event of a
reorganization, restructuring, merger, recapitalization or similar transaction.

In addition, the occurrence of certain events that might otherwise constitute a Change of Control will be
deemed not to be a Change of Control if a certain net consolidated leverage ratio calculated in accordance with
the “Description of the Notes” is not exceeded in connection with such an event. In this case holders of Notes
would not be entitled to require the Issuer to repurchase their Notes and would only be able to rely on the then
prevailing trading prices in order to exit their investments, which might be lower than the 101% change of control
repurchase price. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control” and “Description of the Notes—Certain
_Definitions—Change of Control Triggering Event.”_

The definition of Change of Control in the Indenture will include a disposition of all or substantially all
of the assets of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries (if any), taken as a whole, to any person. Although there
is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase “all or substantially all,” there is no precise established
definition of the phrase under applicable law. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there may be a degree of
uncertainty as to whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition of “all or substantially all” of the
Issuer’s assets and its restricted subsidiaries taken as a whole. As a result, it may be unclear as to whether a Change
of Control has occurred and whether the Issuer is required to make an offer to repurchase the relevant Notes.

**_The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures of the relevant_**
**_clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies._**

Owners of the book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of relevant Notes unless and
until definitive notes are issued in exchange for book-entry interests. Instead, the common depositary (or its
nominee) for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the Notes in global form.

Payments of principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the Notes in global form will
be made to the Principal Paying Agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and Clearstream. Thereafter, such
payments will be credited to Euroclear and Clearstream participants’ accounts that hold book-entry interests in
the Notes in global form and credited by such participants to indirect participants. After payment to Euroclear and
Clearstream, none of the Issuer, the Guarantors, the Trustee, Transfer Agent, Principal Paying Agent or the
Registrar will have any responsibility or liability for any aspect of the records relating to or payments of interest,
principal or other amounts to Euroclear and Clearstream, or to owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if you
own a book-entry interest in the Notes, you must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream and, if you
are not a participant in Euroclear and/or Clearstream, on the procedures of the participant through which you own
your interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of the Notes under the Indenture.

Owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right to act upon our solicitations for consents or
requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Notes, including the enforcement of security for the Notes
and the Notes Guarantees. Instead, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be reliant on the common depositary
(or its nominee) (as registered holder of the Notes) to act on your instructions and/or will be permitted to act
directly only to the extent you have received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and Clearstream or, if
applicable, from a participant. We cannot assure you that procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies
will be sufficient to enable you to vote on any requested actions or to take any other action on a timely basis.

Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture, unless and until the relevant
Definitive Registered Notes are issued in respect of all book-entry interests, if you own a book-entry interest, you
will be restricted to acting through Euroclear and Clearstream. We cannot assure you that the procedures to be
implemented through Euroclear and Clearstream will be adequate to ensure the timely exercise of rights under the
Notes.


-----

**_There may not be an active trading market for the Notes, in which case your ability to sell the Notes may be_**
**_limited._**

We cannot assure you as to:

      - the liquidity of any market in the Notes;

      - your ability to sell your Notes; or

      - the price at which you would be able to sell your Notes.

Future trading prices for the Notes will depend on many factors, including, among other things,
prevailing interest rates, our operating results and the market for similar securities. Historically, the market for
non-investment-grade securities has been subject to disruptions that have caused substantial volatility in the prices
of securities similar to the Notes. The liquidity of a trading market for the Notes may be adversely affected by a
general decline in the market for similar securities and is subject to disruptions that may cause volatility in prices.
The trading market for the Notes may attract different investors and this may affect the extent to which the Notes
may trade. It is possible that the market for the Notes will be subject to disruptions. Any such disruption may have
a negative effect on you, as a holder of the Notes, regardless of our prospects and financial performance. As a
result, there can be no assurance that there will be an active trading market for the Notes. If no active trading
market develops, you may not be able to resell your holding of the Notes at a fair value, if at all.

Although an application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the
Notes on the Exchange we cannot assure you that the Notes will be or remain listed. Although no assurance can
be made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of the admission to the Exchange, failure to be approved for
listing or the delisting (whether or not for an alternative admission to listing on another stock exchange) of the
Notes from the Exchange may have a material effect on a holder’s ability to resell the Notes in the secondary
market.

In addition, the Indenture will allow us to issue additional Notes in the future, which could adversely
impact the liquidity of the relevant Notes.

**_United States civil liabilities may not be enforceable against us._**

The Issuer and all of the Guarantors are incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, and all of
our assets are located outside the United States. In addition, all members of our board and our officers reside
outside the United States. As a result, it may be difficult for investors to effect service of process within the United
States upon us or such other persons residing outside the United States, or to enforce outside the United States
judgments obtained against such persons in United States courts in any action. In addition, it may be difficult for
investors to enforce, in original actions brought in courts in jurisdictions located outside the United States, rights
predicated upon United States laws. See “Service of Process and Enforcement of Civil Liabilities.”

The United States and England currently do not have a treaty providing for the reciprocal recognition
and enforcement of judgments (as opposed to arbitration awards) in civil and commercial matters. This may give
rise to difficulties in respect of the enforcement in England and Wales of judgments obtained in the United States.
See “Service of Process and Enforcement of Civil Liabilities.”

**_Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject_**
**_to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time._**

One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The credit ratings
address our ability to perform our obligations under the terms of the Notes and credit risks in determining the
likelihood that payments will be made when due under the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact
of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed above and other factors that may affect
the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject
to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit
rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn
entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension,
reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the relevant Notes by one or more of the credit
rating agencies may adversely affect the cost, terms and conditions of our financings, and could adversely affect
the value and trading of the Notes.


-----

**_The transferability of the Notes may be limited under applicable securities laws._**

The Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act
or the securities laws of any state or any other jurisdiction and, unless so registered, may not be offered or sold in
the United States, except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration
requirements of the Securities Act and the applicable securities laws of any state or any other jurisdiction. The
Notes are not being offered for sale in the United States except to QIBs in accordance with Rule 144A. We have
not agreed to or otherwise undertaken to register the Notes with the US Securities and Exchange Commission
(including by way of an exchange offer). See “Notice to Investors.” It is the obligation of holders of the Notes to
ensure that their offers and sales of the Notes within the United States and other countries comply with applicable
securities laws.

**_Investors may face foreign exchange risks by investing in the Notes._**

The Notes will be denominated and payable in pound sterling. If investors measure their investment
returns by reference to a currency other than the pound sterling, an investment in the Notes will entail foreign
exchange-related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the pound sterling
relative to the currency by reference to which such investors measure the return on their investments. These
changes may be due to economic, political and other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the
pound sterling against the currency by reference to which such investors measure the return on their investments
could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss
to investors when the return on the Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which such investors
measure the return on their investments.

**_Investors in the Notes may have limited recourse against the independent auditors._**

In respect of the auditors’ reports relating to the consolidated financial statements of the Group
reproduced herein, PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, the Group’s independent auditors, states the following: “This
report, including the opinions, has been prepared for and only for the company’s members as a body in accordance
with Chapter 3 of Part 16 of the Companies Act 2006. We do not, in giving these opinions, accept or assume
responsibility for any other purpose or to any other person to whom this report is shown or into whose hands it
may come save where expressly agreed by our prior consent in writing.”

Investors in the Notes should understand that, in making these statements, the independent auditors
confirmed that they do not accept or assume any liability to parties (such as the purchasers of the Notes) other
than the Group with respect to the report and to the independent auditors’ audit work and opinion. The SEC would
not permit such limiting language to be included in a registration statement or a prospectus used in connection
with an offering of securities registered under the US Securities Act, or in a report filed under the US Exchange
Act. If a US court (or any other court) were to give effect to the language quoted above, the recourse that investors
in the Notes may have against the independent auditors based on their report or the combined and consolidated
financial information to which they relate could be limited.

**_Our majority shareholder may have interests that do not align with yours._**

Following the Acquisition, the Company will be indirectly owned by funds and co-investment vehicles
managed by Aermont together with certain management shareholders. Aermont is an independent asset
management group focused on real estate and real estate related investment activities. Aermont has the power to
control our affairs and policies and also controls, to a large degree, the election of directors, the appointment of
management and the entry into mergers, sales of substantially all of our assets and other extraordinary transactions.
The directors so elected will have authority, subject to the terms of our indebtedness (including the Notes), to
issue additional stock, implement stock repurchase programs, declare dividends and make other decisions. The
interests of our majority shareholder could conflict with your interests. For example, if we encounter financial
difficulties or are unable to pay our indebtedness as it matures, the interests of our majority shareholder and certain
of its affiliates as equity holders might conflict with your interests as a holder of the Notes. Aermont may also
have an interest in pursuing acquisitions, divestitures, financings or other transactions that, in its judgment, could
enhance its equity investments, even though such transactions might involve risks to you as a holder of the Notes.
Additionally, Aermont is in the business of making investments in companies, and may from time to time acquire
interests in businesses that directly or indirectly compete with certain portions of our business or are suppliers or
customers of ours. For more information, see “Our Shareholder” and “Related Party Transactions.”

**USE OF PROCEEDS**

The Offering is expected to be consummated prior to the completion of the Acquisition. To the extent
the Acquisition will not complete on or shortly after the Issue Date, pending consummation of the Acquisition, on
the Issue Date, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Account. The
release of the Escrow Proceeds will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including the closing of
the Acquisition.

The aggregate gross proceeds from the Offering will be £275 million. The Issuer intends to use the gross
proceeds from the Offering, together with the Equity Contribution, to: (i) fund the consideration payable for the
Acquisition, (ii) repay Existing Target Indebtedness, (iii) repay Sellers transaction costs, and (iv) pay the fees and
expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions.

The following table illustrates the estimated sources and uses with respect to the Transactions. Actual
amounts may vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the date of consummation of
the Acquisition, the cash consideration to be paid pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement on the Completion Date,
the outstanding balances due under the Existing Target Indebtedness as of the Completion Date, the amount of
the Equity Contribution and the difference between estimated and actual fees and expenses incurred in connection
with the Transactions.

In particular, the purchase price under the Acquisition Agreement as shown below reflects the agreed
base consideration as adjusted for our estimates of an agreed ticker fee accruing until the Completion Date and
certain notified cash leakage items, certain payments arising as a result of the Transactions and certain other
adjustments required under the Acquisition Agreement. This amount is expected to change depending on number
of factors, including, among others, the timing of the Completion Date.

**Overview**

We are one of the UK’s oldest and most experienced partnership housebuilders, with “5-Star
Homebuilder” status awarded in 2021. We are focused on creating sustainable communities in places where
people want to live, and we specialize in the delivery of affordable and high quality homes, principally targeted
at first-time buyers. Headquartered in Doncaster, England, we operate across England and Scotland through nine
operating regions. We are a top ten UK housebuilder, measured by the number of homes sold, including delivering
4,035 homes in our financial year ended October 31, 2019.

Unlike traditional housebuilders, our business model is based on partnerships with entities interested in
seeing an increase in supply of homes as well as those with demand for our product. These partners are primarily
land owners (such as Homes England, Local Authorities and private land owners) or Registered Providers, which
include the traditional not-for-profit and the newer for-profit entities that are registered with the Regulator of
Social Housing to provide affordable housing. We engage each of our key stakeholders in residential projects by
establishing, aligning and prioritizing their needs and successfully delivering their objectives. We have built our
reputation by aligning our approach to our partners’ objectives regarding the sourcing, procurement, planning and
delivery of successful, affordable housing developments that create significant social value. We believe that we
are the original partnership-focused housebuilder in the United Kingdom, having worked with over 200 partners
to date, with many of these relationships enduring for over 20 years.

Our partnership model allows us to have a high degree of certainty over our land pipeline, with sufficient
land secured for six years of development based on our future development plans and on 2019 home deliveries,
while also typically allowing us to defer payment until milestones are met. We are also able to minimize
development and planning risks by partnering with land owners through the early stages of a development project.
Coupled with the relatively low land costs for the affordable homes that we target, we are able to operate a capitallight business model relative to traditional housebuilders, and generate relatively strong cash conversion and
ROCE. In the financial year ended October 31, 2019, the last full financial year prior to the start of the COVID19 pandemic, our ROCE was 32.8%.


-----

We focus on developing urban and suburban locations where there is an inherent demand and supply
imbalance for new homes. We aim to meet this demand through our five core standard house type ranges. This
standardization allows efficiency in procuring materials and construction, increased certainty of cost and timing
of delivery, and assists in establishing optimal site layout mix based on demand and our partners’ preferences. We
are continually working with new technologies that underpin and refine our designs.

We are committed to deliver a range of affordable housing, predominantly for open market sale, social
housing and shared ownership – which provides us with a higher degree of market resilience over the long term
due to generally consistent demand from first-time buyers and well-funded Registered Providers. In the financial
year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 74% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to
private customers as well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a
site), with the remaining approximately 26% of our sales comprising sales to Registered Providers that are
contracted at the outset of development of a site, including but not limited to those contracted to satisfy Section
106 obligations. Approximately 87% of our open market sales in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 were
to private sale customers, of which approximately 76% were to first-time buyers (first-time buyers accounted for
76% during the financial year ended October 31, 2019). In the financial year ended October 31, 2020,
approximately 45% of our total sales, including 67% of sales to first time buyers, involved the use of the
Government HTB scheme. We believe that first-time buyers provide more resilient structural demand than the
typically discretionary and cyclical home-mover segment.

Sustainability is also a key driver of our operations, with a particular focus on community-building and
place making. In July 2020, following stakeholder consultation, we published our Sustainability Strategy in which
we identified our material issues and aligned our strategy to eight United Nations Sustainable Development Goals
SDGs. Through our Sustainability Strategy, we have committed to minimizing our impact on the environment
and biodiversity. In particular, we have announced that we intend to achieve a net zero carbon position by the
mid-2040s (having formally committed to Race to Zero) and that we intend to publicly disclose our carbon
performance from 2022 onwards.

We were active on 94 sites as of July 31, 2021. In addition, as of July 31, 2021, the number of plots
within our land pipeline was 24,654, with approximately 81% of our land pipeline, or 19,933 plots, being legally
secured (meaning that we have a contractual right to develop or a conditionally exchanged contract). As of July
31, 2021, approximately 19% of our land pipeline, or 4,721 plots, were those on which we had been appointed


-----

preferred developer (meaning that we had been chosen by the land vendor as the final candidate to progress to
contract for the development of the site). Together, these plots are equivalent to a six-year supply of homes, based
on our pre-pandemic annual completion levels.

As of July 31, 2021, we had a forward order book of approximately £503 million (representing 3,151
plots) with an open market sales rate of 0.77 for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021. As of September 19,
2021, we had reserved, exchanged or legally completed almost all of our planned sales for the financial year
ending October 31, 2021. Furthermore, as of September 19, 2021, we had secured approximately 40% of our
planned sales for the year ended October 31, 2022, 85% of our planned sales for the three months ended January
31, 2022, and 45% of our planned sales for the three months ended April 30, 2022. As of September 19, 2021, we
had an eight-week rolling average rate of 0.93, demonstrating continued strong demand from our customers.

Our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 were £628.5 million and
£73.8 million, respectively. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data.” Over the same
period, we generated Free Cash Flow of £44.1 million (and free cash flow conversion of 59.8%). The resilience
of our business model was demonstrated through the COVID-19 pandemic. Working with our partners, we were
able to agree a deferral of 89% of committed and uncommitted land spend, without losing any site investment
opportunities as a result. We believe our financial results in recent quarters demonstrate the resiliency and strength
of our business model.

Our focus on partnerships provides us with an attractive financial model, benefitting from typically lower
land values, attractive (and often deferred) payment terms, the potential for additional elective deals with
Registered Providers (beyond sales in connection with Section 106 affordable housing obligations) and access to

**Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations**

Our results of operations have been, and will continue to be, affected by many factors, some of which
are beyond our control. This section sets out certain key factors that we believe have affected our results of
operations in the period under review or could affect its results of operations in the future.

**_Strength of the UK Housing Market and General Macro-economic Conditions in the UK_**

As we operate and generate our revenue exclusively in the UK, our results are dependent on conditions
in the UK housing market and general macro-economic conditions in the UK — in particular, the demand for
housing and the average selling prices of houses in the regions where we operate. Demand for housing is driven
by a combination of factors, such as the rate of economic growth (both nationally and regionally), the rate of
population growth, the average age and life expectancy of the population, the rate of household formation, the
availability and affordability of mortgages, consumer confidence, the unemployment rate and governmental tax
and incentive schemes (such as the stamp duty rates, holidays and the HTB scheme). Historically, the strength of
the UK housing market and of the housebuilding sector has been linked to that of the UK economy as a whole,
which in turn is influenced by both European and global macro-economic conditions, all of which have been
cyclical in the past. Periods of economic downturn in the UK have generally been correlated with decreases in
demand for homes and in house prices, while favorable economic conditions have generally been correlated with
higher demand and increases in house prices. Since 2013, the UK housing market has benefitted from an improved
economic backdrop, as well as from increased Government support (including from the HTB scheme that started
in 2013). This has contributed to a rise in housebuilding completions to 178,310 in the year ended December 31,
2019, the highest level since 2007.

Nevertheless, the housing market is subject to its own independent dynamics and demand for housing
may sometimes not correlate directly with the broader macro-economic climate. For example, although the
COVID-19 pandemic had a significant effect on UK housebuilders (including Keepmoat) during 2020 as a result
of curtailed construction during the first national lockdown — with the MHCLG estimating that completions and
starts of new homes in England fell 17% and 16%, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020 — in
general the UK housing market has seen robust demand during the pandemic, notwithstanding macro-economic
uncertainty. Nationwide and Halifax reported house price increases of 7.3% and 6.0%, respectively, in the year
ended December 31, 2020 — the strongest annual growth since 2016. Mortgage lending has also been resurgent
with an average of 95,806 monthly mortgage approvals for house purchases in the seven months ended February
28, 2021, the strongest level since 2007. More recent indicators suggest this momentum has continued, with the
number of UK residential purchases in March 2021 being 102.3% higher than March 2020 and 32.2% higher than


-----

February 2021. This momentum has been supported by the tapered extension to September 30, 2021 of the stamp
duty holiday first announced in July 2020.

While macroeconomic factors broadly affect the UK residential property market as a whole, property
trends in the UK historically have varied significantly by region, particularly as between London and the South
East on the one hand and the rest of the UK on the other hand. We operate primarily in lower cost regions (with
all of our nine regions based outside of the greater London area, primarily in the Midlands and the North) where
homes are generally more affordable and where prices tend not to fluctuate as much as in higher cost regions. As
a result, our homes are generally priced at the more affordable end of the market (with an ASP of £174,000 in the
nine months ended July 31, 2021 and £165,000 in the financial year ended October 31, 2020), providing us with
a degree of resilience against macroeconomic downturns. Additionally, in many of these lower cost regions,
mortgages are typically more affordable than rents, which provides additional impetus for first-time buyers to buy
in lieu of renting.

We sell the majority of our homes into the private market, but we are committed to a strategy of delivering
homes of mixed tenure – predominantly for open market sale, affordable rent and shared ownership – helping to
provide a degree of resilience in the longer term through diversification. In the financial year ended October 31,
2020, 74% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as well as elective
sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a site), with the remaining 26% of sales
to Registered Providers for affordable housing pursuant to Section 106 obligations or otherwise agreed with
Registered Providers at the outset of development, where we believe demand is less subject to changing
macroeconomic conditions. Approximately 87% of our open market sales in the financial year ended October 31,
2020 were to private sale customers, of which approximately 76% were to first-time buyers (74% in the financial
year ended October 31, 2019). The ASP of our homes sold through open market sales in the financial year ended
October 31, 2020 was £165,000.

Each of our regions develops and markets its homes according to local conditions and competes with
both new build housing providers who sell houses at a price point similar to us and the secondary housing market.
As a result, local market valuations of both new and secondary homes can impact prices and our revenues. Our
results are also affected to a certain extent by the supply of housing in the second hand-market, as increased stock
in the second-hand market typically leads to lower demand for, and fewer opportunities to construct, new homes.

However, in general, the supply of housing in the UK market has lagged behind demand, and the regions
where we operate in particular are characterized by a supply-demand imbalance. This shortfall has created
favorable trends for housing developers and has encouraged the UK and devolved Scottish governments to take
various stimulus measures, which have been beneficial for us. The Government has announced their target to build
300,000 homes per year by the mid-2020s (as announced in the Autumn Budget 2017), and we expect there to be
continued support for the housebuilding sector as the Government seeks to achieve this target.

**_Our Land Pipeline and Land Creditor Profile_**

Our business and financial returns are highly dependent on acquiring land suitable for new homes on
acceptable commercial terms and developing such projects without significant delay. A significant portion of our
cost of sales relate to the costs of purchasing land. In general, lower land prices help us to sustain a capital light
business model and is one of the components of achieving favorable returns. The costs of securing land in our
consolidated income statement from period to period will be influenced by the terms on which the land is secured
— in particular, whether payment is made up front, in phases or on deferred payment terms. Therefore, our results
of operations are significantly affected by the price of land, and the terms on which it is acquired or secured for
development.

As of July 31, 2021, the number of plots within our land pipeline was 24,654, with approximately 81%
of our land pipeline, or 19,933 plots, being legally secured (meaning that we have a contractual right to develop
or a conditionally exchanged contract). As of July 31, 2021, approximately 19% of our land pipeline, or 4,721
plots, were those on which we had been appointed preferred developer (meaning that we had been chosen by the
land vendor as the final candidate to progress to contract for the development of the site). Together, these plots
are equivalent to a six-year supply of homes, based on our pre-pandemic annual completion levels. Our land
pipeline provides us with a significant degree of visibility with respect to expected home completions and, as a
result, our revenues in the near to medium term.

Our partnership-focused business model differentiates us from most traditional UK housebuilders in the
type of land we focus on and the way we source and deliver the land. We source land through both public and


-----

private sector partners. We believe that by understanding the bid brief and being agile and resourceful in delivering
on land vendors’ requirements, we make ourselves an attractive partner. Land sourced through our partnership
model constituted 79% of our total land pipeline as of July 31, 2021, with the remainder being sourced through
speculative land deals (where we believe we can achieve attractive financial returns).

Our largest source of land is the public sector, typically Homes England and Local Authorities, with
whom we achieve a high proportion of repeat business. These projects are usually brought to market through a
competitive tender process, determined by the FTS (previously OJEU) process, which governs how the public
sector disposes of its land assets and procures development services. In the case of Homes England, this is effected
through DPP3, of which we are a member. As of July 31, 2021, approximately 19% of our secured land pipeline
was secured through the Homes England DPP process. Historically, being a member of DPP3 has reduced the
number of competitors that we compete against to secure large scale public land opportunities, providing us access
to development sites typically unavailable to housebuilders who are not members of DPP3. Homes England
launched its successor to the DPP, the DPDPS, on September 1, 2021, which is designed to modernize the bidding
process through the use of a digital system and encourage new entrants to the market, simplifying the process for
housebuilders to join the list of preferred developers and bid for land. We have submitted our application and
received confirmation that we have been appointed member of the DPDPS. The DPDPS is not expected to be used
to procure schemes until late 2021. With this new system, housebuilders will still have to qualify to be able to join
the list of preferred developers, but they will be able to apply to join at any time, rather than only upon renewal
of the delivery partner panel once every four years, as is currently the case. However, we believe that the depth of
our experience working with Homes England and other public sector partners on large scale development projects
provide us with a distinct competitive advantage. We also source land from the private sector, through
relationships with a small number of national land owners and regionally with land owners and land agents.

Public bodies often focus on disposing of brownfield land, which typically has a lower land value and
can therefore provide a greater potential upside upon development (depending on regeneration costs). This
contributes to our relatively low average land cost (approximately £20,000 per plot (equating to approximately
12.1% of our average ASP of £165,000) in the financial year ended October 31, 2020). Brownfield sites
represented 73% of our legal completions in the financial year ended October 31, 2020.

Our participation in a partnership development may be structured in a number of ways, which are
intended to provide a blend of risk and return appropriate to the land being acquired. Arrangements may involve
that we acquire the land being developed (sometimes in phases) or otherwise we may be granted with development
rights while the original land owner retains ownership of the site and ultimately transfers completed units directly
to the home purchaser. In the case of phased drawdowns, the price is generally finalized at the time the Group is
ready to draw the particular phase of the site down for development. In such arrangements, we have sufficient
time to complete all of our technical due-diligence to be able to appraise the phase based on the prevailing
conditions, utilizing all the experience gained from developing the previous phase. Phased drawdowns provide us
with increased visibility of the end-market and associated cost implications, which thereby reduces our market
risk associated with pre-bought land.

Additionally, where possible, we use deferred payment terms. As of July 31, 2021, approximately 86%
of our current land pipeline included some form of deferred land payment terms. In these arrangements, rather
than paying for the land up front, payments are typically structured with deferred payments to be made either on
fixed dates, on a “pay per plot” sold basis or in instalments tied to milestones such as the sale of a defined
cumulative number of plots or similar development milestones. In addition, some of our arrangements with
development partners include overage mechanisms, whereby we make additional payments to the development
partner following completion of the land sale contingent upon exceeding agreed financial thresholds, with such
payments often deferred to the end of the development of a site or a significant phase of the development.
Together, these deferred payment obligations and overage obligations comprise our land creditor commitments.
See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources—Commitments and Contingent Liabilities—Land Creditor
_Commitments” below for further details of our land creditor commitments as of July 31, 2021._

We believe that our land creditor profile provides us with an element of risk mitigation, as the majority
of our payments are linked to development delivery milestones rather than needing to be made up front. Our land
creditor commitments are unwound as the relevant payments for these deferred land costs fall due and are made
from period to period.

Our results of operations during each period will therefore be affected by a variety of factors related to
land procurement, including the number of developments, the number of completions and the structure of the


-----

partnership arrangement (in particular, whether we are acquiring the land, whether the drawdown is in phases and
whether there are deferred payment terms).

**_The Planning Approval Process_**

The development of land is partly driven by the timing of the planning approval process, including the
receipt of those consents which are required to deliver proposed schemes. The overall timeframe for completing
the planning approval process affects how quickly we are able to realize revenue from our developments, and any
complications that arise during the planning process can increase our costs, including those related to third party
planning experts. The planning approval process typically takes from six to twelve months, depending on the
complexity of the application and may take a longer or shorter amount of time.

We are required to comply with national, local and other laws and regulations and administrative
requirements and policies relating to, among other things, planning, developing, building and land use. In addition,
we are required to obtain numerous permits and approvals from local authorities and other regulatory bodies
regarding, among other things, remediation, roads, drainage, utilities, including gas, electricity and water, and
waste removal as well as UK Town & Country Planning Act obligations. These requirements are more complex
when we are developing brownfield sites.

Of the 24,654 plots in our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021, approximately 19,400, or 79%, benefit from
a planning permission, of which 66% have a detailed planning consent and 13% have an outline planning consent.
The remaining 21% currently do not benefit from a planning consent. Of our estimated completions for the
financial year ending October 31, 2021, 100% have planning permission in place.

**_Relationships with Homes England, Local Authorities, other Public and Private Land Owners and Registered_**
**_Providers_**

Due to our partnership model, our success depends substantially on our reputation and ability to maintain
strong relationships with public and private land owners as well as Registered Providers. In particular, we benefit
from strong, long-standing relationships with both public bodies (including Homes England, Local Authorities
and charitable organizations, and Registered Providers) and private land owners, and 79% of the plots in our land
pipeline as of July 31, 2021 were being developed under the partnership model. These relationships are built
through a successful track-record of delivering projects, a reputation for aligning our approach with our partners’
objectives and a deep understanding of the motivations beyond financial returns that are key to these partners,
including social value, sustainability, accelerated delivery and design quality. Working with public sector partners
also provides us with the potential to access grant funding and investment support (particularly from Homes
England and Local Authority partners) to facilitate the development of land that would otherwise be unviable to
develop.

Partnership projects are typically awarded by public bodies through competitive public procurement
processes, often based on the Local Authority’s or housing association’s perception of a developer’s expertise,
track record and experience with regeneration projects, design quality, reputation, price and value. Our largest
delivery partner is Homes England, we have been a member of all successive DPPs to date (DPP 1, 2 and 3) and
we are one of the most active developers on DPP3. As of July 31, 2021, approximately 19% of our land pipeline
was secured through the Homes England DPP process. In each of these public procurement processes, we tailor
our bids in accordance with the bidding criteria released by the authority, and we believe that we enjoy a significant
advantage against many competing bidders by virtue of our deep understanding of the public procurement process,
combined with our experience and track record of delivering notable regeneration and development projects
aligning with the social goals of public sector partners.

Our partnership model and our focus on working with partners in the affordable end of the housing
market allow us to achieve capital light land sourcing and site development, with typically lower land prices and
favorable (often deferred) payment terms, as well as the ability to access grant funding.

We also experience a number of benefits from our work with Registered Providers, including (i) the use
of multi-tenure housing (such as share ownership homes), which provide a natural complement to our open market
sales; (ii) resilience through the economic cycle as Registered Providers are well funded by the UK Government;
(iii) a capital efficient workstream, with Registered Providers often paying incrementally, but in advance for
homes as they are built, often with a significant upfront deposit which thereby strengthens our project ROCE; (iv)
the potential for additional elective sales during the development of a site on attractive financial terms which
provide additional revenue visibility; and (v) strong appetite for homes from Registered Providers who then in


-----

turn generate strong commercial offers typically close to full open market value (outside of the sales pursuant to
Section 106 obligations, which are often at a significant discount to open market value).

As a result of our use of the partnership model, our relationships with Homes England, other public and
private land owners and Registered Providers have a significant impact on the development opportunities available
to us and, therefore, the number of homes that we sell and our revenues from period to period. As a result, our
reputation and relationships with Homes England and key Local Authorities are critical to our success.

**_The Availability and Affordability of UK Residential Mortgages_**

Home purchases in the UK are often facilitated through mortgage lending, and 89% and 91% of our
homes that were sold through private sales were purchased by customers with the assistance of mortgages in the
financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively. A large proportion of buyers of our homes are
first-time buyers, who are especially dependent upon the availability of mortgages. As a result, the UK mortgage
market and the availability of financing options directly impact our customers’ ability to secure long-term
financing to purchase our homes. Our revenue is therefore directly influenced by the willingness of banks to lend
to customers at affordable rates and any change in available mortgage products can have a significant impact on
our revenue. Reduced availability of affordable mortgage financing and factors that increase the upfront or
monthly cost of financing the purchase of a home, including increases in interest rates, insurance premiums or
taxes or other charges associated with the purchase or ownership of a home, all impact the affordability of, and
therefore the level of demand for, the homes that we build.

The general UK economy significantly influences interest rates and, subsequently, mortgage rates. The
continuing availability of a wide range of mortgage financing options and low interest rates has in recent years
ensured that funding remains affordable in the markets where we are focused. During the period under review,
the Bank of England base rate has ranged from 0.75% to 0.1%. However, increases in the base rate have previously
had a negative impact on the UK property market because interest rates charged on mortgages increased
correspondingly, thereby making home purchases less affordable for prospective buyers. Prospective buyers who
can obtain a mortgage at current interest rates may be deterred by the possibility of increased rates (and, in turn,
higher monthly interest payments) in the future and instead elect to remain in their current property or to continue
renting. Higher mortgage interest rates would likely have an adverse impact on our transaction volumes and the
revenue derived from them.

Against the backdrop of the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK Finance estimated that UK gross mortgage
lending would fall by an estimated 13% in 2020, to £233 billion, and that it would fall to £215 billion in 2021
before recovering to £230 billion by 2022. However, recent mortgage approval data suggests that mortgage
lending in 2021 could be stronger than those estimates indicate, as approvals in the seven months ended July 31,
2021 averaged 84,735 (78% ahead of the comparative period a year prior, which was undisturbed by the COVID19 pandemic).

In terms of affordability, Nationwide estimate that first-time buyers in the UK spent an average of 31.7%
of mean take-home pay on mortgage payments in the fourth quarter of 2020. This compares to the average since
1983 of 33.1%, a low of 17.5% in 1996 and a high of 55.8% in the fourth quarter of 1989. This demonstrates that
while first-time buyer house price-to-earnings multiples are close to an all-time high (5.2x at the end of 2020)
mortgage rates are low in a historic context, reflecting low base rates. The price-to-earnings multiple is also highly
dependent upon region, with average multiples of 5.2x for the North East and 5.7x for the North West, compared
to 12.4x for London and the surrounding areas. Lower price-to-earnings multiples indicate greater affordability,
and our business is focused principally upon the more affordable regions which are characterized by lower priceto-earnings ratios. We believe that our business is less sensitive to these spreads given our relatively low ASP
and, currently, the support of the HTB scheme for first-time buyers, with rates on offer under the scheme trending
at approximately 1.7% for three- and five-year fixed rate periods in 2021. However, the HTB scheme is currently
scheduled to expire in 2023 and it remains unclear whether the scheme will be extended (and, if it is extended,
whether it will be modified) and what impact an expiry or modification would have on the affordability of
mortgages for the first-time buyer market.

The housebuilding sector and lenders are currently exploring new low-deposit mortgage products to
provide additional alternatives for buyers, including a product backed by a mortgage indemnity scheme developed
by the Home Builders Federation and other market participants that will offer 95% LTV mortgages for new homes.
Upon completion of home purchases offered as part of the scheme, the developer pays a percentage of the purchase
price into an insurance policy, which reduces risk for the lender. This scheme is currently being piloted in the


-----

North East of the UK but is expected to be rolled out more widely across the UK in 2021 should the trial prove to
be successful.

Any changes in the availability of mortgage financing, interest rates or lending guidelines or other factors
that increase the upfront or monthly cost of financing a home could impact both the demand for our homes and
their pricing, which will, in turn, affect our revenue and profitability.

**_Government Purchase Assistance Schemes_**

As a UK housebuilder with a particular focus on the affordable end of the UK housing market and firsttime buyers, our results of operations are significantly affected by the level and nature of Government purchase
assistance schemes.

Since 2016, the UK Government has focused its approach on providing additional new homes through a
number of policy statements and initiatives including an increase in its capital funding for its Affordable Homes
Programme, a £1 billion loan scheme to support SME housebuilders, confirmation of HTB funding and additional
capital for various funds, including the “Housing Infrastructure Fund,” the “Land Release Fund” and the “Planning
Delivery Fund.” In addition, the UK government is currently targeting to build 300,000 new homes a year by the
mid-2020s, a goal that has significant cross-party support. In June 2021, the UK Government launched a new
initiative called “First Homes” will extend the tenures being offered through local authorities planning policy for
affordable housing. The First Homes initiative offers first-time buyers the opportunity to buy a home at a discount
(minimum 30%) in perpetuity subject to meeting local and key work eligibility criteria.

These stimulus measures make it easier for us to sell homes and hence have an impact on our revenue
and margins. These government programs are particularly important when traditional mortgage lenders do not
have suitable products available for, or are unwilling to provide based on their lending criteria, the full loan amount
required by home buyers.

A significant number of our customers have used HTB, a UK government equity loan scheme designed
to encourage home ownership in the UK. The HTB program provides assistance to purchasers of new-build homes
in the UK by reducing the minimum down payment required from the purchaser to 5% of a property’s value and
providing an equity loan of up to 20%, or 40% in London, of the property value (originally available up to a value
of £600,000). HTB sales represented approximately 68% of our private sales in the financial year ended October
31, 2020. The HTB scheme has been modified and extended to March 2023, but with reforms restricting the
scheme to support only first-time buyers from April 1, 2021 onwards and with regional price caps ranging from
£186,100 in the North East to £600,000 in London. As a result of these reforms, non-first-time buyers who
previously would have been able to secure funding through the HTB scheme are no longer eligible to do so, which
in turn could have an adverse impact on our home sales. In addition, the HTB scheme remains subject to future
regulatory changes, including to applicable eligibility criteria, and such changes may affect the availability of
government funding of mortgages, which in turn may affect public demand in the homes market. It is not currently
known whether the HTB scheme will be extended after 2023 or, if it is extended, how it may be modified, or
whether any other similar UK Government-backed program will continue at current levels, or at all, or that lenders
will participate in them. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business— A majority of our business is secured
_or supported either directly or indirectly from various Government sources, and changes in local or Government_
_funds, loans, grants or subsidies, or changes to or the discontinuation of mortgage assistance schemes or equity_
_loan schemes (including in particular Help to Buy) could significantly impact our business.”_

Scotland has a separate program (Help to Buy (Scotland)), and its “Affordable New Build Scheme”
available to larger housebuilders (including Keepmoat) stopped accepting new applications on February 5, 2021.
However, we believe that this has not had a material effect on demand for our homes in Scotland.

The availability of funding for these programs remains subject to governmental decisions. In the future,
governments and/or local bodies may change their priorities and programs, for example, by reducing or amending
mortgage assistance schemes, or undertaking welfare reforms that may impact funding stability for housing
associations and local authorities. Any reduction or discontinuation of UK Government-backed home purchase
assistance programs in the future may make it more difficult for our core first-time buyer customers to afford
homes, which would make it more difficult for us to sell homes and may force us to either lower prices or increase
purchase incentives.


-----

**_Product Mix and ASPs_**

Our profitability is influenced by the number of legal completions we achieve and the margin we earn
on those completions. The margins we earn can vary significantly and depend on the underlying profitability of
the projects, the types of homes sold and the location of the sites. Therefore, our results can be significantly
affected by product mix and regional mix.

In terms of product mix, our results are affected in particular by the split between open market sales and
sales to Registered Providers. We pursue a strategy that blends the potential of margin enhancement through
higher-margin open-market sales with the certainty, risk mitigation and cash generation of selling to Registered
Providers for affordable rent and shared ownership housing. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, we sold
74% of our plots on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as well as elective sales to
Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a site), with 26% to Registered Providers as part
of Section 106 affordable housing obligations in connection with planning consents or otherwise agreed with
Registered Providers at the outset of development. In comparison, in the financial year ended October 31, 2019,
we sold 78% of our plots in the open market and 22% to Registered Providers. Although the sales prices of homes
sold to Registered Providers pursuant to Section 106 affordable housing obligations are typically lower than open
market sales, and involve lower margins, the sales often involve the Registered Providers forward funding these,
both providing revenue visibility and reducing the working capital needs of sites. In addition, this enables us to
use the cash proceeds from such sales to accelerate delivery of site outputs, ultimately generating an enhanced
ROCE. In addition to the sales in connection with Section 106 obligations, we are able to agree additional sales
to Registered Providers either at the outset of a development (in which case we categorize these as Registered
Provider sales, alongside the sales pursuant to Section 106 obligations) or as elective sales during the development
of a site (in which case we categorize these as open market sales). In either case, for sales outside of Section 106
obligations the Registered Providers are able to utilize Affordable Homes Programme funding, which helps to
generate attractive commercial offers. In particular, elective sales agreed during the development of a site are
benchmarked against other open market sale opportunities and are often at only a small discount to the open
market price.

Our results are also affected by the regional mix of sales among our nine regions, with some of our
regions having higher ASPs than other regions. For example, in the nine months ended July 31, 2021, our regional
ASPs ranged from £138,000 in our North West MCI region to £221,000 in our South Midlands region. Our results
may therefore vary from period to period as we expand our operations in certain regions and based on the location
of the development opportunities available to us in each period.

While our product mix and regional mix is largely within our control, we are impacted by external factors,
in particular the availability of planning consents and government policy.

In the near term, our margins are also affected by site mix, reflecting the fact that current management
has implemented an enhanced land sourcing process that we believe has resulted in a progressively increasing mix
of higher quality, better procured sites. For example, for sites under development that were approved between
2017 and 2019 (excluding the North West MCI region), average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development
Margins for each year of approval range from approximately 22% to 23% by year, whereas for sites either
approved since 2020 or within our secured pipeline and to be approved, average forecasted full-site-life Gross
Development Margins for each year of approval or for the “to be approved” category, range from approximately
24% to 25% by year or category. This is an increase from the average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development
Margins for sites under development that were approved in 2016 and pre-2016, for which average forecasted fullsite-life Gross Development Margins are approximately 21% and 18%, respectively.

**_Our Cost Base, including the Supply and Cost of Sub-contractors and Materials_**

A significant portion of our cost of sales relate to the costs of building our housing developments,
including the costs of raw materials and labor. Factors outside our control, including raw materials prices and
wage costs, can have a material impact on these costs and, accordingly, our financial results.

We sub-contract a large proportion of the actual construction of our developments to third-party
providers and therefore our ability to source sub-contractors that meet our strict quality requirements and rate/price
expectations are important to our business. We compete for labor with our competitors in the housebuilding sector
and with housebuilders in other sectors and, therefore, changes in the labor market directly impact our costs. The
concentration of our sub-contractors is low. This diversification reduces our exposure to individual subcontractor


-----

risk. In addition, in order to reduce risks of subcontractor rate increases on developments, we typically aim to lock
in subcontractor prices over a phase, or part-phase, of a development through “all risk” contracts.

We are directly exposed to the cyclicality of the construction industry, which impacts the labor market.
During periods of market contraction, pools of labor leave the market, sometimes permanently, for example to
retrain in other professions or move abroad in search of work. During periods of increased construction activity,
competition among housebuilders for qualified labor increases and the associated impact on labor rates and
availability can impact us, and result in materially higher labor costs. This has been demonstrated during the
current financial year, with high levels of construction activity in the UK housebuilding sector giving rise to
increasing competition for skilled labor and a consequential increase in labor costs.

We are also affected by our ability to source sufficient materials at competitive prices. The cyclicality of
the construction industry also impacts the supply of materials so that in times of market contraction, production
is scaled back and therefore when markets recover there can be a lag on supply which pushes prices upwards.
More generally, periods of increased construction activity can give rise to demand and supply imbalances which
tend to increase construction costs. For example, a significant increase in UK housebuilding activity during the
current financial year has resulted in a significant increase in demand for construction materials and a lengthening
of supplier delivery times. Data released by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy indicated
that the overall cost of materials for new housing was 6.7% higher in January 2021 than in January 2020. An IHS
Markit/Cips UK survey published in May 2021 indicated that input-cost inflation had increased for the seventh
month in a row to its highest level since the survey began in April 1997, with steel and timber experiencing
particularly sharp price rises.

We seek to mitigate any supply shortages and cost inflation risk by having strong supplier relationships
that can meet our demands. Our material supply-chain strategy is underpinned by annual, Group-wide deals with
suppliers with national coverage. This enables us to negotiate better commercial terms through consolidated
volume and enables the utilization of volume-related rebates. We operate a series of group-wide, long-term
strategic frameworks providing preferential commercial terms and service levels nationally and regionally for
supply of materials, site equipment and business consumables. Our supply chain team manage over 96
arrangements which are made up of framework agreements, commercial arrangements and formal price lists. In
the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 88% of our direct spend was channeled through these frameworks.

Our use of standardized designs helps to reduce and improve the predictability of costs, improves
construction build times and quality and continues to provide us with the flexibility to utilize our skills and
experience in design and place-making by tailoring aspects of our standardized designs to each particular
development. Although the amount of homes built using our standardized type varies from year to year, in the
financial year ended October 31, 2020, 88% of our homes were build using a standardized house type. We believe
that our shift to increased construction standardization can help reduce costs and build times while continuing to
allow us to utilize our skills and experience in design and place-making.

We also seek to mitigate the risk of price rises through the use of phased viability in developments where
possible, allowing increased build costs to be included in future phases following updated viability assessments,
facilitating the delivery of our required financial returns if the cost base increases on subsequent phases. This
mechanism mitigates the impact of cost increases on future phases, but does not affect cost increases during the
construction of a particular phase.

Our supply chain and costs could also be affected by political events, such as the ongoing effects of
Brexit. We have worked closely with our supply chain since the Brexit vote to ensure that we understand the
changes arising from Brexit. We have continued with this close engagement since the confirmation of the new
trade arrangements to understand their challenges and contingency strategies. These include careful monitoring,
increasing UK stock holding and diverting imports to alternative UK ports where bottlenecks are predicted. At
this stage, we have not experienced any significant supply chain issues associated with Brexit.

Central overhead costs (including central administrative personnel as well as non-personnel overhead
costs for central office rental and rates as well as IT costs, insurance, audit, legal, tax and other consultancy
services and other expenses) represented 3% and 4% of our revenue in the years ended October 31, 2019 and
2020, respectively, while regional overhead costs (including regional administrative personnel as well as nonpersonnel overhead costs for regional office rental and rates and other expenses) represented 6% and 8% of our
revenue.


-----

Our overhead has risen in recent years as a result of our expansion into new regions. However, as our
operations in these regions mature, we expect to capture greater operational efficiencies and reduce overhead costs
as a percentage of revenue, enhancing our profit margins. We expect this decrease in overhead costs as a
percentage of revenue will be driven principally by efficiencies of scale in growth regions and central overheads.

We have also made significant investments in personnel at both the regional and head office level to
support our growth and build a national platform for future expansion in our target geographies. Margins have
remained stable over this period and we have proven our ability to invest and grow scale.

**_Seasonality_**

Historically, our revenues and levels of working capital have varied during the year due to peaks of
completions in certain months of the year. As a consequence, our debt profile has exhibited peaks and troughs
over the course of the financial year consistent with seasonal trends.

The timing of completions within a financial year is influenced by a number of factors. Typically, the
majority of our reservations for open market sales are made in January to March and August to October (with the
latter correlated to the start of the new school year). Our ability to manage the timeline from the engagement and
planning phase to the exchange of contract and legal completion is, therefore, one of the factors that affects the
timing of completions. Although we generally have a significant degree of flexibility in managing the phasing of
completions and typically aim to stagger the timing of our completions to the extent practicable, the impact of
weather on building activity and plot delivery has also tended to favor a peak in completions in the late summer
and early autumn.

In addition, prior to the change of the KM Group’s financial year end from March 31 to October 31 in
2018, divisional efforts to achieve targets and maximize sales for the financial year end led to a peak of
completions in March. This had an effect on our results of operations for the financial year ended October 31,
2019, as our incentive scheme for that financial year remained tied to an end date of March 31. However, we do
not expect this to have an impact on our financial results in any subsequent years. For the financial year ended
October 31, 2021 we have amended our incentive targets to include an additional measure tied to half-year targets,
in order to achieve a more levelled number of completions throughout the financial year.

The above factors may lead to volatility in our quarterly financial results. These factors that affect the
phasing of completions through a financial year tend to result in a weighting of plot completions, and accordingly
revenue and profit, to the last quarter of financial years. Results of a single fiscal quarter or half year might
therefore not be a reliable basis for the expectations of a full financial year and may not be comparable with the
results in the other fiscal quarters or half year. Factors that affect our peak selling seasons can have a
disproportionate impact on our performance in a particular period.
