**_Changes to Accounting Principles_**

_IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers)_

IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) was issued in 2014 and was endorsed by the EU in
2016. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) establishes a comprehensive framework for determining
whether, how much and when revenue is recognized. It replaces existing revenue recognition guidance, including
IAS 18 (Revenue). IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) is effective for annual periods beginning
on or after January 1, 2018, with early adoption permitted.

We adopted IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) from April 1, 2018 in accordance with
the fully retrospective transitional approach without using the practical expedients for completed contracts or for
modified contracts. We have applied the expedient allowing both non-disclosure of the amount of the transaction
price allocated to the remaining performance obligations, and an explanation of when it expects to recognize that
amount as revenue for all reporting periods presented before the date of initial application.

Under IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers), revenue is recognized based on indicators of
control, rather than solely when risks and rewards are transferred. This can lead to differences in revenue
recognition on certain sites, based on the specific contractual arrangements in place. The majority of our revenue
and profit, including revenue from open market sales, continues to be recognized on legal completion. For those
sites in respect of which stage payments are received from Registered Providers, revenue is recognized based on
stage of completion rather than on legal completion.

IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) also sets out the requirements for recognition of noncash consideration as revenue. Previously, where we entered into arrangements to provide housing to Registered
Providers at below open market value in exchange for discounted land from partners, the associated housing unit
revenue was recorded at open market value. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) does not permit
this, as the exchange transaction (land discount from partner) is not received directly from the customer (the
Registered Provider) and so does not meet the criteria of non-cash consideration. This change has the impact of
reducing reported revenue. Accordingly, the revenue recognized in respect of these housing units will be equal to
the cash consideration received from Registered Providers, with no open market value adjustment. There are a
limited number of developments where the eventual buyer of the affordable units is the same entity as the land
vendor. In these instances, the discount received represents non-cash consideration, which continues to be
recognized as revenue.

_IFRS 16 (Leases)_

On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16
(Leases) on November 9, 2017. IFRS 16 (Leases) replaced IAS 17 (Leases) and the related International Financial
Reporting Interpretations Committee’s and the Standards Interpretation Committee’s interpretations, and results
in almost all leases being recognized on the balance sheet, as the distinction between operating and finance leases
is eliminated. Under the new standard, the lessee recognizes an asset (the right to use the leased asset) and a
financial liability to pay lease payments. The only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases. IFRS 16
(Leases) is effective for fiscal years commencing on or after January 1, 2019, with early adoption permitted if
IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) has also been applied.

We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) from November 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective approach. Under
this approach, comparative information is not restated and the cumulative effect of initially applying IFRS 16
(Leases) is recognized in retained earnings at the date of initial application. In particular, as a consequence of
IFRS 16 (Leases) our total assets and liabilities increased as the right of use asset associated with leases and the
corresponding liability, which were previously treated as operating leases, are recognized on the balance sheet. In
addition, operating lease expenditure has been reclassified and split between depreciation and finance cost, and as
a result, our EBITDA increased.

IFRS 16 (Leases) was effective for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. The impact of adopting
IFRS 16 (Leases) for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was the recognition of right of use assets of £8.0
million and lease liabilities of £8.6 million on transition in respect of offices, company vehicles, site plant
equipment and show homes. The impact on Adjusted EBITDA for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was


-----

£0.6 million. This information may not be indicative of the impact of the adoption of IFRS 16 (Leases) on our
total assets, total liabilities and EBITDA for the next financial year or any future period.

**_Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic_**

Our financial performance during the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was affected significantly
by the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result of program disruption and the costs of operating with COVID-19 working
practices and social-distancing measures, our delivery volumes declined significantly given construction activity
was significantly stalled from April through August 2020, our margins declined slightly compared to the financial
year ended October 31, 2019 and our EBIT and ROCE performance eroded significantly.

However, as demonstrated by our performance for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 and our forward
order book, we have recovered strongly from the COVID-19 pandemic and we believe that we are well positioned
to deliver on our planned growth in the medium term. We have benefitted from a robust UK housing market, with
a favorable mortgage environment, ongoing government support and strong demand, against the resilient
economic backdrop during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Despite the strict lockdown measures that were imposed through April 2021, for the twelve months ended
July 31, 2021, our Adjusted EBIT and ROCE increased 12.8% and 150 basis points, respectively, as compared to
the financial year ended October 31, 2019.

We believe our financial results in recent quarters demonstrates the resiliency and strength of our
business model. The COVID-19 lockdown restrictions imposed in March 2020 caused our financial performance
to decline but did not stress our overall financial profile given the lower risk inherent in our partnership model. In
addition, during the financial year ended October 31, 2020, £24.4 million in partner payments were deferred,
representing approximately 80% of our total commitments, which illustrates the flexible land creditor profile we
maintain.

**Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items**

**_Revenue_**

Revenue is recognized based on indicators of control, rather than solely when risks and rewards are
transferred. This can lead to differences in revenue recognition on certain sites, based on the specific contractual
arrangements in place.

The majority of our revenue and profit, including revenue from open market sales, is recognized at legal
completion. For those sites in respect of which stage payments are received from Registered Providers (which are
government approved organizations that provides Affordable Housing, including Housing Associations, Local
Authorities and private companies) for the provision of housing or where we undertake development contracts,
revenue is recognized based on stage of completion rather than on legal completion. We consider the provision of
land and residential properties to represent a single performance obligation which represents a judgement taken
in the application of IFRS 15.

_Sale of Housing to Open Market Customers_

Revenue and profits associated with these activities are recognized in the statement of comprehensive
income on legal completion. Revenue in respect of the sale of residential properties is recognized at the fair value
of the consideration received or receivable upon legal completion. Open market sale plots are recognized at the
agreed sales price which is deemed to be fair value.

_Sale of Housing to Registered Provider Customers and Associated Development Contracts (with Stage Payments)_

We construct and sell residential properties and undertake associated development activities under longterm contracts with customers. Such contracts are entered into before construction of residential properties or
associated development activities begin. Under the terms of the contracts, we are restricted from redirecting the
properties or development works to another customer and have an enforceable right to payment for work done.
Revenue from construction of residential properties and associated development activities is therefore recognized
over time based on a certified monthly valuation of work performed or the assessed physical stage of completion
at the balance sheet date. We consider that this method is an appropriate measure of the progress towards complete
satisfaction of these performance obligations under IFRS 15.


-----

_Sale of Housing to Registered Provider Customers (without Stage Payments)_

Revenue and profits associated with these activities are included in the statement of comprehensive
income on legal completion, at which point control is passed from us to the purchaser.

**_Cost of Sales_**

Cost of sales consists of:

      - costs associated with the investment in land (land purchase costs) which are recognized as WIP
(included as inventories in our financial statements) as they are incurred and allocated to plot
sales based on remaining plots to be sold at each site;

      - architectural and engineering fees associated with the design of each site;

      - build costs, including direct labor, sub-contractors and materials, which are also recognized as
WIP (included as inventories in our financial statements) as they are incurred and allocated to
plot sales based on remaining plots to be sold at each site; and

      - sales and marketing costs related to the sales of our homes.

**_Administrative Expenses_**

Our administrative expenses include both cash and non-cash items and are made up of personnel costs
(including wages, salaries, bonuses and national insurance costs) and non-personnel overhead costs for office
rentals and rates as well as IT costs and other expenses.

**_Other Operating Income_**

Other operating income includes part exchange property sales.

**_Other Operating Expenses_**

Other operating expenses include associated expenses with part exchange property sales.

**_Share of Results of Equity Accounted JVs and Associates_**

Joint ventures and associates are accounted for using the equity method. The share of results of equity
accounted JVs and associates represents our share of the entities’ profits or losses for the period. Where the share
of losses exceeds our equity accounted investment in a joint venture, the carrying value of the equity interest is
reduced to nil and the recognition of further losses is discontinued.

**_Adjusted Operating Profit/(Loss)_**

Adjusted operating profit represents gross profit for the applicable period less administrative expenses
plus other operating income for such period plus the share of results of equity accounted as part of our joint
ventures and associates and excludes exceptional items and amortization of acquisition related intangibles.

**_Exceptional Items_**

Exceptional items are material items of income or expense that have been shown separately in our income
statement due to the significance of their nature or amount.

Exceptional items for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 amounted to an expense of £38.5 million and
related to a share-based payment charge of £19.5 million and advisory fees incurred in relation to the sale of the
Group of £19.0 million.

Exceptional items for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 amounted to an expense of £1.8 million
and related to £1.3 million in respect of a restructuring exercise and £0.5 million in respect of professional advisor
costs relating to refinancing and corporate finance matters.

Exceptional items for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 amounted to income of £1.3 million and
related to the release of an onerous lease provision.


-----

**_Amortisation of Acquisition Related Intangible Assets_**

Amortisation of acquisition related intangible assets represents amortization of goodwill arising on
acquisition of subsidiary entities.

**_Operating Profit_**

Operating profit represents adjusted operating profit for the applicable period after giving effect to any
exceptional items and amortization of acquisition related intangibles during the applicable period.

**_Finance Income_**

Finance income is recognized in the income statement in the year or period to which it relates using the
effective interest rate method. Finance income comprises interest receivable on loans to joint venture partners;
and other interest receivable.

**_Finance Expense_**

Finance expense is recognized in the income statement in the year or period in which it occurs. Finance
expense comprises: (i) interest payable on term loans and debt securities; (ii) the unwinding of discounts on
deferred land payments; (iii) interest payable on bank loans and overdrafts; (iv) finance charges on senior secured
notes; (v) interest payable on subordinated shareholder loan notes; (vi) interest payable on other loans; and (vii)
interest payable on leases.

**_Income Tax Credit/(Charge)_**

Income tax credit / (charge) includes all current and deferred taxes, as calculated in accordance with the
relevant tax laws in force. Income tax is recognized in the income statement except to the extent that it relates to
items recognized directly in equity.

**_Capital Resources_**

**_Working Capital_**

We define changes in working capital as the sum of changes in accrued/deferred income, changes in
receivables, changes in subcontractor and supplier payables and other creditors, accruals, provisions, debtors and
prepayments, and changes in land and build WIP resulting from the cash flows statement. Our working capital
requirements are driven by timing of land payments, plot completions, build WIP and supplier and subcontractor
terms. Accrued and deferred income consists of stage payments from Registered Providers, Local Authorities and
other housing associations. Payables mainly include invoices from sub-contractors and suppliers. Our contract
provisions typically provide for accruals for subcontractor work completed and materials supplied that have not
been invoiced.

The amount of working capital required to service our operations is closely monitored and controlled and
forms a key part of the management information reviewed on a daily, weekly and monthly basis. Current assets
mainly comprise trade receivables, WIP and land held for the development of private housing and affordable
housing through partnership schemes. As our trade receivables relate mainly to public sector and housing
association clients, there is no significant history of bad or doubtful debts.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk**

Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices such as interest rates, house prices and foreign
exchange rates will affect our income or the value of our financial instruments.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that we will not be able to meet our financial obligations as and when they fall
due. Our objective is to manage liquidity by ensuring that we will always have sufficient liquidity to meet our


-----

liabilities as they become due. This is assessed under normal and stress conditions, without incurring losses or
risking damage to our reputation.

In connection with the Transactions, we will establish the Revolving Credit Facility in the amount of £70
million.

We believe we have a rigorous cash management processes. Cash balances are reported daily with
detailed analysis of variances to short term cash forecasts. Short term cash forecasts are updated monthly and for
a period of 26 weeks, with the first eight weeks on a daily basis and the remaining 18 weeks on a weekly basis.
These complement our minimum of four long term quarterly cash forecasts each year which are compared to the
annual cash flow budget and to previous quarterly forecasts. These facilitate management’s assessments of our
expected cash performance and to compare to the facilities available and our covenants.

Key risks to liquidity and cash balances are a decrease in the value of open market sales, a downturn in
the UK housing market, deterioration in credit terms obtainable in the market from suppliers and subcontractors,
a downturn in the profitability of work, delayed receipt of cash from customers and a general decline in the ability
of local authorities to fund urban regeneration projects.

In order to mitigate this risk we continually monitor open market house sales volumes and prices;
continuous monitoring of working capital levels and contract profitability and the review of client and supplier
credit references and credit terms with clients and suppliers to ensure they continue to be appropriate.

We do not have any derivative financial liabilities.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Interest rate risk relates to the impact of interest rate increases on our floating rate borrowing. We hold
facilities at floating interest rates at a margin over LIBOR. Our floating rate financing has increased our liquidity
but has also increased our exposure to interest rate fluctuations. While the risk of increased interest rates are
beyond our control, we continually keep our exposure under review.

**_Housing Market Risk_**

We are affected by price fluctuations of the UK housing market. The market is impacted by consumer
demand and employment levels and is dependent on the availability of mortgage finance. Furthermore,
Government incentives, including the Help to Buy scheme, have helped to stimulate consumer demand. While
these risks are beyond our ultimate control, we have mitigated certain elements of this risk by diversifying across
differing business activities and geographical regions.

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk relates to our risk of financial loss if a customer fails to meet their contractual obligations.
The risk mainly arises on our trade receivables and amounts due from construction contract customers.

IFRS 9 requires an expected credit loss model, rather than an incurred credit loss model to be applied.
This requires the assessment of the expected credit loss on each class of financial asset at each reporting date. This
assessment takes into consideration changes in credit risk since initial recognition of the financial asset.

Our exposure to credit risk is limited for open market housebuilding activities as we typically receive
cash at the point of legal completion of our sales.

The credit risk on Registered Provider sales depends on the individual characteristics of the counterparty,
many of whom are in the public sector or are funded by the public sector (e.g., housing associations). We believe
the credit rating of these customers to be good and the credit risk on outstanding balances to be low. A highly
immaterial provision is present in all periods.

We do not have any concentration of risk in respect of amounts due from construction contract
receivables or trade receivable balances, with receivables spread across a wide range of customers.

We apply the simplified approach under IFRS 9 to measure expected credit losses associated with trade
and other receivables. The carrying value of receivables is reduced at each reporting date for any increase in the
lifetime expected credit losses with an impairment loss recognized in the statement of comprehensive income. We


-----

are of the opinion that there is a significant concentration of credit risk for those balances past due greater than
one year. As of July 31, 2021, trade receivables with a carrying amount of £2.7 million are past due (October 31,
2020: £1.8 million; October 31, 2019: £10.5 million) and £0.2 million are impaired (October 31, 2020: £0.2
million; October 31, 2019: £0.8 million).

**_Foreign Exchange Risk_**

We do not hedge against foreign currency exposure due to our minimal exposure to foreign currency
movements, as our business is conducted entirely in the UK and primarily in pound sterling.

**Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates**

The preparation of historical financial information under IFRS requires that our management make
judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of policies and reported amounts of assets and
liabilities, income and expenses. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and
various other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the
basis of making judgements about the carrying value of assets and liabilities which are not readily apparent from
other sources. Actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates and underlying assumptions are
reviewed on an ongoing basis and any revisions to them are recognized in the period in which they are revised.

The estimates and judgements that have a risk of causing a material adjustment to the carrying amounts
of assets and liabilities within the next financial year are addressed below.

**_Estimation of Development Profitability_**

The gross profit from revenue generated on each of our developments in a specific period is based on
our latest forecast for the gross profit expected to be generated over the life of that development or phase. The
expected gross profit is calculated as an output of development valuations completed using the latest selling prices
and forecasts of all land and construction costs associated with the development. These calculations of expected
gross profit require a degree of estimation due to their long-term nature and are sensitive to future movements in
both the estimated cost to complete and expected selling prices.

Our management has established internal controls to regularly review and ensure the appropriateness of
the forecasts and estimates made on an individual development basis. However, a change in estimated gross profits
over a number of developments (due, for example, to changes in estimates of costs remaining or a reduction in
average selling prices in the private market) could materially affect profitability. As an illustration, a reasonably
possible change in profits of 1% across all developments in the period to July 31, 2021 would have reduced gross
profit and net assets by an estimated £4.8 million (October 31, 2020: £4.1 million; October 31, 2019: £6.5 million).

**_Judgement Over the Right to Develop Land Under a Build Lease_**

We enter into arrangements with land owners under which we acquire an interest in land under a build
lease with the benefit of a right to develop. The directors judge these arrangements as in-substance purchases and
not leases under the scope of IFRS 16. This is on the basis that: (i) we have physical possession of the land and
have accepted the asset; (ii) the land owner has an enforceable right to payment; (iii) the freehold is passed to the
end customer; and (iv) we take on any risks associated with the land and ultimately benefit from the reward on
sale of the developed plots. On this basis, land rights acquired under these arrangements are treated as inventories
and are held at the lower of cost or net realizable value as per our accounting policy for inventories.

**_Fair Value on Share-based Payments_**

Assumptions are made in determining the fair value of employee services received in exchange for the
award of units under share-based payments awards at the date of grant, and of the likely outcome of non-market
conditions.

**INDUSTRY OVERVIEW**

**History and Overview of United Kingdom Housing Market**

Housing output in the United Kingdom has ranged between approximately 130,000 and 250,000
completions per annum since 1980, a level much lower than in the 1960s and 1970s when direct local authority
build programs pushed housing completions toward 400,000 per annum. Against this backdrop, private sector
housing completions have trended between 150,000 and 210,000 per annum since the 1960s – except for the
periods immediately following the 1970s’ recession and the global financial crisis that started in 2008 (the “GFC”)
when completions fell below this level. This is in contrast to many European countries where housebuilding rates
per person have exceeded that of the UK.

In 2004, the Government commissioned the Barker Report to conduct a review of the underlying supply
issues and responsiveness of housing in the UK, with due consideration given to the role of competition, capacity,
technology, and finances of the housebuilding industry. In addition, the report sought to explore the interplay
between these factors and the wider UK planning system in order to distinguish where shortfalls were presenting
themselves. More specifically, the review stated its key objectives as achieving: (1) improvements in housing
affordability in the market sector; (2) a more stable housing market; (3) a location of housing supply which
supports patterns of economic data; and (4) an adequate supply of publicly-funded housing for those who need it.
As the report highlighted, the aforementioned level of housebuilding fell short of the growth in household
formations and resulted in the recommendation that the UK should be building 240,000 houses per annum to
reduce the growth in house prices to zero real growth. The report also highlighted the greatest shortfall of housing
provision was within the affordable housing marketplace and recommended that greater Government subsidy in
this area was required.

While UK housebuilding rates improved post the Barker Report to 223,590 homes in 2007, the impact
of the GFC resulted in housing completions falling to a record low of 135,980 in 2010. This was compounded by
the stress in the banking sector and led to mortgage approvals for house purchases falling to approximately 26,000
in November 2008, compared to pre-GFC mortgage volumes which did not fall below 100,000 per month.

These trends in housing completions have been against the backdrop of a growing housing shortage, as
demonstrated by the following graph displaying the cumulative housing shortage in England between 2007 and
2020:

This backdrop has led to the Government taking a more active role in the UK housing market, to promote
home ownership and higher levels of housing completions. Arguably the most effective program has been the
Help to Buy equity loan scheme, which was announced in April 2013 and provides buyers who contribute deposits
of at least 5% with an interest free equity loan of up to 20% (London 40%) to help support the purchase of a new
build home. The scheme was originally intended to run until 2017, but it has been extended several times and is
now scheduled to run until March 2023 (with certain variations, including that it is available only to first-time
buyers from April 1, 2021).

The improved macroeconomic backdrop from 2013, alongside Government support, enabled
housebuilding completions to rise to 214,190 in the year to December 31, 2019, the highest level since 2007.


-----

172,010 of these were built by the private sector, 38,390 by housing associations and only 3,800 by local
authorities (compared to 415,460 total completions in 1967, 204,210 of which were built by the private sector).
This level of build still fell well short of the Government’s target to build 300,000 homes per year by the mid2020s (as announced in the Autumn Budget 2017).

The following chart shows the level of public sector and private sector new housing completions from
1969 to 2020, as compared against the Government’s current target of 300,000 homes per year:

In keeping with other industries, the COVID-19 pandemic has presented major challenges for the UK
housing market and the construction of new homes. While data for the UK is not yet available, the Ministry of
Housing, Communities and Local Government (“MHCLG”) estimates that completions and starts of new homes
in England fell 17% and 16% in the year to December 31, 2020, respectively. This reflected the substantial closure
of the UK housing market between March and May 2020 (alongside the national lockdown) and the practical
effects social distancing had upon the rate of build.

Since restrictions were eased following the first national lockdown in May 2020, housing market activity
has been strong. Total housing completions in 2020 for England totaled 148,630, a decrease of 17% compared to
the year ending December 31, 2019, despite the widespread disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic early
in the year. Nationwide and Halifax reported house price increases of 7.3% and 6.0%, respectively, in the year
ending December 31, 2020 – the strongest annual growth since 2016, demonstrating a continued momentum in
UK house prices. The following chart shows the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on the nationwide house price
growth, as well as on the amount of newly agreed sales and completed transactions for the periods indicated:

The following graph shows UK nominal and real house price growth from 2000 to the first quarter of
2021, according to Nationwide. Nominal house prices include all UK properties, without taking into account


-----

seasonal adjustments. Real house price are adjusted for retail prices, using the Office for National Statistics Retail
Price Index (“RPI”) to convert nominal prices to current prices.

__________________

Source: Savills Residential Property Forecast, March 2021

Mortgage lending has also been resurgent with an average of 95,341 monthly mortgage approvals for
house purchases in the seven months up to and including February 2021, the strongest level since 2007. More
recent indicators suggest this momentum has continued, with the number of UK residential purchases in March
2021 being 102.3% higher than March 2020 and 32.2% higher than February 2021. Rightmove announced that it
had recorded its busiest ever day on April 7, 2021, with 9.3 million visits to its website, and attributed this strength
to growing optimism in the UK’s economic outlook (in light of the positive vaccine roll-out), the return of low
deposit mortgages and the benefit of the stamp duty holiday extension to the end of September 2021. The extension
will see no tax levied on the first £500,000 of property purchases until June 20, 2021, with this nil-rate band
reducing to £250,000 until September 30, 2021, after which it will revert to £125,000.

The provision of affordable housing remains a priority for the Government, with a pledge to invest
approximately £12 billion in the construction of affordable homes (as defined by the NPPF as housing for sale or
rent for those whose needs are not met by the market) in England between 2021 and 2026 – the largest investment
into affordable housing in over a decade. The 2021-2026 program is expected to support the construction of
180,000 homes over five years from 2021 to 2026 and is expected to unlock an additional £38 billion of
public/private investment in affordable housing.

**Housing Demand and Supply Dynamics**

We believe the following key factors drive the demand for housing in the UK:

**_Macroeconomic Environment_**

Historically, the strength of the UK housing market and of the housebuilding sector has been linked to
that of the UK economy as a whole, which in turn is influenced by both European and global macro-economic
conditions. Demand for housing is driven by a combination of factors, such as the rate of economic growth (both
nationally and regionally), the rate of population growth and the increasing number of first-time buyers, the
average age and life expectancy of the population, the rate of household formation, the availability and
affordability of mortgages, consumer confidence (discussed further below) and the unemployment rate. In
addition, the outlook in prices remain strong across different region, representing an increasing opportunity for
Keepmoat.

Due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, global GDP is estimated to have fallen 3.5%, with UK
GDP declining 9.9%. While current data remains volatile due to the phasing of Government restrictions (UK GDP
rose 1.2% in December 2020, fell 2.2% in January 2021, and rose 0.4% in February 2021), the UK economy
appears to be recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic, in part due to a successful vaccine roll-out. Recent
forecasts from the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) estimate GDP growth at 4.0% in 2021 and envisage
that the economy will return to its pre-pandemic levels by Q2 2022. Elsewhere, the labor market continues to be
distorted by the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (“CJRS”) (with an estimated 4.7 million workers furloughed
at the end of February 2021 versus 8.9 million in May 2020), with the ONS estimating the employment rate at
75.1% in February 2021 (1.4% down year-on-year) and the unemployment rate at 4.9% (0.9% higher year-onyear). Despite this, the OBR estimates that the unemployment rate will peak at 6.5% in Q4 2021 as furlough winds
down and improve thereafter. Notably, for the period from January 2021 to March 2021, London had the highest
level of unemployment at 6.8%, compared to 5.4% in the North East, 5.0% in the North West, 5.7% and 4.9% for
the West and East Midland regions respectively, and a low of 3.4% in the South-East.

There have also been early signs of recovery in wage growth since the end of lockdown. In contrast to
past periods of economic stress, the housing market has seen renewed momentum since May 2020, with many
commentators attributing this to the release of pent-up demand and changing household preferences instigated by
the COVID-19 pandemic.

**_Consumer Confidence_**

Consumer confidence is an economic indicator that measures the degree of optimism that consumers
have regarding the overall state of the economy and their own financial situations, and provides an indication of
future developments of households’ consumption and savings. Generally, when consumer confidence is high, this
will have a positive effect on demand for housing. The Bank of England is predicting increased consumer
confidence with the easing of restrictions on economic activity and households expected to spend around 10% of
their additional accumulated savings over the next three years. The GFK Consumer Confidence Index rose to a
13-month high in April 2021, its highest level since the start of the pandemic. Consumer confidence was -8 in
August 2021 (-7 in July 2021), which compares to a lockdown low of -34 in April 2020.

**_Mortgage Availability_**

Demand for housing is also affected by the ability of prospective buyers to secure financing to buy a
home, which is in turn affected by banks’ and other lenders’ willingness and ability to provide mortgages to
prospective buyers. UK Finance, a trade association for the UK banking and financial services sector, estimates
that UK gross mortgage lending to £233 billion in 2020, representing a 13% decline from the prior year, and
forecasts that it will fall to £215 billion in 2021 before recovering to £230 billion by 2022. However, recent
mortgage approval data points to a stronger situation, with approvals in the seven months up to and including
February 2021 averaging 95,053. This is 41% ahead of the comparative period a year earlier, which was
undisturbed by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Bank of England’s Q2 2021 Credit Conditions Survey showed that
lenders expected the availability of credit to improve further in the three months ended August 31, 2021, as well
as expecting demand to improve and for mortgage spreads to narrow further.

**_Mortgage Affordability_**

Demand for homes is affected not only by the availability of mortgages, but by the affordability of the
mortgage products that are available, relative to earnings. Nationwide estimates that first-time buyers spent an
average of 31.7% of mean take-home pay on mortgage payments in Q4 2020. This compares to the average since
1984 of 33.1%, a low of 17.5% in 1996 and a high of 56% in 1989, as demonstrated by the following graph
showing UK mortgage rates between 1995 and 2021:

Notably, the key geographical drivers behind the rise in the UK house price-to-earnings ratio through
recent quarters have been London and the surrounding areas, with an average multiple of 12.7x since 2015
(compared to 5.2x for the North East, and 5.7x for the North West). The more Northern regions typically display
better affordability ratios, given their lower house prices. The average UK mortgage rate secured in February 2021
was 1.92% (compared to 1.82% in February 2020), which while up from a low of 1.73% in August 2020, compares
to 3.85% in May 2011 (the highest point since the start of 2011).

**_Land Supply_**

Demand for housing is also affected by overall land supply levels. Housebuilders have reported a seismic
shift in the UK land market since the introduction of the NPPF in 2012 (subsequently revised in 2018), which put
forward a notion in favor of sustainable development built upon economic, social, and environmental objectives.
This has resulted in planning approvals for residential development in England rising toward 400,000 per annum,
which compares to just over 200,000 completions across the entirety of the United Kingdom in 2019 and an
average of 164,301 per annum in the five years up to and including 2012. This shift in the supply/demand dynamic
has led to much more moderate land prices. Whilst UK house prices are approximately 30% higher than their pre2008 peak, UK greenfield and urban land values are only back to 90% and 80% respectively of their peak 2007
values. This more moderate profile in the land market can also be seen from the disclosed land input costs of the
quoted housebuilders.

**Government Support for Housebuilding**

The introduction of the NPPF in 2012 and Help to Buy in 2013, the 2015 Spending Review and Autumn
Statement and the subsequent Housing and Planning Bill in November 2015 all stand as key milestones in a recent
historical context to evidence growing governmental support for the housebuilding sector. The December 2019


-----

Conservative Party majority win (the largest governmental majority since 2005) reinforced this, and the
Conservative Party reiterated its support for the sector in its 2021 annual budget.

**_New Housing_**

With new housing highlighted as a fundamental party value, the Conservative Party reiterated its pledge
to increase the number of new homes built per annum, with the goal of delivering at least one million additional
homes through this parliamentary cycle. A target of delivering 300,000 homes a year by the mid-2020s provides
scope for significant upside from current levels of approximately 200,000, with optimism reinforced by a proposed
£10 billion Single Housing Infrastructure Fund (a capital grant program to fund the provision of strategic
infrastructure, such as roads, schools and healthcare facilities, needed to support new homes) to help deliver on
targets.

**_Mortgage Guarantee Scheme_**

The Government announced in April 19, 2021 a new mortgage guarantee scheme which will increase the
availability of 95% loan-to-value mortgage products, enabling more households to access mortgages without the
need for prohibitively large deposits. Further, in an attempt to increase the ability of young people to take the first
step onto the housing ladder, the Government will seek to encourage a new market in long-term fixed rate
mortgages with slashed deposit values, improving entry-potential for first-time buyers across the UK.

**_Right to Buy_**

The voluntary Right to Buy scheme with housing associations is expected to continue, with the scheme
granting eligible housing association tenants the opportunity to purchase their homes at Right to Buy level
discounts. This comes following the successful pilot voluntary scheme adopted by five housing associations
(L&Q, Riverside, Saffron, Sovereign, and Thames Valley Housing) in 2016, and the subsequently launched
Midlands pilot scheme in August 2018. The latter saw 44 housing associations take part and a total of 1,892 home
sales or homes in the final stage of the sales process by 30 April 2020. All large housing associations (over 1,000
dwellings) in the Midlands took part, with four guiding principles acting as the basis for the scheme:

      - Right to Buy level discounts for eligible housing association tenants: eligible housing
association tenants have the right to the same level of discounts, funded by the Government, as
local authority tenants have under the statutory Right to Buy scheme.

      - Board control over which homes to sell: housing associations have the final decision over
whether or not to sell a property with the Government compensating the housing association
should the discount be applied to an alternative housing association property purchased by the
same tenant.

      - Full compensation: housing associations to receive the full market value of the property sold,
with the discount value funded by the Government.

      - Flexible one for one replacement through new supply nationally: for every home sold, a new
affordable property would be built in England to increase overall supply.

In February 2021, a full evaluation of the scheme was published by the Government, with a subsequent
indication they were committed to the evaluation of new pilot areas, with further details to be provided in due
course.

**_Right to Acquire_**

The Right to Acquire scheme is similar to the Right to Buy scheme, but is available to eligible housing
association tenants across England with homes built or acquired after April 1, 1997 who have had a public sector
landlord for at least three years. It provides a smaller level of discount compared to the Right to Buy scheme.

**_Help to Buy_**

An extension of the Help to Buy scheme from 2021 to 2023 has been confirmed, providing buyers with
deposits of at least 5% an interest free equity loan of up to 20% (London 40%) to help support the purchase of a
new build home. The scheme additionally incorporates regional maximum property price caps, ranging from


-----

£186,100 in the North East to £600,000 in London, denoting the maximum value of a home to which the scheme
applies. From April 1, 2021 onwards, the scheme is restricted to first-time buyers.

**_Help to Buy Shared Ownership_**

This scheme enables anyone in England with household income of less than £80,000 outside London and
£90,000 inside London to buy a home through shared ownership. Under the new model of this scheme, buyers
acquire a stake between 10% (previously 25%, but to be reduced to 10% from 2022) and 75% of the home’s value
and pay rent on the remaining share. This scheme is also expected to run until 2023.

**_Stamp Duty Holiday_**

The impact of the Coronavirus pandemic put the housebuilding sector largely on hold between March
and May 2020, with this followed by a period of reduced activity given the stop-start nature of the easing of
lockdown restrictions. In an attempt to both kick-start the housebuilding sector and reinvigorate the wider
economy, on July 8, 2020 the Chancellor announced a temporary increase in the amount a purchaser could pay
for residential property before Stamp Duty Land Tax (“SDLT”) would apply, from £125,000 to £500,000, for the
period July 8, 2020 to March 31, 2021. This holiday was extended until June 30, 2021, from which point the
threshold reduced to £250,000 until September 30, 2021, after which it will revert to £125,000.

**_Community Housing_**

The Right to Buy and Right to Acquire schemes will seek to assist tenants in local communities who
wish to establish ownership of their council/housing association homes. Additionally, the Government has also
announced £2.1 million in funding to help communities have a greater say in how their local area is developed.
The fund will boost neighborhood planning by giving additional support to local authorities in under-represented
areas.

**_Help to Build_**

The Government announced new plans in April 2021, supported by over £150 million in new funding,
to lower the required deposit for mortgages in order to make it easier and more affordable for people to build their
own homes. The Government estimate the Help to Build scheme could deliver 30,000 to 40,000 new homes per
year, with an equity loan provided with a low-level deposit similar to that of the Help to Buy scheme.

**_Affordable Homes Programme_**

The Affordable Homes Programme was set up in 2010 to provide grant funding to support the capital
costs of developing affordable housing for rent or sale. The first iteration of the program from 2011 to 2015 aimed
to fund the creation of 150,000 affordable homes through a combination of new builds and the conversion of
existing housing assets. A subsequent program was introduced for 2016 to 2021, in which the Government made
£4.7 billion of capital grants available to deliver starts on site for at least 135,000 homes for Help to Buy: Shared
Ownership; 10,000 homes for Rent to Buy; and 8,000 homes for supported and older people’s rental
accommodation. The provision of affordable housing was reaffirmed as a priority for the Government in the 2021
budget, with a pledge to invest £11.5 billion in the construction of affordable homes in England between 2021
and 2026, providing up to 180,000 new homes across the country. Approximately £7.5 billion of funding will be
provided to deliver up to 130,000 homes outside of London, and a further £4 billion to deliver homes in London.

**_First Homes_**

In June 2021, the UK Government launched a new initiative called “First Homes,” which offers firsttime buyers a minimum discount of 30% on the purchase of a new home through developer contributions. The
same percentage discount must then be passed on with the sale of the property to future buyers (who must also be
first-time buyers), meaning that homes will always be sold at a discount to market value in perpetuity, with the
aim of benefitting local communities, local workers and key workers and families. After the discount has been
applied, the first sale must be at a price no higher than £250,000 (or £420,000 in Greater London). Changes
proposed to the planning system to support this initiative may require that First Homes properties should account
for at least 25% of all affordable housing units secured through developer contributions. The Group partnered


-----

with Homes England and Bolsover District Council on the first phase of an early delivery project of First Homes
in the Bolsover district, East Midlands.

**_Environmentally Friendly Homes_**

Global support for green considerations and carbon reduction continues to grow, with the Government
echoing this in looking to support the creation of new homes with advanced energy saving capabilities in its
proposed changes to the building regulations governing the specification of the homes the sector builds. A vision
for ‘Homes of the future’ was laid out within the Conservative Party pledges, with an intended incorporation of
innovative design and technology noted as methods to address environmental considerations. The proposed Part
L and Future Homes standard in the building regulations will reduce the carbon dioxide emissions of running a
home, but will be more expensive to build.

A primary focus remains to further prioritize brownfield site developments and protect the Green belt
through enhanced biodiversity and improvements to poor land quality. The proposed 10% ‘Bio Diversity Net
Gain’ element of the Environment Bill could inadvertently increase the cost of developing brownfield land due to
it becoming dense, self-seeded vegetation over the decades it has been left vacant. This land is regarded as having
a higher bio diversity value, than greenfield land and therefore achieving the proposed net gain is potentially more
costly.

**Housebuilder and Lender Collaboration**

In recognition of the need for low deposit, high loan to value mortgages to support aspiring house buyers
become homeowners, the housebuilding sector and lenders are exploring new low-deposit mortgage products,
including a product backed by a mortgage indemnity scheme developed by the Home Builders Federation and
other market participants that will offer 95% loan to value mortgages for new homes. Upon completion of home
purchases offered as part of the scheme, the developer pays a percentage of the purchase price into an insurance
policy, which reduces risk for the lender. This scheme is currently being piloted in the North East of the UK but
is expected to be rolled out more widely across the UK should the trial prove to be successful.

**Regulatory Environment**

One of the key regulatory regimes that UK housebuilders must adhere to are those that concern planning
permissions for residential developments. In England and Wales, the majority of spatial planning is regulated by
the Town and Country Planning Act 1990. All developments, except for those which are permitted pursuant to
permitted development rights, require planning consent by the relevant local planning authority.

Planning consent is obtained through the preparation and submission of a planning application, which in
some circumstances may include an environmental statement prepared as part of the Environmental Impact
Assessment process. The planning application is considered by the local planning authority following consultation
with relevant stakeholders, having regard to national and local planning policies, environmental impacts and other
material considerations.

There are two types of planning consent that can be obtained. The first, known as outline planning
consent, is typically sought for the development of greenfield sites or larger sites requiring development in phases.
An application for outline planning permission allows for a decision on the general principles of how a site can
be developed. Outline planning permission is granted subject to conditions requiring the subsequent approval of
one or more “reserved matters.” Reserved matters are those aspects of the development which an application can
choose not to submit details of with an outline planning permission. These include aspects such as appearances
and layout. The second, known as full planning consent, grants detailed consent for the development.

Planning consents are granted subject to various conditions which must be complied with at certain points
throughout the delivery of a development. Some planning conditions require certain information to be provided
to and approved by the local planning authority prior to certain works being undertaken. In addition, all planning
permissions are granted subject to the development commencing within a certain period of time, failure of which
results in the lapsing of the planning consent.

In the case of most developments, local planning authorities require that housebuilders enter into Section
106 agreements prior to the grant of planning consent in order to make such developments acceptable in planning


-----

terms. These agreements govern a developer’s commitments to build affordable housing and infrastructure, in
addition to providing other community benefits. Obligations under these agreements could include financial
contributions towards local infrastructure (including schools, roads and healthcare facilities) that are needed as a
result of increased demand brought about by the development. Additional obligations could include affordable
housing contributions, which may take place either through an on-site requirement for the housebuilder to build
an agreed amount of affordable housing or payment of a commuted sum. The level of affordable housing
contributions is often set within local authority planning policy but can be renegotiated on specific grounds.
Section 106 agreements must be entered into by the owner of the land for which the related planning permission
relates. As the obligations contained within such agreements run with the land and (subject to any exclusions
agreed with the local planning authority), they are enforceable against subsequent owners of the land.

In England and Wales, housebuilders may also be required to pay a Community Infrastructure Levy
charge typically intended to contribute to the wider infrastructure of an area in which a site is located.

Given the complexity and localized nature of the land planning system, the overall process is usually
considered risky, time consuming and expensive. Following a consultation process launched in August 2020
which was aimed at reforming the planning system, the Government is expected to bring a new planning bill
before the UK Parliament in Autumn 2021. Some of the key areas under consideration are:

      - consulting local communities from the beginning of the planning process;

      - harnessing the latest technology through online maps and data in order to ensure the planning
system is more accessible;

      - ensuring local plans are developed and agreed in 30 months – down from the current average of
seven years – so that homes may be built more quickly;

      - overhauling the current planning process with a clearer, rules-based system. Under the current
system, approximately one third of planning cases that go to appeal are overturned at appeal;
and

      - replacing the existing systems for funding affordable housing and infrastructure with a new,
more predictable, and more transparent levy.

In July 2021, the Government introduced its long anticipated Building Safety Bill (which is applicable
in England, although some of the changes will also apply to Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland). The Building
Safety Bill has not yet made its way through the UK Parliament, and it is anticipated that this will take at least
nine months from the introduction of the bill and possibly longer. Thereafter, the changes will come into force
incrementally. The Building Safety Bill has been introduced to strengthen the regulatory system for building
safety, change industry culture to foster a greater emphasis on safety and accountability, implement rigorous safety
standards for construction products, and provide a clearer path to redress for homeowners. The main elements of
the Building Safety Bill include:

      - overhauling the regulatory landscape for the design and construction of high risk residential
buildings that are 18 meters or have at least seven stories and two residential units and their
subsequent occupation, management and operation;

      - establishing a building safety regulator and updating existing building safety regulations;

      - establishing a new framework to provide national oversight of construction products and
strengthening the powers of the Office for Product Safety and Standards in this area;

      - establishing a new homes ombudsman and simplifying the process to log complaints to the
Housing Ombudsman Service for social housing tenants;

      - making financial provisions to support the removal of unsafe cladding, including through a levy
on developers seeking permission to develop certain high rise buildings in England; and

      - strengthening the enforcement action that can be taken in the event of breach including in
relation to criminal offences for non-compliance.


-----

Impact assessments undertaken by the Government indicate that the reforms will cost the industry more
than £1 billion in their first three years. This is not inclusive of the levy referred to above, nor is it inclusive of the
proposed new tax for the UK residential property development sector (which also serves to meet cladding
remediation costs). The proposed new tax will apply to residential developers’ profits over £25 million and the
Government anticipates raising at least £2 billion over a decade. The Government is currently in consultations to
determine the structure of the tax scheme ahead of its inclusion in Finance Bill 2021-22.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are one of the UK’s oldest and most experienced partnership housebuilders, with “5-Star
Homebuilder” status awarded in 2021. We are focused on creating sustainable communities in places where
people want to live, and we specialize in the delivery of affordable and high quality homes, principally targeted
at first-time buyers. Headquartered in Doncaster, England, we operate across England and Scotland through nine
operating regions. We are a top ten UK housebuilder, measured by the number of homes sold, including delivering
4,035 homes in our financial year ended October 31, 2019.

Unlike traditional housebuilders, our business model is based on partnerships with entities interested in
seeing an increase in supply of homes as well as those with demand for our product. These partners are primarily
land owners (such as Homes England, Local Authorities and private land owners) or Registered Providers, which
include the traditional not-for-profit and the newer for-profit entities that are registered with the Regulator of
Social Housing to provide affordable housing. We engage each of our key stakeholders in residential projects by
establishing, aligning and prioritizing their needs and successfully delivering their objectives. We have built our
reputation by aligning our approach to our partners’ objectives regarding the sourcing, procurement, planning and
delivery of successful, affordable housing developments that create significant social value. We believe that we
are the original partnership-focused housebuilder in the United Kingdom, having worked with over 200 partners
to date, with many of these relationships enduring for over 20 years.

Our partnership model allows us to have a high degree of certainty over our land pipeline, with sufficient
land secured for six years of development based on our future development plans and on 2019 home deliveries,
while also typically allowing us to defer payment until milestones are met. We are also able to minimize
development and planning risks by partnering with land owners through the early stages of a development project.
Coupled with the relatively low land costs for the affordable homes that we target, we are able to operate a capitallight business model relative to traditional housebuilders, and generate relatively strong cash conversion and
ROCE. In the financial year ended October 31, 2019, the last full financial year prior to the start of the COVID19 pandemic, our ROCE was 32.8%.

We focus on developing urban and suburban locations where there is an inherent demand and supply
imbalance for new homes. We aim to meet this demand through our five core standard house type ranges. This
standardization allows efficiency in procuring materials and construction, increased certainty of cost and timing
of delivery, and assists in establishing optimal site layout mix based on demand and our partners’ preferences. We
are continually working with new technologies that underpin and refine our designs.

We are committed to deliver a range of affordable housing, predominantly for open market sale, social
housing and shared ownership – which provides us with a higher degree of market resilience over the long term
due to generally consistent demand from first-time buyers and well-funded Registered Providers. In the financial
year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 74% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to
private customers as well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a
site), with the remaining approximately 26% of our sales comprising sales to Registered Providers that are
contracted at the outset of development of a site, including but not limited to those contracted to satisfy Section
106 obligations. Approximately 87% of our open market sales in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 were
to private sale customers, of which approximately 76% were to first-time buyers (first-time buyers accounted for
76% during the financial year ended October 31, 2019). In the financial year ended October 31, 2020,
approximately 45% of our total sales, including 67% of sales to first time buyers, involved the use of the
Government HTB scheme. We believe that first-time buyers provide more resilient structural demand than the
typically discretionary and cyclical home-mover segment.

place making. In July 2020, following stakeholder consultation, we published our Sustainability Strategy in which

have committed to minimizing our impact on the environment and biodiversity. In particular, we have announced
that we intend to achieve a net zero carbon position by the mid-2040s (having formally committed to Race to
Zero) and that we intend to publicly disclose our carbon performance from 2022 onwards.

We were active on 94 sites as of July 31, 2021. In addition, as of July 31, 2021, the number of plots

secured (meaning that we have a contractual right to develop or a conditionally exchanged contract). As of July
31, 2021, approximately 19% of our land pipeline, or 4,721 plots, were those on which we had been appointed

contract for the development of the site). Together, these plots are equivalent to a six-year supply of homes, based

planned sales for the year ended October 31, 2022, 85% of our planned sales for the three months ended January
31, 2022, and 45% of our planned sales for the three months ended April 30, 2022. As of September 19, 2021, we
had an eight-week rolling average rate of 0.93, demonstrating continued strong demand from our customers.

Our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 were £628.5 million and
£73.8 million, respectively. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data.” Over the same
period, we generated Free Cash Flow of £44.1 million (and free cash flow conversion of 59.8%). The resilience
of our business model was demonstrated through the COVID-19 pandemic. Working with our partners, we were
able to agree a deferral of 89% of committed and uncommitted land spend, without losing any site investment
opportunities as a result. We believe our financial results in recent quarters demonstrate the resiliency and strength
of our business model.

**Our Strengths**

**_Strong Fundamentals Underpinning the UK Housing Sector, Supported by a Favorable Government Policy_**
**_Environment_**

The supply of housing in the UK market has lagged behind demand and the regions where we operate in
particular are characterized by a structural supply-demand imbalance. The UK Government’s position has
historically been that everyone should have the opportunity to own an affordable, decent home within a sustainable
and mixed community. To this end, support for the housing market and first-time buyers has been a target of
government policy over recent years, starting with the introduction of the NPPF in 2012.

In its 2021 annual budget, the Government reiterated its pledge to increase the number of new homes
built per annum, with the goal of delivering at least one million additional homes through this parliamentary cycle.
Overall, the Government has a target to build 300,000 homes per year through the mid-2020s (as announced in
the Budget 2017), and we expect there to be continued support for the housebuilding sector as the Government
seeks to achieve this target.

The following chart shows the number of homes completed by private sector and public sector funding,
as compared to the Government target of 300,000 per year.

In particular, the first-time buyer market outside of London, our core target market, is aided by a
supportive structural and political backdrop promoting both home ownership and affordable housing, including
through UK central Government funds, loans, grants and subsidies, which assist in both the viability of schemes
and also pace of delivery. As demonstrated by the recently launched “First Homes” program, which offers firsttime buyers a minimum 30% discount on the purchase of a new build home, we expect this segment to continue
to be a key focus area for the UK government in the future. This has contributed to a rise in housebuilding
completions to 178,310 in England in the year ended December 31, 2019, the highest level since 2007. This is,
however, far below the 300,000 per year needed in England as estimated by the UK Government in early 2021
despite the macro-economic uncertainty created by the pandemic. As household formation continues to rise and
the pandemic has reinforced buyer preferences for houses over flats, we have experienced a strong recovery in
2021 to date.

**_We Operate in those areas of the UK Housing Market with the Highest Levels of Affordability and Resilience_**

We believe that we are strategically positioned in the most attractive segment of the UK housing market,
from both a demographic and a geographic perspective. Key attractions of this market segment include resilience
in adverse macroeconomic environments, the greatest affordability levels in terms of income/price ratios and one
of the strongest growth rates in historical and forecast volumes. This segment is also conducive to strong
partnerships with land owners such as Homes England and other local authorities, as well as delivery partners,
including Registered Providers, in their role as agents for the implementation of Government housing policies
driven by social objectives.

As a result, we have achieved consistently strong sales rates in recent years, outperforming more broadly
focused housebuilders. From April 2017 to July 2021, Keepmoat has achieved an average open market sales rate
per outlet per week of 0.82, which is above the broader housing sector’s average open market sales rate per outlet
per week of 0.66.

**_Our Partnership Model Carries Inherently Less Risk than the Traditional Housebuilding Model, with High_**
**_Barriers to Entry and Partners that are Structurally Aligned_**

We are one of the UK’s leading dedicated partnership-focused housebuilders with a proven track-record
and a strong reputation of delivering large scale, multi-faceted, residential-led regeneration schemes throughout
England and Scotland. Unlike traditional housebuilders, we primarily develop in collaboration with partners that
have some form of long-term continuing interest (either through ownership or social responsibility) in the relevant
development. We are a partner of land owners such as Homes England and other Local Authorities, as well as
delivery partners, including Registered Providers of affordable housing, strategically catering to structural demand
driven by social objectives and Government housing policies.

Partnership relationships promote effective and capital light land sourcing and site development (often
with deferred payment terms correlated to the pace of site development and unit sales), as well as the ability to
unlock development sites often inaccessible to traditional housebuilders. Unlike the traditional model, the
partnership model offers an attractive financial profile with lower land acquisition costs, favorable (often deferred)
payment terms, cash generative and competitively priced deals with Registered Providers, access to grant funding
and accelerated delivery, enabling us to pursue investments with an attractive ROCE.

Over the past 25 years, we have developed strong relationships with many of the largest land partners in
the UK, which are predominantly public land owners but also include private land owners, and have built a strong
reputation for delivery, quality and place making (i.e., creating thriving, sustainable communities where people
genuinely want to live, work and play). Relationships are maintained at multiple organizational levels, which help
identify future projects and facilitate successful tender processes. This results in a high volume of repeat business
and a strong visibility of the order book. Long-standing partner relationships such as ours are inherently difficult
to replicate for new entrants.

We believe that the partnership model also has a reduced risk profile, as it is fundamentally based on a
structural alignment of objectives among ourselves and our partners, which results in pragmatism and flexibility
when required. As demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic, working with our partners, we were able to
agree a deferral of 80% of committed land spend and 97% of forecast uncommitted land spend, without losing
any site investment opportunities as a result.

**_Operating Model with Best-In-Class Processes and Cost Structure_**

We have specialized in offering a standardized product range of family homes as the optimal means of
building affordable and high quality housing units, while minimizing execution risk and improving predictability
of costs as well as improving construction build times. This focus on product standardization is a key
differentiating element of our business model and commercial proposition to our partners, contributing to the
creation of a strong brand.

To facilitate standardization, we typically utilize our five standard house type ranges, catering to the
requirements of private sale, sale to Registered Providers and local authorities, future mobility standards and
Scottish building standards (where applicable), which assist in establishing optimal site layout mix based on
demand and partner’s preferences. Although it varies from year to year, in the financial year ended October 31,
2020, 88% of our homes were built using standardized housing types.

The in-house development process of our portfolio of core standard designs is based on internal feedback
for saleability, buildability, customer feedback and land/commercial optimization, and is a key driver of the
continued operational improvements across the Group that have resulted in enhanced operating margins.


-----

Standardization of house types has enabled us to accurately reflect third party designs (such as heating,
roofs, furniture and kitchens) for space and accessibility standards. These standard details allow us to promote
best practices for quality, safety and precise material scheduling, optimizing waste as a result. Importantly,
standard specifications facilitate forward demand planning, purchase leverage and rebate maximization. It allows
contractors to bid aggressively on our projects as they have greater confidence around deliverability on cost and
on time. The standardization process has also enhanced the quality of our products which, in turn, has increased
customer satisfaction and reduced aftercare costs.

The efficiencies across the supply chain and cost control and optimization have strengthened our ability
to maintain strong margins and provide a partial defense from cost inflation pressures. This is further enhanced
by our disciplined approach through all stages of capital allocation, acquisitions and cost control. Standardization
has also enabled us to continue to maintain a low ASP, providing the potential to benefit from sale price increases
during inflationary periods.

**_Proven Ability to Source Land through a Disciplined Acquisition Process_**

We have implemented a structured and agile land acquisition process, enabling a continued
replenishment of our land pipeline that has contributed to sustained margin improvement over the last few years.
As there is a lag between the securing of land and the ultimate delivery of finished product on that land, we may
see benefit from this focus on land acquisition being realized over time.

We have a controlled and disciplined internal land acquisition approval process, working within defined
control gateways each requiring senior executive and/or Capex Committee approval. Our land approval protocol
involves three stages. The Pre-Bid Capex proposal establishes the nature, suitability and targeted financial returns
(for gross margin and ROCE) of the opportunity. The Capex 1 Proposal includes a review of planning, title and
legal reports, site risks/mitigants and required approvals, with continued focus on delivering in line with the
threshold financial returns. Finally, the Capex 2 proposal is the region’s final proposal to develop the site
(including financial plan) once all legal matters and major approvals are received. We believe this rigorous land
sourcing process, together with sales price optimization, build and sales management and the resulting increasing
mix of higher quality and better procured sites, may all be contributing factors driving continued margin
expansion.

For example, for sites under development that were approved between 2017 and 2019 (excluding the
North West MCI region), average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for each year of approval
range from approximately 22% to 23% by year, whereas for sites either approved since 2020 or within our secured
pipeline and to be approved, average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for each year of
approval or for the “to be approved” category, range from approximately 24% to 25% by year or category. This
is an increase from the average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for sites under development
that were approved in 2016 and pre-2016, for which average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins
are approximately 21% and 18%, respectively.

We have a strong management team with a proven track record in UK housebuilding, including expertise
in land acquisition, construction, planning, development and partnering with housing associations, local
authorities, and Registered Providers. This has been instrumental in helping us to achieve 5-Star Homebuilder

Since the formation of our executive management team in 2018, we have delivered consistent year-onyear revenue growth, Gross Development Margin and EBIT growth (excluding the COVID-impacted financial
year ended October 31, 2020). The team has accomplished this primarily through an increase in scale, improved

which has extensive knowledge of the selected regions in which we operate.

**_Strong Financial Track Record of Growth and Returns_**

We have a strong track record of growth and increase in profitability in recent years, resulting from the
combination of our geographical expansion process and strong focus on operational improvements and margin
expansion. From the financial year ended March 31, 2015 to the financial year ended October 31, 2019, revenue
grew by a CAGR of 22% and home completions grew from 2,133 to 4,035 (representing a CAGR of 15%), driven


-----

by methodical expansion in established regions and into new regions, including in January 2017 the acquisition
of MCI Developments Limited in the North West, as well as benefiting from ASP increases.

The KM Group’s Adjusted EBIT increased 47.7% from £41.4 million for the financial year ended March
