**Our Strategies**

Our strategy is to maintain and strengthen our position as one of the leading partnerships-focused
housebuilders in the UK, while delivering enhanced margins and returns from our maturing regional platform. To
achieve this goal, we are focused on the following key strategic priorities.

**_High Visibility on Medium Term Revenue Growth, Risk Mitigation Opportunities and Margin Improvement_**

Our current land pipeline reflects a strong level of land security to deliver on the business plan and
continue to drive future growth, providing us with excellent forward visibility. As of July 31, 2021, there were
24,654 plots in our land pipeline, of which approximately 81% were legally secured, meaning that we have a
contractual right to develop or a conditionally exchanged contract. This equates to a land pipeline of six years at
pre-pandemic annual volumes. We intend to continue to leverage our strong land pipeline and high near-term land
visibility to increase delivery volumes.

We currently characterize five of our nine regions (the East Midlands, South Midlands, North West MCI,
Scotland and West Midlands regions) as “growth regions,” and we believe these regions have significant potential
to deliver additional plots within the existing regional management structure as they mature. We will target both
continued growth in volume and margin improvement, as the business delivers on regional management team
investments that have been made in these growth regions and benefits from the continued realization of land
acquired through improved sourcing processes.

Approximately 86% of our land pipeline has agreed deferred land payment terms with our partners. Of
our land pipeline plots that have been legally secured as of July 31, 2021, approximately 37% represents projects
that were not legally completed and there remained conditionality (e.g., planning and groundworks survey) prior
to finalizing the contract. There are further risk mitigation opportunities available to us within our partnership
model such as land payments made by Registered Provider partners, overage agreements, pace and tenure delivery
flexibility and multi-tenure development.

The benefits of these risk mitigation features have been demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic,
with our strong relationships with partners providing flexibility to recalibrate land and delivery obligations during
this challenging period. Altogether, we were able to either defer or pay in alignment with plot delivery £58.4
million of £65.5 million total forecast land payments (89%) from April 1, 2020 to August 31, 2020.

**_Continued Development of Our Large and Strong Land Pipeline_**

In addition to building out our strong land pipeline of over 24,000 plots, we intend to continue to pursue
new land opportunities to maintain the secured land pipeline, particularly increasing the amount of higher quality,
better procured sites (reflecting our enhanced requirements and processes prior to approval for an opportunity
being granted). We expect to continue to have a structured, disciplined and agile approach to land acquisitions to
facilitate securing suitable land opportunities across all of our regions, who each have dedicated land acquisition
teams focused on high quality land opportunities within each region’s geographical area of operation.

**_Strengthen Relationships with Key Stakeholders_**

We intend to build on our long-standing relationships with key stakeholders such as Registered Providers,
Local Authorities, and Government agencies, such as Homes England. These relationships have been nurtured


-----

over two decades and are held throughout our organizational structure and that of our partners, from executives
to regional management and staff.

We have a proven track record for delivery, quality and placemaking resulting in winning repeat business.
Going forward, we will continue to align objectives with key partners in areas such as climate and biodiversity
emergency targets, in addition to the growing need for affordable homes. We will also seek to develop new
relationships through our new business teams.

**_Continue to Focus on Delivering Best Services while Maintaining Strong ESG Benefits and H&S Standards_**
**_at our Sites_**

Customer satisfaction is at the heart of our business and we strive to deliver high-quality homes and
customer service, reflected by our 5-star customer status. We intend to continue to focus on ensuring that our
customers are supported throughout their house buying journey, meeting their expectations, and providing them
with a high-quality new home.

Sustainability is core to the partnership business model and we are committed to prioritizing ESG
initiatives. Key stakeholders are aligned in their focus with approximately 74% of Local Authorities in the UK
declaring a climate and biodiversity change emergency, with regeneration areas often more vulnerable to climate
and environmental impacts. We are working with Wildscapes, which is a wildlife trust consultancy, to develop
methodologies to support the delivery of a net gain in biodiversity for future developments. We are responsible
for placemaking and regeneration which in turn helps create direct and indirect employment opportunities within
low-income communities. We are focused on providing affordable, low carbon homes to contribute to delivering
on our and our partners’ objectives of improving the environmental sustainability of the UK’s homes.

We have committed to a number of near term ESG targets, including: introducing science-based carbon
targets aligned to limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius along with carbon performance metrics (currently
anticipated to be set in late 2021); setting our decarbonisation roadmap within 12 months from July 2021, with
the aim of achieving a net zero carbon position by the mid-2040s; mitigating supply chain risks and supporting
our supply chain to become more sustainable; and updating our sustainability structure, providing greater
oversight and focus on sustainability with the function reporting directly to the CEO and receiving greater focus
from the Board.

Additionally, we have well-developed and structured H&S policies, certified to ISO 45001:2018, and
training programs, as reflected in our health and safety track record. We have clear policies, best practice guides
and robust standards and operate a number of forward looking and backward looking metrics.

We continuously seek to improve our H&S performance and approach, focusing on risk throughout all
phases of a development. Our strategic objectives are centered around (i) keeping people safe and healthy every
day; (ii) protecting and enhancing the environment; and (iii) being assured and informed. Each of the these
strategic objectives contain a number of initiatives focused on achieving the objectives and cover, amongst other
matters, active and visible leadership; managing risk effectively and proportionately; accountability, behavior and
culture; capability; contemporary management systems; and key performance indicators. As initiatives are
implemented, they are reviewed for effectiveness by our executive EHS committee and monitored.

**Our History**

Our origins as a partnership focused homebuilder date back to 1931, when we were founded as Bromell
& Ogden to work with local authorities in South Yorkshire to build and maintain essential amenities. Since then,
we have grown organically and through acquisitions.

During the 2008 financial crisis, we came under the ownership of the Lloyds Banking Group, which was
then our financial lender. The Lloyds Banking Group exited in 2014, with TDR Capital LLP (“TDR”) and Sun
Capital Partners (“Sun”) acquiring controlling interests. Under TDR’s and Sun’s control, we introduced a new
management team focused on growing our business, expanding from four regions in 2014 to nine regions as of
the date of this Offering Memorandum.

Our organic growth was enhanced in January 2017 by the acquisition of MCI a developer of social
housing projects for local authorities and other Registered Providers, which strengthened our capacity, particularly
in the North West of England. Following the acquisition of MCI, we further streamlined our operations, selling
our regeneration business to ENGIE for £330 million. With our renewed focus on homebuilding, and the


-----

completion of a successful internal restructuring exercise to streamline our regional operations, we obtained 5star Homebuilder status in 2021.

**Business Operations**

We are one of the UK’s largest partnership-focused housebuilders, working with over 200 partners to
date including Homes England, Local Authorities and Registered Providers, as well as private partners, with
strong expertise in regeneration projects to develop affordably priced housing and positive social outcomes.
Approximately 79% of the plots in our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021 were being developed under the
partnership model. The remainder of our homes are planned to be developed under speculative land deals whereby
we purchase land to then develop sites on our own.

We have a presence across much of the UK (excluding the greater London area, Wales, southern home
counties and directly west and north west of London) and were one of the top-ten UK housebuilders from 2018
to 2020 (measured by the number of homes sold), delivering a total of 3,988 homes in the twelve months ended
October 31, 2018, 4,035 homes in the financial year ended October 31, 2019, 2,460 homes in the financial year
ended October 31, 2020 (reflecting the impact of COVID-19 during the second half of the financial year ended
October 31, 2020) and 3,652 homes in the twelve months ended July 31, 2021. We focus on building homes with
standardized designs, which in turn contributes to design and building efficiencies and quality control. Our designs
are also relatively straightforward to build and sell, as they do not involve high rise buildings, complex
construction methods or cladding. Our homes typically have two to four bedrooms, with 25% of our plots as of
October 31, 2020 consisting of two bedroom homes, 59% consisting of three bedroom homes and 13% consisting
of four bedroom homes. Of those private homes which achieved legal completion in the financial year ended
October 31, 2020, approximately 57% were semi-detached houses, 15% were detached houses, 11% were end of
terrace houses, 10% were mid-terrace houses and 7% were apartments.

is responsible for each of the two divisions, supported by a Divisional Finance Director in each division.

structure provides an appropriate span of control for the divisional management team, allowing the right level of
oversight for each region to ensure that performance is carefully monitored while maintaining alignment of our
overall strategy and growth plans.

**_Our Partnership Model_**

Our partnership model is central to our approach to development and sets us apart from our competitors.
Our partnership model presents the following benefits:

      - reduced competition for large scale land opportunities;

      - resilient demand for affordable homes;

      - capital light approach delivering strong ROCE; and

      - repeat business through track record and reputation.

Unlike traditional housebuilders, we primarily develop in collaboration with partners that have some
form of long-term continuing interest (either through ownership or social responsibility) in the relevant
development, which are primarily land owners (such as Homes England, Local Authorities and private land
owners) and Registered Providers of social housing. We assist our partners in achieving their key goals of
regenerating sites that achieve positive social outcomes through the provision of high-quality, affordable housing.
Our focus on this segment of the market provides us with significant expertise in the management of regeneration
projects, which is a key differentiator between us and most traditional housebuilders. We believe that this model
facilitates efficient, effective and capital light land sourcing and site development, while also enhancing returns
and mitigating market and development risks.

Some of our partner agreements facilitate the drawdown of land under phased viability assessments.
These forms of agreements accounted for approximately 19% of our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021, and see
large development opportunities broken down into phases, with the land for each phase being appraised and valued
at the time that we are ready to develop it. Payment terms are also agreed and drawn down once we are ready to
develop that phase, and are therefore based on the prevailing market conditions at the time. This allows us to
assess the performance of a prior phase before we commit and agree to payment terms and a land valuation for
the following phase. The characteristics of phased viability schemes help to reduce the working capital
requirements of each project, limit our market and planning risk (including exposure to unexpected land cost
depreciation) and allow us to mitigate any exposure to challenging partner specifications or cost inflation related
to construction and materials. For our other partner agreements, land is purchased from our partners as a single
site, with the land value and payment terms (often deferred) agreed at the completion of the deal. We complement
this approach with a build timescale that matches our sales patterns.

As of July 31, 2021, our land pipeline comprised 24,654 plots equating to six years of land supply at prepandemic volumes. The composition of the land pipeline is as follows:

      - 19% is that which we categorize as “preferred developer” status, where we have been chosen
by the land vendor as the final candidate to progress to contract for the development of the site.

      - 30% is secured with a conditional contract, often subject to planning approval and ground
condition resolution. Consolidating these first two categories, 49% of the pipeline is made up

      - The residual 51% is land on which we have legally completed the purchase or securing of the

Our legally secured plots have certain features which mitigate certain risks associated with developing
the plots. These features include (i) deferred payment terms, which are often correlated to the pace of delivery;
(ii) land payments that are made by Registered Provider partners; (iii) low base land costs through negotiation and
the inclusion of an overage share; (iv) pace and tenure delivery flexibility, which is particularly significant during
periods of market slowdown; and (v) opportunities for multi-tenure delivery.

_Land Creditor Commitments_

Our partnership model seeks to enhance returns and mitigate risk by reducing upfront investment in the
land through deferred payment terms, payments on a per-plot basis, payments triggered by cumulative plot sales
or similar development milestones (that may or may not include specified backstop dates) and deferred land
tranche payments. As of July 31, 2021, 86% of our land pipeline was purchased with land payments to be made
on deferred terms.

We believe that our land creditor profile provides us with an element of risk mitigation, as the majority
of our payments are linked to development delivery milestones rather than needing to be made up front. Our land
creditor commitments are unwound as the relevant payments for these deferred land costs fall due and are made
from period to period. The following chart shows the amount of land creditor commitments as of July 31, 2021,
that we expect to unwind during each of the periods indicated:

In addition, some of our arrangements with development partners include overage mechanisms, whereby

**_Our Partners_**

We leverage our long-term partner relationships to both access target sites and proactively identify
delivery partners for development opportunities. As of July 31, 2021, 79% of the plots in our land pipeline were
being developed under the partnership model. Our partners include public and private sector land owners as well
as Registered Providers. In particular, we benefit from strong, long-standing relationships with public bodies
(including Homes England, Local Authorities and charitable organizations, and Registered Providers) and private
land owners. These relationships have been built using our successful track-record of delivering projects, our
reputation for aligning our approach with our partners’ objectives, our established national scale and our deep
understanding of the motivations beyond financial returns that are important to our partners (including social
value, sustainability, accelerated delivery and design quality). We have established a track record of doing repeat
business with a growing number of partners.

Our partners select housebuilders that can help them deliver their housing, economic, social and
environmental goals. Choosing a developer who can (a) repurpose brownfield land into well-designed schemes of
affordable, high-quality homes, (b) regenerate neglected, derelict areas into thriving mixed tenure communities
that are socially and economically inclusive, and (c) deliver this in a way that enhances the public realm and
biodiversity and reduces carbon outputs which is at the forefront of partners’ objectives.

In order to successfully operate our partnership model, it is imperative that we understand our partners’
goals and maintain and promote strong relationships and a strong reputation for delivery. Our reputation and
understanding of these features contributes to our strong forward pipeline of projects and our competitive
advantage. We believe that this understanding, alongside our extensive experience with the public procurement
process and proven regeneration expertise, provides us with a significant competitive advantage. Furthermore,
our partnership oriented focus allows us to remain closely aligned with Government housing policy and our close
work with various levels of government allows us to participate in a wide range of pilot projects and government
consultation initiatives. Working with these partners provides us with the potential to access grant funding and
investment support (particularly from Homes England and Local Authority partners) to facilitate the development
of land that would otherwise be unviable to develop. As a result of the structured and lengthened timelines that
we operate under while working with our partners, we are able to carry out extensive due diligence and thorough
evaluations of the technical and economic feasibility of a project development before committing to a land value,
which in turn serves as an important risk mitigation tool. Conversely, in traditional development and in speculative
transactions, the due diligence and evaluation of a site is often undertaken in a compressed timeframe so that the
site can be acquired before the vendor has the opportunity to sell the site to another prospective purchaser.

Registered Providers are experts in delivering multi-tenure housing, which may include social rent,
affordable rent, market rent and shared ownership homes in a single development. We believe that a multi-tenure
housing offer is essential in order to regenerate and deliver truly sustainable communities and this acts as a driving
factor as to why we work with delivery partners including Registered Providers. In addition, creating multi-tenure
communities allows us to diversify our revenue streams among various demographics and through shared
ownership, outright sale and private rented homes.

In June 2021 we applied to be part of Homes England’s new “dynamic purchasing system” and received

**_Working with Registered Providers_**

Our work with Registered Providers can be divided into three distinct categories:

      - _Registered Provider sales required through Section 106 obligations (categorized as Registered_
_Provider sales): Local planning policies often specify the proportion of homes on new_
residential developments that must be provided as social housing through a Registered Provider.
This obligation is often a condition to planning consent for a particular site, and is set out in
each case through a Section 106 agreement. Social housing that must be delivered through a
Section 106 agreement is ineligible for Affordable Homes Programme funding and, as a result,
Registered Providers generally purchases these homes at a significant discount to their open
market value. This discount is factored into our land appraisal at the outset of the development.
Registered providers typically pay for these homes incrementally as the site is developed.


-----

      - _Registered Provider sales, in addition to Section 106 obligations, agreed at the outset of_
_development of a site (categorized as Registered Provider sales): These sales represent_
agreements (agreed at the outset of development) to sell all or a proportion of the homes on a
site to a Registered Provider as part of our strategy for purchasing and developing a site, in
addition to any Section 106 obligations. As these sales are in addition to any social housing
obligations under Section 106 agreements, they are eligible for Affordable Housing Programme
funding, which helps generate attractive commercial offers from the Registered Provider.
Registered providers typically pay for these homes incrementally as the site is developed.

      - _Elective Registered Provider sales agreed during the development of a site (categorized as open_
_market sales): These are sales agreed with Registered Providers after the development of a site_
has already commenced. Had each such sale not been made, we would otherwise have sold the
home to a private buyer as part of our overall open market selling activity for the site. The
decision to agree this form of sale is based on the specific economics of each potential
Registered Provider elective sale, as benchmarked against other open market sale opportunities.
These sales are particularly useful in periods where the residential housing market has slowed,
or where a site is less attractive on the open market than otherwise predicted. As these elective
sales are in addition to any Section 106 obligations, the Registered Provider is able to access
Affordable Homes Programme funding, which helps generate attractive commercial offers.
Registered Providers typically pay for these units through a deposit with the balance paid upon
completion.

Our work with Registered Providers provides us with a number of benefits, including:

      - a capital efficient work stream, as Registered Providers often pay incrementally and in advance
of their homes being built (often with a significant upfront deposit), which thereby strengthens
each project’s ROCE;

      - the multi-tenure housing (including shared ownership homes) that we offer to Registered
Providers serves as a natural complement to our private sales;

      - Registered Providers are well funded by the Government and have delivery commitments to
fulfil in a defined period of time; and

      - in addition to our developments with Registered Providers pursuant to Section 106 obligations
or pursuant to build agreements at the outset of a site development, we have found that
Registered Providers’ strong appetite for homes generally provide us with an opportunity to
make additional elective sales during the period of development, on commercial terms that are
in line with a home’s full open market value.

The benefits of our partnership model and our work with Registered Provides have been demonstrated
during the COVID-19 pandemic, with our strong relationships with partners providing flexibility to recalibrate
land and delivery obligations during this challenging period. Altogether, we were able to either defer or pay in
alignment with plot delivery £58.4 million of £65.5 million total forecast land payments (89%) from April 1, 2020
to August 31, 2020. The following chart further describes our ability to defer or pay in alignment with plot delivery
during the COVID-19 pandemic:

**_Selected Ongoing Partnership Developments_**

Some of our current projects being undertaken through our partnership model include:

      - _Charlestown, Salford:_ Charlestown is a brownfield development project that we have
undertaken together with Salford City Council. The development, which was launched in
October 2016, is a 15 hectare development of 425 homes, located in a deprived community in
Salford. The development will include two hectares of green space, amounting to 13% of the
total area of the development. 85 homes at the site, equating to 20% of the total homes
developed, will be affordable homes. The project is expected to complete in June 2024.
Environmental benefits at the site include the creation of a Sand Martin nesting colony on the
riverbank and 99% of waste being diverted from the landfill. The sites environmental benefits
have received notable recognition, having been shortlisted for the BIG Biodiversity Award for
NEET (not in education, employment or training) horticultural project.

      - _Primrose Lodge, Goscote: Primrose Lodge is a brownfield development project that we have_
undertaken together with Walsall Housing Group (selected through its DPP). The development,
which was launched in November 2019, is a 11.9 hectare development of 407 homes, located
in a deprived community in Goscote, Walsall, on the site of a former interwar housing estate.
126 homes at the site, equating to 31% of the site’s total homes, will be affordable homes. The
project is expected to complete in May 2026. Environmental benefits at the site include: (i) no
net loss of biodiversity through native species planning in woodlands and public open spaces;
(ii) sustainable drainage ponds providing amphibian habitats and local species nesting boxes
and habitation; (iii) the inclusion of an electric vehicle charging point in all homes; (iv)
sustainable drainage designed for a one in one hundred year flood plus 40% climate change
adaptation; and (v) 99% of waste being diverted from the landfill. Social benefits include a
commitment to providing work placements, school support, construction college support and

      - _Waterside, Leicester: Waterside is a brownfield development project that we have undertaken_
together with Leicester City Council, and which represents our first major scheme in the city.
The development, which was launched in November 2019, is a 6.95 hectare development of
288 homes, located in a deprived community near Leicester city center on a site formerly
occupied by an industrial estate and cement batching plant. The site will include a 79 bedroom
extra care facility. The project is expected to complete in April 2026. Environmental benefits at

sustainable drainage to prevent localized flooding in a high flood risk area; and (iv) 99% of
waste being diverted from the landfill. Social benefits include (i) the creation of 88 work
placements to date along with nineteen full-time jobs that will continue to exist after

**_Our Development Process_**

_Sourcing Development Opportunities_

Land sourcing opportunities and strategy are a crucial aspect of our business and receive a significant
amount of attention from our senior management. We source land for our business from both public and private
sector partners. We believe that by understanding bid briefs and being agile and resourceful in delivering on the
land vendors’ requirements, we make ourselves an attractive partner. Our largest source of land (currently
representing approximately 79% of our land) are our partnerships with the public sector, typically Homes England
and Local Authorities, with whom we have formed strong relationships and strategic private partners, with whom
we achieve a high proportion of repeat business. We also source land from the private sector through our regional
contacts with individual land owners and land agents (which currently represent approximately 21% of our land).

With both public and private partners, our participation in a partnership development may be structured
in several ways, each of which is intended to provide a blend of risk and return appropriate to the land being
acquired. Certain arrangements may require us to acquire the land being developed (sometimes in phases). Other
arrangements may grant us with development rights while the original land owner retains ownership of the site
and ultimately transfers completed units directly to the home purchaser. In some instances, we may also enter into
joint ventures with partners to secure exclusive development rights over large scale land holdings, with our longest
running joint venture lasting over 25 years. The timelines from identification of a site to beginning its development
can vary widely from as little as 12 months to two years or longer, and then the development phase can last for a
number of years depending on size and complexity of the project.

Public-sector land is usually brought to market through a competitive tender process, determined by the
“Find a Tender Service” (“FTS”) (previously the Official Journal of the European Union (“OJEU”)) process,
which governs how the public sector disposes of its land assets and procures development services. In the case of
Homes England, disposals are currently effected through the DPP (currently DPP3), of which we are a member.
Historically, being a member of DPP3 has reduced the number of competitors that we have competed with to
secure large scale public land opportunities, providing us with access to development sites typically unavailable
to housebuilders who are not members of DPP3. However, Homes England launched its successor to the DPP,
the DPDPS, on September 1, 2021, which has been designed to modernize the bidding process through the use of
a digital platform which encourages new entrants to the market, and thereby simplifies the process for
housebuilders to join the list of preferred developers and bid for land. We have submitted an application to be a
member of the DPDPS and have received confirmation of our membership on the panel. With this new system,


-----

housebuilders will still have to ‘qualify’ to be able to join the list of preferred developers, but they will be able to
apply to join at any time, rather than only upon renewal of the delivery partner panel once every four years, as is
currently the case.

The public procurement process is a formal, complex and sometimes lengthy process, which, along with
the regeneration aspect of most public-sector land and the pricing dynamics of the affordable housing market,
deters some larger housebuilders from competing for these opportunities. However, our significant experience
with developments of this type and deep knowledge of the financial dynamics and the requirements of these public
sector partners allows us to navigate this process efficiently and effectively.

We often begin preparations for a scheme bid well before we receive formal notification of a project.
Land purchased through the public sector will generally involve multiple phases over an extended timeframe. The
typical process and indicative timeframe is as follows:

**Timeline** **Activity**
Month 0 Release of site for sale / notification of project
Month 2 Submission of an expression of interest
Month 3 Shortlisting by vendor / invitation to tender sent
Month 6 Submission of bid document
Month 8 Formal presentation / bid interviews
Month 10 Clarification sessions
Month 9-12 Appointment of preferred developer partner
Month 17-18 Entry into binding contract
Month 24 Planning consent received
Month 24-28 Finalize land value and legal completion

Vendors in the public sector decide between developer bids according to set, published scheme criteria
and a scoring matrix. The bid assessment criteria often include land value, quality of design, use of modern
methods of construction (“MMC”) and socio-economic elements (including the use of local supply chains and
training and apprenticeship opportunities). A housebuilder’s reputation and track record of delivery will also be a
consideration in awarding large scale regeneration projects. The criteria are usually broken down into specific
categories, with scores and weightings attached to each. Therefore, developers are generally aware of how bids
will be assessed before they are submitted. For example, Homes England typically assesses scheme bids against
two core categories, with 50% of the weighting attributed to the financial offer and 50% attributed to design and
social value. Local authorities often more evenly weigh the financial offer, design and social value. We tailor our
bids in accordance with the bidding criteria that is released for each project, and we believe that we enjoy a
significant advantage against many competing bidders by virtue of our deep understanding of the public
procurement process, combined with our experience and track record of delivering notable regeneration and
development projects aligning with the social goals of public sector partners.

Public bodies generally focus on disposing of brownfield land, which typically has lower land value and
can therefore provide a greater potential upside upon development (depending on regeneration costs). This
contributes to our relatively low average land cost of approximately 11% of sales.

Private sector land is often brought to the market through the owner or a land agent working with the
owner. We also identify site opportunities directly through land searches and planning leads. These provide the
potential for off-market deals where one-on-one negotiation may take place. In both cases, we conduct an initial
assessment to filter out opportunities and compete only for those where we believe we have a high chance of
successfully securing the site. We have strong relationships with a small number of national private sector land
owners with whom we do repeat business, as well as with a number of land agents. The strength of these
relationships, which are based on a mutual track record of delivery and understanding of business drivers, has
been instrumental in our ability to secure large scale, capital light deals with private sector vendors.

In those cases where we are successful in our bid for a project, we are appointed as the preferred
developer and each other party will work towards signing a binding contract while we complete additional due
diligence, as described below.

_Approval Process and Due Diligence_

Once a potential development opportunity has been identified, we follow a clearly defined due diligence
process before we finalize any land purchase. We have a controlled and disciplined internal land acquisition


-----

approval process, working within defined control gateways with extensive senior executive review. Our approval
process can be divided into three stages:

     - _Stage 1 — The “Pre-Bid Capital Expenditure” Proposal: This stage occurs prior to the_
submission of a formal bid or offer for a land parcel, and is intended to establish the financial
suitability of an opportunity. The proposal sets out the nature of the opportunity, including scale
and scope, and considers the opportunity against our targeted returns for gross margin and
ROCE. These target financial returns are then used as benchmarks in stages 2 and 3 of the
process (as described below). Our regional teams, led by the regional managing director,
complete the “Pre-Bid Capital Expenditure” proposal and present it to the Divisional Chairman
for approval. Homes England bids also require approval from the Group Development Director.
There is very limited expenditure incurred at this stage of the majority of bids. Approval of a
Stage 1 proposal allows the region to perform more detailed planning, design, technical and
legal due diligence, as described in Stage 2 below.

     - _Stage 2 — “Capital Expenditure 1” Proposal: This stage is completed before we enter into a_
contract to purchase or develop a site. A region commissions a suite of reports to facilitate the
formulation of a plan to develop the site. The due diligence undertaken by the region to prepare
a “Capital Expenditure 1” proposal includes:

(i) _Land — legal reports and reports on title;_

(ii) _Technical — planning reports, geo-technical (ground) reports, surveys (topographical_
and environments) and design (architectural and engineering working);

(iii) _Sales — market research reports;_

(iv) _Commercial — cost estimates and validation; and_

(v) _Construction — health and safety assessments, environmental assessments and_
programs to facilitate the accurate appraisal of a site.

The focus is on identifying the key constraints (including sustainability constrains), risks and
mitigation plans for the site, embedding them into the site appraisal and ensuring it still delivers
in line with the threshold returns expected for gross margin and ROCE. The costs incurred as
part of this stage include the design work by the architects and engineers, geotechnical work,
surveys, solicitors fees and other consultants fees.

The regional team presents this proposal to our Capex Committee, which comprises our Chief
Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, Group Production Director and Group Development
Director, and which is supported by our legal team. Our Capex Committee reviews the scheme’s
risk profile against the anticipated returns and cohesion of the regions plan while assessing the
site for approval to proceed to exchange of contract. Approval is also required from the relevant
Divisional Chairman and the Divisional Finance Director. Once Stage 2 approval is obtained,
our legal team authorizes our panel solicitors to exchange contracts to purchase or develop a
site.

      - _Stage 3 — “Capital Expenditure 2” Proposal: This stage is completed before we commence_
construction of the site. It reflects the completion of our pre-development due-diligence process,
presenting the region’s final proposal to deliver the site, including the financial returns the
region is committing to deliver (gross margin and ROCE). It reviews the final position on the
land contract conditions, other legal matters, final details of the deal, technical constraints,
latent risk and mitigation plan, breakdown of the site start budget build cost, a construction plan,
a sales plan confirming values and volume (with updated independent market research) and the
final profit output and cash requirements of the proposal. At this stage, planning consent has
been granted and most, if not all, of the technical approvals have been obtained. Additionally,
we will have already tendered the construction work, providing more cost certainty prior to
commencing the development of the site . The regional team present this proposal to our Capex
Committee for approval, along with approval from the Divisional Chairman and Divisional
Finance Director.


-----

Each region within the Group has land, technical, commercial, construction and sales functions to
undertake (directly or through consultants) all of the pre-development due-diligence when assessing a site for
acquisition. The technical function has overall responsibility for the ground, design, planning, utilities and
environmental investigations. The nature, scale and assessed risk of a scheme and land deal, will determine the
extent of the investigation undertaken, The work undertaken by consultants in high-risk areas, including geotechnical and groundworks areas, is peer-reviewed by other panel consultants to ensure we have identified the
extent of any risk and to ensure that we have robust mitigation plans to protect our financial returns.

Examples of the due diligence work that we undertake during our land acquisition approval process
include:

     - full schedule of technical fees to undertake land due diligence;

     - planning consultation with Local Authorities and planning consultants to establish policy and
requirements;

     - establishing site boundaries and legal ownership;

     - topography of the site;

     - conducting site access checks with the land registry and highways authority;

     - establishing the full requirements to develop the site, including remediation, foundation types,
roads and sewers design and drainage connections and requirements;

     - conducting a full utilities trace which includes gas, water, electrical and communications
equipment using ground penetrating radar; and

     - conducting engineering appraisals such as current drains and site requirements.

The technical planning process is detailed and aimed at avoiding and minimizing risk when construction
teams are on site. Following technical due diligence, the scheme will be packaged, tendered and costed for
submission as described with respect to Stage 3 as described above.

_Agreement of Development Framework and Objectives_

With respect to our partnership developments, after being selected as preferred developer we begin to
negotiate with our partner an agreement laying out the basic framework of our relationship in each development.
Typically, the framework agreement outlines terms applicable for the drawdown of land (sometimes on a phased
basis), funding sources, the development timeframe, development milestones, permissible types of development,
land price, land payment timing and the overage share, where applicable.

We will then refine the objectives of our development with our partners. With Local Authorities, this
usually entails neighborhood transformation through mixed-tenure housing construction and sometimes other
community facilities. We are able to offer our partners a wide range of housing designs to suit their different needs
and can tailor our developments to meet specific goals, such as space standards, tenure, sustainability and
affordability.

_Project Execution_

Land Acquisition and Construction

The ways in which we secure development opportunities may require us to acquire the land being
developed (sometimes in phases), or otherwise we may be granted with development rights while the original land
owner retains ownership of the site and ultimately transfers completed units directly to the home purchaser.

Our developments predominantly utilize the partnership model, although we from time to time acquire
land in speculative deals where we believe that we can achieve attractive financial returns by developing the land
on our own. These private developments may sometimes shift to partnership arrangements during the course of
development, for example, by entering into an agreement with a Registered Provider during the course of
development rather than at the outset.


-----

Our North West MCI region has a different, but complementary operating model to our other regions.
The North West MCI region, which became a part of our business following our acquisition of MCI in 2017,
works exclusively with Registered Providers. The North West MCI region sources land in much the same way as
our other regions, but agrees to deals whereby a Registered Provider buys the site and also pays us to build homes
on the site through build contracts. The Registered Providers pay in advance for the land and progressively for the
construction of the homes, resulting in a model with minimal working capital requirements and substantially
removing the land and sales risk. Our other regions may also enter into similar arrangements with Registered
Providers to deliver all homes on a site to that provider. This typically happens if we have a commercially
attractive offer from the Registered Provider and can generate both a requisite gross margin and an attractive
ROCE, with the Registered Provider funding both the land and build WIP.

Once land is acquired or secured for development, we commence construction, with a focus on realistic
build programs, product and process standardization and a focus on quality at each stage of the build. Standardized
designs allow us to achieve design and building efficiencies while helping to maintain quality control and
simplifying compliance with relevant building requirements. We seek to leverage our scale and procurement
capabilities to deliver homes reliably and manage costs appropriately, utilizing rigorous “cost to complete”
meetings to maintain control on costs throughout the process. Our construction team is responsible for the delivery
of the build process on site to ensure it meets the required safety, quality and program requirements. Sites are
appropriately resourced with experienced management teams to ensure the construction phase runs smoothly at
each site. Infrastructure work is carefully programmed to optimize ROCE.

Quality is a top priority for our business, and all supporting design detailing, workmanship and material
specifications have been developed to embody good practice and simplification. These specifications, created in
collaboration with all departments and subcontractor forums, are used at all stages of our design, procurement and
subcontractor appointment processes. They are embedded in our quality training programs and site inductions and
are also used as build quality checks. We have a formal inspection and sign off process that allows us to benchmark
our build quality, consisting of an internal quality inspection process and external NHBC key stage inspections.
Alongside this, we have produced a series of best practice guides for our site teams to ensure that our homes meet
the required standard and comply with our detailed trade specifications. Customer satisfaction is supported by our
inspection process, which drives our culture of keeping customers as the key focus of our business.

Sustainability is also one of our key focus areas in terms of our approach to construction. Our sustainable
construction practices include the utilization of timber-frame construction (accounting for 12% of homes
completed in each of the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020), the integration of digital and
standardized designs which increase our ability to use offsite manufactured components, improved site efficiency,
control of waste, and a modular homes partnership with ilke Homes. See “—Environment and Sustainability”
below for further detail. Our core house type range is designed using Building Information Modelling (“BIM”).
BIM is used to create house types using digital 3D models which facilitate simpler design, scheduling, cost
estimating, programming, construction, sales visualizations, and sharing with partners and consultants (such as
architects, engineers, community groups and planners). Certain house types designed and built using BIM further
support improved efficiency, waste reduction and collaboration with our third-party designers. Our core house
types accounted for 85% of all homes that we delivered in the financial year ended October 31, 2020.

Additionally, we have been at the forefront in the use of MMC. These methods, which we believe are
particularly well suited for high-volume developments, range from whole homes being constructed with factorybuilt volumetric modules to the use of componentized elements in the construction process. In Scotland, timber
frames are used exclusively, whereas at other of our sites, they are used selectively where required in the bid brief.
Furthermore, we look to integrate off-site manufactured components, such as roof and floor cassettes, which
minimize waste and on-site processes within a traditional build. We have a strong understanding of MMC and
make use of this in testing new technology and exploring and responding to demand for MMC-built homes on our
sites.

Standardization

We focus on building homes from our standard house type range, with over 75% of our homes completed
in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 being standard types. Standardization, and in particular a “Standard
House Type Range” contribute to design and building efficiencies and quality control, as well as simplifying
compliance with relevant building requirements.

We utilize a clearly defined standard house type range that enables our business to benefit from
standardization while facilitating flexibility to adapt both internal levels of specification and external elevations.


-----

We apply standardized elevation and specification detailing in order to adapt to local planning design guides and
regional market expectations. Standardization leads to less risk and greater cost predictability, while different
exterior designs provide us with the flexibility to adapt to the local vernacular.

The following charts shows the percentage of homes built by us that have used standardized designs
during each of the years indicated below:

We utilize a number of core standard design types as set out below:

     - _Open Market Sale Homes: these homes are designed to meet the needs of open market sales_
customers, and are focused on keeping homes affordable while optimizing land use and
profitability. This is the default setting when planning a site, unless partners specify different,
larger space standards.

     - _Design Quality Standards Homes (“DQS”): this is a house type of range aligned to an older_
design code, still preferred by some Registered Providers, which is larger than the “Open Market
Sale Homes” range. These homes are designed for social rent at full occupancy. Homes built in
accordance with these standards adhere to enhanced space standards for circulation, internal
storage and specific minimum furniture layouts.

     - _Nationally Designed Space Standards Homes (“NDSS”): this is a house type range aligned to_
the Nationally Described Space Standards, representing a larger internal space standard, which
is available for adoption by Local Authorities. NDSS homes are subject to local plan viability
testing and approval by the planning inspectorate. These homes are deemed suitable across all
tenures defined by the level of occupancy and were introduced to supersede DQS.

     - _Mobility Standards Homes: this house type range meets a higher level of accessibility and_
incorporates adaptability to address future mobility requirements for occupants. These homes
typically include wider doors, enlarged circulation spaces and ground floor washrooms which
are sized and serviced for future conversion into a ground floor shower room.

     - _Scottish Homes: these homes are developed to meet the Scottish building regulation and space_
standards.

Our use of standardization provides us with a number of benefits, including the following:

     - increased efficiency resulting in reduced pre-development time scales and professional fees;

     - improved cost certainty, construction program certainty and accuracy of land feasibility
analysis;

     - standard details promoting best practices for quality, safety and precise material scheduling,
which in turn reduces waste;

     - standard finishes specification enabling forward demand planning, purchase leveraging and
rebate maximization;

     - improved quality resulting in enhanced customer satisfaction and a reduction in aftercare costs;


-----

     - strong brand creation and the sharing of marketing assets between sites and regions;

     - repeat delivery supporting the efficiencies of our supply chain from tender to completion; and

     - streamlined incorporation of new regulatory standards and considerations into future project
designs.

Our approach to standardization is developed based on internal feedback for saleability and buildability,
customer feedback, commercial viability, and land optimization. Furthermore, trade specifications have been
developed to support the delivery of our homes to promote quality and safety in build and occupation.

Design and Place-Making

We have a proven track record of revitalizing communities through the delivery of high-quality,
affordable homes, in well-designed and well-connected neighborhoods and we believe that our focus on design
quality and place-making helps drive our success in planning applications and sales performance.

We actively contribute to the NHBC Standard Review Group and other industry working groups to help
ensure our design, detailing and specification represent best practices and are aligned to future change.
Fundamental to our design principals is the creation of a sense of inclusion and community through the delivery
of new homes of mixed tenures in attractive, regenerative environments that complement existing local areas and
promote health and well-being. We consider the unique characteristics of each site and its surroundings and seek
to incorporate and enhance existing natural landscape features and habitat to create a sense of place. Design guides
support the use of the house types and elevational styles in delivering the principles of good place making. For
example, strong street scenes, gateway access blocks, urban squares, overlooked public realm and vista stoppers
can all be efficiently achieved using the standard range of houses. Our design model ultimately creates an attractive
living space while maximizing development density.

Pursuant to our partnership model, we engage with Local Authorities and other partners at an early stage
to create design schemes that are acceptable to our local community and help to shape the social and community
infrastructure provided in the area. Early planning and clear design and construction briefs for a regeneration site
are particularly important to set a distinctive sense of place and the tone for the partnership with the local
community. We also engage with communities at early stage regarding regeneration schemes to engender local
support in both a political sense and from the community directly. We believe that our reputation for design and
related collaborative working relationships with regeneration stakeholders are important factors that land owners
and their advisers consider when considering us as a development partner.

We strive to innovate and develop our designs to suit the requirements of all of our customers, including
first-time buyers, families, social housing partners, supported housing providers, and the elderly. Our designs
include enhanced mobility standards, where required, to support the needs of both able-bodied and disabled
people. In certain situations, the design of new homes has been adapted to include special features to support the
customer in their daily routine, for example including a lift, a bathroom with a lifting hoist and wider doors to
allow for a wheelchair user to be able to easily access all areas of the home and garden. While tailoring designs
in order to meet the needs of the customers is a focus of ours, we are also committed to ensuring the homes that
we design are commercially optimized with respect to house type profitability, plot profitability and development
density. The house type range that we’ve established creates a balanced mix of designs to foster generational and
social diversity, support good place making and deliver plotting efficiency.

We recognize the key role that commercial and other non-residential buildings and amenities (including
neighborhood centers, retail space and schools) contribute to creating vibrant communities. Although our core
business does not involve the development of these buildings and amenities, these are typically developed or
delivered by third parties, and many of our brownfield developments are anchored around existing commercial
and non-residential buildings and amenities. We are committed to building stable, sustainable, diverse and
balanced communities, which have at their core an integration of public space, landscaping, biodiversity and
sustainable drainage systems.

Procurement and Supply

We widely employ sub-contractors to build our homes, both for the purposes of efficiency and as part of
our commitment to supporting local communities. Because of the fragmented nature of the market in which subcontracting firms operate, we typically work with local small-and medium-sized enterprises instead of national


-----

companies. Prior to appointing sub-contractors, we pre-qualify them in line with the PAS 91 standardized
questionnaire, through the use of a third party assessment provider. Each sub-contractor is assessed across a range
of areas covering, among other items, health and safety, insurances, environmental, quality management, antibribery and corruption, financial standing, modern slavery and equal opportunities. Sub-contractors submit
tenders based on the house type and design specifications, at which point we then compare the tender quotes
against the appraisal and standard regional costs. Sub-contractors operate under our Keepmoat brand and our
health and safety (“H&S”) team provides them with advice and support and monitors compliance with regulatory
and best practice standards. We work continuously with sub-contractors to ensure a high-quality of product is
delivered at a competitive cost base.

We employ a diversified range of sub-contractors, which limits our exposure to individual sub-contractor
risk and provides more downside protection and flexibility than a direct labor force.

The construction and delivery of homes involves a substantial supply chain. We operate an advanced
centralized procurement process to minimize lead time and construction delay, obtain quota guarantees and
negotiate fair payment terms. Our materials supply-chain strategy is typically underpinned by annual, Group-wide
deals with suppliers with a national, regional or local coverage. This enables us to negotiate better commercial
terms through our consolidated volume and enables the utilization of volume-related rebates. We procure all
material components centrally and have no sole supply agreements on any key materials. Our supply strategy is
delivered through our supply chain director, who is supported by experienced commercial teams employed by us
to manage our material supply chain and sub-contractor relationships. Our subcontractors are responsible for
providing and installing a proportion of the materials required to build a house.

Our suppliers play an essential role in our business, providing the materials and services that we use to
build homes. Our business requires substantial amounts of construction materials, including bricks and blocks, in
addition to construction and equipment and waste disposal services. We believe that maintaining a high-quality
supplier base that is fully aligned to our values is critical to support our growth. Consequently, we seek to maintain
a close partner-based relationship with local supply chains. This approach encourages face-to-face engagement
with our suppliers to maintain core standards and to continuously improve quality, safety, service, innovation and
cost competitiveness.

We operate a series of group-wide, long-term strategic frameworks providing preferential commercial
terms and service levels at a national and regional level to supply the requisite services, materials, site equipment
and business consumables. These frameworks capture both direct purchases of supplies by us and indirect
purchases of supplies, which we specify for use, by our contractors, offering significant pricing advantages, while
also including important delivery, service and product warranties which helps us maintain and improve our quality
and service to our customers. Our “Supply Chain Team” manages over 97 arrangements, which include framework
agreements, commercial arrangements and formal price lists. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 88%
of our direct spend was channeled through these frameworks.

Our supply frameworks align with the Keepmoat Homes Standard Specification and opportunities to
work closely with suppliers to assess new products and technologies to support our drive for standardization (for
example, using roof and floor cassettes to simplify, speed up, make safer aspects of construction, while reducing
the amount of waste). Our supply frameworks also provide customer care and product warranty support to our
customer services teams, with many providing value engineering support, free site surveys and scheduling and
pricing services. Additionally, our supply frameworks reduce business risk and help ensure a secure supply of our
essential materials. We work hard to mitigate price increases and to ensure that our agreements are always
competitive and provide the best quality without compromising on standards. Many of our framework agreements
include rebate agreements.

We maintain regular contact with suppliers and manufacturers to ensure continuity of supply, and
negotiate our product allocations by volume. The availability of materials is secured in line with demand and we
carefully manage the supply of our key products, including bricks and plasterboard, by working with our regional
businesses and our supply chain partners. We engage with our suppliers to keep them informed of key forecasting
information, providing them with a rolling build program on a monthly basis, in addition to product specific
demand schedules. We also notify our supply chain of any changes to our working practices as appropriate.

**_Marketing and Sales_**

We have regional sales teams that are supported by a centralized marketing team. These teams collaborate
with our partners and local communities throughout a development’s lifecycle, from inception to viability
assessment, planning applications and infrastructure planning and then construction and completion. Our central
marketing team is responsible for branding, corporate literature, digital support and public relations. It also
operates our social media platforms, produces sales and marketing literature, promotes our developments and
works towards strengthening our brand identity. As of July 31, 2020, we had two employees in our central
marketing team.

We utilize a number of typical marketing strategies, including the following:

     - targeted social media advertising aimed at our core market demographics, using Facebook and
Instagram, focusing on key locations identified in our market research;

     - advertising in suitable local and professional publications, aimed at our core market;

     - local advertising on bus routes and using digital platforms at stations near sites;

     - development and house type brochures available in our onsite marketing suites;

     - informative brochures and advertising explaining the “Shared Equity” and Help to Buy
schemes, available in our marketing suite and through online and postal mail shots, as well as
print, online and social media;

     - first-time buyer clinic events;

     - first-time buyer and drop-in sessions arranged with large local employers and held at their
premises and coupled with potential incentives for employees of these organizations; and

     - an “Easymove” facility to help customers with the sales process of their existing home.

Our regional sales teams operate out of our sales outlets, of which we had 56 outlets operating as of July
31, 2021. Regional sales teams are overseen by sales managers, who maintain a detailed understanding of the
local real estate market and trends. Members of our sales teams are generally present at our active sales outlets
and guide buyers through the home buying process. Our sales outlets are typically open five days per week, with
sites in certain high demand areas being open seven days per week. We directly recruit, employ and train our sales


-----

executives to deliver their sales services to our specific target customer demographics. As of July 31, 2021, we
had 145 employees in our regional sales teams.

Our sales teams are supported by our digital sales capabilities, which have taken on increased importance
in recent years. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, we opened eight digital sales offices. We also
secured 1,254 online reservations through our digital sales offices and our “Reserve Online” tool in the same
financial year, which was equivalent to approximately 50% of our completions in the period.

The typical process and timeframe for a house sale is as follows:

     - _Site visits (week 0): at this stage, the customer typically undertakes multiple visits to the site to_
review the development and the available housing choices;

     - _Preliminary credit assessment (weeks 1-4): at this stage, the customer has narrowed down his_
or her interest. Our sales team refers the customer to an independent financial advisor to make
a preliminary credit assessment and evaluate mortgage eligibility;

     - _Reservation (week 4): the customer reserves the property and pays a nominal fee;_

     - _Exchange contracts (weeks 12-14): at this stage, the customer typically instructs a solicitor to_
undertake the conveyancing work, progresses the mortgage application and enters into a
contract for the purchase; and

     - _Legal completion (week 24-26): the customer completes the purchase and moves in, after the_
house is built and inspected for quality.

We pursue a sales strategy that blends the potential for margin enhancement through open-market sales
with the certainty, risk mitigation and cash generation of selling to Registered Providers. In the financial year
ended October 31, 2020, 74% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as
well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a site) and 26% to
Registered Providers as part of the Section 106 affordable housing obligations agreed in connection with the
planning consents required for our sites or as otherwise agreed with Registered Providers at the outset of
development. In comparison, in the financial year ended October 31, 2019, we sold 78% of our plots in the open
market and 22% to Registered Providers.

Open market sales are delivered primarily through our sales team, who are present at each site. We
typically design a sales area, including a sales office and show homes, to present a shop-window of how the site
will look once developed. We look to open these sales areas as early as possible in the development of our sites
to allow customers to experience what they may eventually purchase.

Conversely, sales to Registered Providers are agreed at the time of the planning process, pursuant to our
Section 106 obligations, in accordance with an authority’s affordable-housing policy. Through our strong
relationship with national and local Registered Providers we are able to agree commercially-driven elective sales
to Registered Providers subsequent to the initial planning stage, which serves an important tool in maintaining
sales flexibility throughout the life of the site. These sales are often only at a small discount to open market prices
as they benefit from grants or other funding (such as Affordable Homes Programme funding).

Although a relatively small proportion of our business, we treat private rental sector (“PRS”) sales as
complementary to our open-market and Registered Provider sales. PRS sales are location sensitive as they only
work on commercially acceptable terms in areas with strong rental demand and rental values. We discuss PRS
sales with our partners and seek to devise sales strategies on a site-by-site basis.

We completed sales for a total of 2,774 homes, 2,460 homes and 4,035 homes in the nine months ended
July 31, 2021, the financial year ended October 31, 2020 and the financial year ended October 31, 2019,
respectively.

As of July 31, 2021, our forward order book, which represents (i) plots that are contracted for but homes
have yet to be completed on the lot and (ii) plot reservations for which contracts have yet to be exchanged, was
approximately £503.2 million, comprising of 3,151 plots.

As of September 19, 2021, we had reserved, exchanged or legally completed almost all of our planned
sales for the financial year ending October 31, 2021. Furthermore, as of September 19, 2021, we had secured


-----

approximately 40% of our planned sales for the year ended October 31, 2022, 85% of our planned sales for the

**_Cancellations_**

Once a customer has reserved a property, identified the particular home they want and paid a reservation
fee, they still have the option to cancel their reservation and receive a refund if they choose to withdraw from the
sale. The customer may cancel at any time before the exchange of contracts, and if they have purchased through
the Help to Buy scheme and have cancelled within ten calendar days of the reservation, they will be entitled to a
full refund of their reservation fee. Otherwise, the customer will be refunded the reservation fee less administrative
costs of £125. Once contracts have been exchanged, the customer may only serve notice to cancel the sale if (i)
we have not served the completion notice (confirming the date on which completion will take place) before the
long stop date specified in the sale contract; or (ii) we have made substantial changes to the property that were not
agreed in advance by the customer. If the purchaser does not serve notice to cancel where the property is not ready
and the completion notice has not been served by the relevant long stop date, then we may continue to build the
property, concluding as soon as reasonably practicable, and the customer must complete the purchase. If the
customer fails to complete the purchase on the completion date (once such date has been set), we may provide ten
days’ notice to complete the purchase, following which we will have the right to rescind the contract if the
customer still fails to complete the purchase. If we are to exercise our right of rescission, we may retain the deposit
and any accrued interest, claim damages if applicable and re-sell the property. If we fail to complete our
performance under the contract before expiry of the notice, then the customer has the right to rescind the contract
and to the return of their deposit.

**Our Customers and Customer Experience**

We have a diverse customer base, and in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 75% of our sales
were on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as well as elective sales to Registered
Providers that are agreed during the development of a site) and 25% to Registered Providers as part of the Section
106 affordable housing obligations agreed in connection with the planning consents required for our sites or as
otherwise agreed with Registered Providers at the outset of development.

First-time buyers are one of our key demographics, representing 76% of our private sales in the financial
year ended October 31, 2020. First-time buyers with the benefit of financial support schemes from the Government
have historically proven to provide resilient structural demand and constitute a deep and relatively predictable
market. First-time buyers are typically “need to buy” customers, in that they are experiencing life events such as

private sale customers aged 35 or younger (based on statistics from a survey of 1,053 customers in the financial
year ended October 31, 2020). We generally do not have large exposure to customers in any particular occupation,
implying a well-diversified customer economic exposure. In terms of the way that our customers finance their
purchases, based on statistics from the same survey in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, approximately
68% of our private sale customers utilized the Help to Buy scheme, 30% were unassisted and 1% utilized the
Affordable Homes Programme.
