### Strategic Report 

 Chief Executive’s Strategic Update

I was delighted to take over the role of Chief Executive Officer at Keepmoat Homes in February 2019 and to be given the opportunity to
steer the business through its next phase of growth and development. The last 12 months have been a truly transformational period for
Keepmoat Homes which has seen us focus on establishing a strong management team and creating a high-performance culture where
our people feel valued and empowered to deliver success. This was recognised through our recent Investors In People (IIP) Audit, where
our assessor, who has been involved with Keepmoat Homes for a number of years, paid tribute to the remarkable turnaround in the
business describing it in his report as ‘huge and quite amazing’ in terms of the enormity of change and the level of progress and
commitment in a relatively short period of time. We still have more to do, as these changes have not yet permeated every area of the
business, but I am confident that we are now in a very strong position moving forward.

I believe that we now have the right people in the right roles and I am extremely proud of the management structure we have created
which has enabled us to deliver an outstanding result in the financial year to 31 October 2019. We have increased our revenues by 8.8%
to £649.8m and delivered 4,035 high quality new homes for our customers.

As we move in to FY20 and a period of increased stability following months of political uncertainty, I am pleased to say that the market
for quality new homes is strong and is particularly favourable, following the recent general election, in Keepmoat Homes’ northern
heartland.

This is also supported by the continued availability of mortgage products that help people get on to the property ladder by making it more
affordable to buy than rent. This is key to our core First Time Buyer market. In the last financial year 70% of our Open Market Sales
were to First Time Buyers and they will continue to be a focus for the business moving forward.

Delivering high quality new homes and delighting our customers is our top priority, so I am pleased to say that in the 12-month reporting
period, Keepmoat Homes increased its customer satisfaction score to 87.4% which is sufficient to achieve a 4-star builder status across
the business and I am confident that this will increase to 5-star in early 2020.

Our current score of 87.7% in the 2019 Home Builders Federation (HBF) annual customer satisfaction survey is a 12% improvement on
our 2018 result and a 15% improvement on our 2017 result.

**A regional focus on national delivery**

Keepmoat Homes is committed to delivering high-quality, affordable homes across the UK, with 11 regional businesses organised into
three divisions: Scotland and North West; North East and Yorkshire; and Midlands and South. The regional businesses and their
boundaries will remain flexible allowing for growth and expansion into new areas where this makes sense and is required to enable all
offices to remain at an optimum size for effective management.

A Divisional Chairman is responsible for each of the three divisions, supported by a Divisional Finance Director. Each of the regional
businesses has its own management board and is empowered to deliver our overarching business excellence strategy, applying the
Group’s policies and systems to local markets and circumstances. This structure and approach means that we are well positioned for
future growth in the right locations.

Over the past twelve months we have concentrated on operational excellence, introducing greater rigour to manage our sites holistically
to fully optimise our development economics over the full life of the site. With enhanced financial processes and reporting, this enables
us to ensure we are buying land with the right margins and in the right locations. As a result, we are well positioned to deliver shareholder
value and delight our customers by building more of the high-quality homes they deserve, in the places they want to live.

**The Strength of our Partnership Business Model**

Our partnership business model is what sets us apart from our competitors. It gives us the ability to secure land on a capital light basis
by negotiating deferred or staged payments, delivering an excellent return on capital and creating a lower risk business model.

We establish and maintain deep enduring relationships with both private and public-sector land owners many of which have lasted for
over 20 years.

We are the largest delivery partner of Homes England and are delivering over 13,000 homes in partnership with them as a member of
consecutive Delivery Partner Panels since 2009, accessing over £177m in funding initiatives. We have used the Home Building Fund to
accelerate the delivery of 2,200 homes and Help to Buy to support the ambitions of 70% of our homebuyers.

We have built our reputation by aligning our approach with our partners’ objectives to deliver successful, large scale, mixed-tenure,
developments. We have a proven track record of revitalising communities through the delivery of high quality homes, in well-designed
and well-connected neighbourhoods and at prices that our customers can afford. Over the last 25 years we have successfully delivered
new homes in some of the country’s most challenging housing markets, demonstrating our commitment to delivery even in the most
demanding market conditions.

### Strategic Report 

 Chief Executive’s Strategic Update

Our partnership approach delivers many advantages including:

- An ability to deliver large scale multi-phased development sites, providing a strong forward pipeline of land

- The opportunity to work with partners who are motivated not only by financial returns, but also by non-financial outcomes (including

   - accelerated delivery, social value and design quality);

- The potential to access grant funding or investment support from Homes England and Local Authority partners; and

- The opportunity to secure repeat business from existing partners and landowners, or to generate new business opportunities on
the strength of our track record and reputation for delivery.

**Community and Stakeholder Engagement**

Our extensive experience and commitment to stakeholder engagement underpins our partnership approach and demonstrates a strong
commitment to working with communities and involving local people at all stages of neighbourhood projects. We recognise the
importance of exploring local needs and making sure all voices are heard to deliver real improvements to our developments. We actively
support our partners in the development and implementation of stakeholder engagement strategies, working proactively to ensure that
lines of communication are developed and maintained and that we develop the right approach.

**Placing our Customers at the Heart of Our Business**

Customer satisfaction is at the heart of everything we do. Ensuring our customers are supported throughout their journey with us, meeting
their expectations and providing them with a high quality new home is extremely important to us.

We regularly review our processes and continually strive to introduce further improvements and deliver greater levels of customer service
and satisfaction. We include all regional management teams in this process to ensure all improvements are delivered consistently across
our entire business.

We have introduced a bespoke quality inspection process “Hallmark”, and best practice guidance and we ensure that our teams receive
regular training on our systems and understand the importance we place on delighting our customers.

We maintain close contact with our customers throughout their journey with us, from their initial enquiry, during the exciting process of
purchasing one of our properties and after moving into their new home to ensure they consistently receive a high level of service.

We also participate in the National House Building Council (NHBC) customer satisfaction survey, we monitor every survey and reflect
on the comments and use this feedback to learn and improve. It also gives us a means to identify and reward our people who demonstrate
excellence in delivering customer care. In 2020 we will introduce an annual Customer Experience Awards Scheme to recognise the very
best teams at Keepmoat Homes, who are raising the bar and leading the way to achieve ever higher standards.

As a business we are committed to providing our customers with fantastic levels of service, from providing comprehensive information
and guidance on their new home to dealing with issues and queries quickly and efficiently.

What matters to our customers:

- A home delivered on time, to the right quality, that is great value for money;

- Great service both during and after the purchase;

- An environment that has been created to provide great amenities and green space;

- A community that they can enjoy and thrive in; and

- Knowing that the development has contributed to the wider community and considered and supported a positive environmental
impact.

**Government commitment to housing supply**

We welcome the ongoing cross-party consensus on the importance of housebuilding and the particular focus and support from all the
main political parties on building more affordable homes during the 2019 General Election. In addition, the Government continues to
support new home building with the extension of Help to Buy until 2023, albeit with reforms restricting the scheme to support First Time
Buyers from 2021 onwards. We welcome these reforms which will ensure that funding is available to the people who need it most. We
believe Help to Buy is a successful scheme that has supported new development whilst helping more people to buy a new home.

The operating environment has been uncertain for three years due to the UK’s decision to leave the European Union (EU), with shortterm disruption to existing trade and regulatory arrangements, uncertainty around the long-term relationship with the EU and the potential
political fall-out from a no-deal Brexit. Whilst we recognise the heightened risk profile associated with the Brexit process, Keepmoat
Homes is in a strong position offering affordably priced homes, with a good range and choice of affordable house types available across
our key markets.

Post General Election, the UK now has a degree of political stability but still has a degree of uncertainty regarding a trade agreement
with the EU. Despite this uncertainty, the prevailing economic and political backdrop for the industry is positive. Home ownership is still

### Strategic Report 

 Chief Executive’s Strategic Update

the tenure of choice for the majority of people, and this combined with the long-term undersupply of new housing means that underlying
demand remains strong.

We look forward to the content of the Government’s Planning White Paper in the year ahead, which will be designed to make the planning
process clearer, more accessible and more certain. Further measures are expected in the March Budget, including devolving strategic
planning powers to combined authorities across England, the First Homes initiative and liberalisation of planning regulations in regard
to upwards extensions to properties.

We also support the Government’s initiatives to assist the increase in output from the industry towards its goal of reaching 300,000 new
homes built each year, across multiple tenures, by the mid-2020’s. We remain committed to contributing to this increase in new home
delivery and Keepmoat Homes is well positioned to deliver new developments, with an emphasis on first time buyers and first-time
movers.

The fundamentals of the housing market are sound, with lenders keen to lend at low fixed rates, average wages rising and employment
at a record high. The increase in buyer demand since the General Election would indicate that buyers and sellers feel the election result
has finally provided a window of stability. The alignment of Keepmoat Homes with the ambitions of Government and our public-sector
partners means we are optimistic about our future at the heart of the UK housing market.

**Positive Market Positioning**

The fundamental underpinnings for the UK Housing Market are strong, including Government support, health of mortgage lenders,
constrained supply, general aspiration to own a home, a high level of employment and relatively low interest rates. However, since the
result of the referendum vote to leave the European Union (EU) in June 2016, there has been a significant amount of uncertainty for
business and consumers which has manifested itself differently in different sectors of the housing market.

Fortunately, Keepmoat, with an average sales price of £161,000 and limited exposure to London and the South East has remained
virtually unaffected in the year to 31 October 2019 with sales across all regions remaining healthy and in line with our expectations.
Since the General Election in December 2019 market and customer sentiment has reflected a greater sense of political stability. Despite
this the terms of the future relationship and trade agreements with the EU remain uncertain. Accordingly, the Board has continued to
consider the potential effect on our business and has updated risk assessments. Key risks have been identified, such as the supply and
cost of materials, the impact on availability of labour and potential changes to Government policy and regulation.

The business has appropriate mitigation plans in place to address any adverse impacts should they arise. Most of our building supplies
are manufactured in the UK and are not at risk from future trade arrangements with the EU. An element of the products procured through
our network of UK based suppliers will be imported from the EU and we are working closely with those suppliers to monitor the potential
impact as trade arrangements with the EU are clarified over the coming year. We believe that the Group’s multi-tenure partnership
approach and expertise in the first-time buyer market provides some resilience should any adverse market effects arise.

We will continue to closely monitor market conditions through the coming year considering wider political and economic developments.

**The UK’s leading brownfield homebuilder**

Keepmoat Homes is the UK’s leading brownfield homebuilder, meaning we do more than just deliver new homes. We regenerate urban
and brownfield land to create thriving new communities. 80% of our current developments are on brownfield sites.

We are pleased to see continued support to bringing forward brownfield land from the public sector. Our work with local authorities
across the UK including in Leeds, Sheffield, Rotherham and Glasgow, provides model approaches for others to follow. For example,
through our partnership with Glasgow City Council we will deliver over 800 new homes in the Sighthill area over the next 10 years on
our transformational Northbridge development as part of the council’s commitment to regenerating the north of the city.

**Developing our Product**

Our house type ranges have been developed to improve efficiency in build, quality and safety to ensure we are aligned with regulatory
changes and space standards. This has been informed by customer feedback to reflect lifestyles and deliver affordable high value homes
and brand consistency throughout the business.

The range has been developed to support our partnership model with a high percentage of both two and three bed homes tailored to
meet requirements for a range of tenures.

Whilst we see the standardisation of detailing and components fundamental in supporting improved quality, waste reduction and delivery
targets, we have also introduced flexibility to enable site specific fenestration and expanded the range to enable the principles of good
quality design and place making to be achieved without compromise to profit optimisation.

High levels of standardisation have supported future demand planning, procurement strategies, rebate recovery and contributed to
improved quality and waste management strategies.

Keepmoat actively contributes to the NHBC Standards Review Group and other industry working groups to help ensure our design,
detailing and specification represent best practice and are aligned to future change.

With quality being the key focus of the business, all supporting design detailing, workmanship and material specifications have been

### Strategic Report – Our Vision, Mission and Values

Our vision, mission and values shape our strategy and the way we work, and mean we are a different type of housebuilder. Our corporate
strengths include our local knowledge, long term partner relationships, national and local presence, supply chain and our ability to
enhance local economies by employing local firms and creating local jobs.

**Keepmoat Vision:**

**Building Communities, Transforming lives.**

This means that we think and act beyond bricks and mortar. As well as creating better places for people to live, we know that our
success depends on us playing our part in building the strong communities our partners and customers want.

We work with our partners to regenerate places to improve economic and social outcomes for the local community while providing
housing choice in these areas. We focus on improving the communities we work in and the people we serve, creating significant local
economic benefits through our supply chain and local employment. 8% of our workforce are trainees, apprentices and graduates.

**Keepmoat Mission:**

**We are committed to developing enduring relationships to build more, vibrant new communities at prices our customers can**
**afford.**

Our Mission explains how we are very different from a traditional housebuilder. It’s in what we do, and how we do it. We create long
term partnerships with large organisations who have unused land or properties. Together we build attractive, affordable and high- quality
homes and communities where people want to live, work and play.

We bring together all facets of housing development, including design, planning and community engagement skills, to help partners
achieve their ambitions. We nurture an extensive supply chain of small and medium sized companies that support us around the country
and make that supply chain available to our public and private sector partners.

**Keepmoat Values:**

**Straightforward, Passionate, Collaborative and Creative.**

Our Values support the vision, shape the culture and reflect how we work and behave.

   - Straightforward: We get the job done in the most efficient way. We are friendly, open and honest. In other words, the people

you could trust on any project, large or small.

   - Passionate: We care about what we do. We put pride and energy into delivering results. We give the best, so more people can

enjoy living in safe, happy communities and homes.

   - Collaborative: We work together in partnership to deliver the very best customer experience. By sharing our expertise, we can

build the very best quality new homes.

   - Creative: We are proactive, flexible and resourceful. We listen, learn and deliver solutions.

8

### Strategic Report – Making the most of our strengths

Keepmoat’s existing strengths support our growth ambitions:

**National scale, local understanding. Keepmoat has successfully grown into a large national business with deep local roots and we**
intend to maintain that national and local approach.

**Develop our comprehensive offer. We have a broad set of skills ranging from developing partnerships establishing supply chains,**
building new homes of all tenures and supporting large-scale, housing-led community regeneration schemes.

**Organic growth. In the next five years we intend to increase the number of new homes we build for sale or rent and continue to make**
a significant contribution to meeting the country’s housing needs.

**Market and sector expansion. The need for more housing means we can bring our distinct approach to new markets:**

   - **Grow our core: Our core markets will remain first time buyer homes, and we will continue to work in partnership with local**
authorities and housing associations. We will continue to build our presence in this market.

   - **Enter new geographies: We continue to expand our offer into Scotland, the South West and South of England, where we have**
historically had little presence.

   - **Enter new sectors: We will enter new markets, so more housing opportunities will be created. We are expanding our home**
offer by introducing offsite manufacturing in to our developments and are creating partnerships with financial organisations
combined with our skills and capabilities to create new homes in the private rental sector.

**Leveraging our scale. We have grown mostly by financing and delivering medium sized housing programmes, whether homes for sale**
or new build for rent. Now, our national scale and financial strength together with the breadth of our experience and depth of our skills
and capabilities, means we are delivering a greater number of larger programmes and partnerships as the core part of our business.

**Shape more partnerships. At the heart of our growth will be deeper and broader partnerships with existing and new partners. That**
requires us to understand partners’ challenges and objectives and develop ways to help them meet their goals whether economic growth; social - tackling deprivation, improving health; environmental - reducing carbon consumption; financial - reducing operating
costs; operational - improving customer service; or strategic - developing their housing portfolios.

**Efficiency and effectiveness. As we grow bigger, we risk becoming less agile. Through our model of regional autonomy, we want the**
best of both worlds - being local and agile, almost like a small business can be. But we also want the benefits of being a large business
such as professional rigour, quality, efficiency and effectiveness in winning and delivering work. That means we share what works well
and avoid duplication and unnecessary costs, as our customers expect.

**Building our brand. To build more homes we will need more people to choose to work for us as colleagues or with us as suppliers and**
partners. That means we need to be better understood. Our audiences need to know what we do, how we do it and why we are both
different, and better, than the competition. We are continuing to build our profile with our partners and across the industry, improving
brand position with customers as we move to 4-star and ultimately to 5-star builder status.

**Our Essentials**

Our Essentials are the five basic building blocks of our business.

   - Safety: The safety of people, partners and communities is at the heart of everything we do.

   - Quality: We work to exceed our stakeholders’ expectations of our service, product and delivery.

   - Customer: We focus on delighting our customer.

   - People: Our people are the heart of our business, providing a service we are proud of.

   - Sustainability: We protect the environment, act ethically and leave a positive legacy.

### Strategic Report – Making the most of our strengths

**Customers and Quality**

**Sales specification**

In response to customer feedback trials of super-fast 1GB broadband have been successfully completed during the year. The provision
of superfast broadband with day one connectivity for our customers will now become a standard specification for all future developments.

Smart homes controls are also in trial and positive feedback has led to the development of this technology as part of our sustainable
design solutions.

**West Gorton – Sustainability Trial Manchester**

Manchester City Council and Keepmoat are jointly delivering a pilot scheme to demonstrate innovative and affordable home
energy solutions which combine fabric improvements, smart control technologies, and energy generation with energy storage
to significantly reduce carbon emissions, energy consumption and lower fuel bills. The pilot will deliver valuable learning to
support future delivery of sustainable housing solutions, social value and affordable housing outcomes for the City and promote
a collaborative journey towards a zero-carbon future.

**The proposed pilot aims to deliver the following benefits:**

   - Smart energy management;

   - Reduction in home energy consumption by 20%;

   - Reduction in electricity bills by up to 90%;

   - Delivery of outstanding thermal performance; and

   - Greater use of renewable, clean, green energy.

**Digitisation in build**

Keepmoat is committed to the continued development of collaborative digital design and management processes.

Our house type ranges have been developed exclusively using 3D BIM software. Following a year of transition and training the digital
portfolio is now informing all new estate layout designs supported by the development and implementation of a new document
management system, which will promote efficiency, transparency and collaboration between Architects, Engineers and supply chain.
The accurate integration of 3rd party designs into the house type models and the clear visualisation of detailing has been developed to
support improved quality in build, reduce waste and improve efficiencies in both design and construction.

The digital models are also informing the development of 3D estate layout designs, which are being used to establish design and build
pre-development risk management decisions to support the digital marketing team with the development of interactive marketing tools.

**Introducing Digital Technology to our Customer Experience**

Our customers are early adopters of new technologies and many of their day to day experiences are conducted online, from shopping
to consuming media. In 2019 we re-engineered our customer journey, using digital technologies to make the process of buying a home
even easier, and more closely aligned to our customers’ expectations. Our customers can now reserve online from the comfort of their
own home and receive a series of automated e-mail communications with helpful information at each key stage of their journey with us.

The transformation of the customer journey has been driven by investment in a new website and other associated technology. This
provides an improved showcase for our products and offers visitors a first-class user experience resulting in higher enquiry volumes
(15% increase year on year). The new platform also offers greater scalability, enabling us to add new features and functionality cost
effectively and in an agile manner.

We have launched ‘My Keepmoat’, an account which allows our customers to manage and personalise their buying journey with
Keepmoat Homes. Over 3,000 potential buyers have created accounts since going live in September 2019.

We have also started to introduce digital technology to our sales offices through the addition of interactive touchscreen technologies,
providing our sales advisors with tools which enable our customers to visualise their future home and street, even before the first homes
are built. This is particularly beneficial for Keepmoat Homes as 84% of our homes are sold off plan and visual cues are a key influencer
of buyer behaviour.

-----

### Strategic Report – Making the most of our strengths

Finally, a new web-based platform has been developed to enable customers to personalise their Kitchen and Bathrooms, selecting
options and extras for their new home. Customers can do this at home or on a tablet in the sales office. As well as improving revenue
from options and extras, we anticipate that the new functionality will increase customer satisfaction, by allowing customers to visualise
different colour and product combinations ahead of them being installed.

**Outstanding Build Quality**

The build quality of their new home is of paramount importance to our customers. We are confident that the quality control systems and
warranties we provide allow them to feel confident that their home will be built to an excellent standard. We aspire to go beyond their
expectations.

An efficient construction process is vital to our business and to this end we are introducing several new initiatives to bring about
improvements. We have reviewed our key build stage inspection procedure and now have a formal inspection and sign off process that
allows us to benchmark our build quality. Alongside this we have produced a series of best practice guides to act as an aide memoir for
our site teams to ensure that when inspected our homes meet the required standard and comply with our detailed trade specification.
This inspection procedure is in addition to the formal inspections carried out by building control and the warranty provider.

We recognise that having the right people and teams on site and supporting them in their roles is key to a successful business and to
this end have introduced a site management development programme. This programme will take all new site-based staff members
through a series of training workshops to give them the detailed knowledge around programming, quality and cost control that they need
to develop a successful site. This programme is delivered by senior managers within the business and alongside these workshops the
programme also includes formal training on building regulations and defect prevention which is delivered by external providers to ensure
our teams are kept up to date with the latest regulations. Given the initial success of this programme with our new recruits, our intention
is to now expand the course to include all our existing site-based teams, which will act as a refresher and ensure a consistent approach
across all our developments.

**Modern Methods of Construction (MMC)**

We are a dynamic and progressive business and recognise the role that Modern Methods of Construction (MMC) can play in accelerating
housing delivery, improving build quality and addressing the sustainability challenge.

MMC is also an increasingly important requirement when bidding for public land, with Homes England requiring MMC across all sites
brought forward through their Delivery Partner Panel (DPP3). During 2019 we secured two new Homes England schemes at Brue Farm,
Highbridge and Croston Road, Leyland, both of which included a requirement to construct the homes using MMC.

We have worked in partnership with ilke Homes to create a product tailored to the aspirations of the first-time buyer market and to meet
the requirements of our public sector, registered provider and investor partners.

MMC forms a key strand of our growth plans and fully modular units are expected to make up in the order of 5% of total output over the
2020 financial year.

We are committed to increasing the number of homes we deliver using MMC and by increasing the percentage of off-site manufactured
components into our traditional designs. We continue to develop new ways of working to help address challenges faced in the industry
including reduced availability of skilled workforce, safety in build and a drive for increased speed of delivery, performance and quality.

Currently 12% of completions were delivered in timber frame. We also use off site manufactured roof cassettes, spandrel panels and
are trialling the use of pre-cut intermediate floor assemblies to increase the pre-manufactured value of our homes.

We maintain a close working relationship with ilke Homes for the incorporation of a fully volumetric housing solution. Processes have
been developed following a review of our internal pre-development, sales and construction procedures to ensure the full benefits of the
volumetric system are realised in terms of customer satisfaction, and speed of delivery and quality, with a specific focus on integration
between the home and site infrastructure works.

**Procurement**

**Our Vision is to build a more efficient and strategic Supply Chain.**

**Operational Supply chain**

To support our regional autonomy model, during the financial year we completed the process of decentralisation of the buying function
by moving our buyers away from our Doncaster Head Office and locating them in the regional businesses. All extra resources were
recruited and embedded into the regions reporting in to the regional commercial heads with the support of the Supply Chain Director
with the regions taking full responsibility for the operational procurement process.

The regional buyers work in partnership with framework suppliers to ensure successful operation of the arrangements providing feedback
on performance and service and on future requirements.

11


-----

### Strategic Report – Making the most of our strengths

**Strategic Supply Chain**

Our suppliers play an essential role in our business, providing the materials and services we use to build our homes. It is therefore
essential that we build long-lasting, good relationships that make us their partner of choice.

We operate a series of group-wide, long-term strategic frameworks providing preferential commercial terms and service levels nationally
and regionally for supply of our materials, site equipment and business consumables.

These arrangements offer significant pricing advantages, whilst also including important delivery, service and product warranties which
will help us to maintain and improve our quality and service to our customers.

The Group Supply Chain team manage over 85 arrangements which are made up of framework agreements, commercial arrangements
and formal price lists. In the year to 31 October 2019, 89% of spend was channelled through our frameworks (2018: 87%)

The Framework Agreements align with the Keepmoat Homes Standard Specification and delivers innovative solutions to support our
drive for standardisation. They also provide customer care and product warranty support to our customer services teams. Many of the
agreements provide value engineering support, free site surveys and scheduling and pricing services.

Several of our Framework Agreements are with manufacturers and suppliers who provide their products through our subcontractors and
compliance to these agreements was 96% during the year (2018: 92%).

**Management of Cost**

We work hard to mitigate price increases and ensure that agreements are always competitive and provide the best quality without
compromising on standards. We work in partnership with our suppliers to deliver the best solution for our site teams and our customers.
Many agreements include details of free supplier training for our people and our subcontractors.

**Management of Supply Chain Risk**

We maintain regular contact with suppliers and manufacturers to ensure continuity of supply, negotiating product allocation by volume.
Availability of materials is generally in line with demand and we carefully manage the supply of key products, such as bricks and
plasterboard, by working with the regional businesses and our supply chain partners.

We engage with our suppliers to keep them informed of key forecasting information and also of any changes to our working practices
as appropriate. These long-term frameworks reduce business risk and help ensure a secure supply of our essential materials. We order
around 30 million bricks annually and all are sourced in the UK. In 2019 we reviewed our homecare defects and identified high risk
products. This has allowed us to proactively reduce and mitigate any future defects, promoting an environment for both internal and
external stakeholders where product innovation is welcomed including the specification and inclusion of ARC fire barriers to improve fire
protection and ease of installation and the reduction of waste from previous methods of construction.

**Sustainability in the Supply Chain**

We promote sustainability within the supply chain through our sustainable procurement policy. Working closely with our sustainability
team ensuring all suppliers provide data in a timely manner and to a format that identifies the key metrics. We work with our supply chain
partners to support the development of reporting tools. Whilst every effort is made to support our supply chain, where business critical
data is not provided, an alternative partner is identified to ensure we meet our key obligations.

We work with supply chain partners to ensure compliance with our policies i.e. anti-bribery & corruption, modern slavery, equal
opportunities, health and safety and environmental policies as well as inclusion of our supplier chain partners own polices where
available.

**Focusing on our People and Our Culture**

As a people-centric business, a key focus is delivering our people strategy. This means ensuring that we are the employer of choice in
the home building industry, attracting the right talent, develop our existing talent and engaging all our employees so that they enjoy
working for Keepmoat Homes and feel motivated, supported, trusted, committed and can grow their career with us.

**Culture**

We put our people at the heart of everything we do. Our culture is aligned to our values – it is straightforward, passionate, creative and
highly collaborative; it is also based on openness, challenge, questioning, innovation and high engagement. Our environment is fast
paced, friendly and one where people are supported with their development and encouraged to grow.

Understanding the link between our vision, values and our behaviours, culture and the way we work is extremely important and is
covered at our corporate induction events for our new joiners. This focus on our culture has driven great improvements in our processes,
our customer focus and the quality of our product all of which has driven an increase in our levels of customer satisfaction.

**Talent and Development**

### Strategic Report – Making the most of our strengths

The emphasis on development and our approach to talent mapping and succession planning is carried out in conjunction with our PDR
process to understand the alignment with our employees’ career aspirations and development objectives. This enables our managers
to focus on understanding and supporting their teams and on helping them to realise their potential and gives us a clear talent pipeline
enabling us to achieve the right balance between our external recruitment and internal promotions.

We have developed a Future Leaders Programme which was launched in the financial year. This year-long programme is aimed at our
high performers that have the potential to reach a senior leadership role and focuses on leadership style and skills, coaching and
mentoring. We also support our Senior Leaders with their development through a series of Leadership Masterclasses as well as
coaching, psychometrics and feedback.

**Apprentices and Trainees**

We are proud to be a member of the 5% Club which means we are committed to at least 5% of our employees being apprentices or
trainees in ‘earn and learn’ positions across all functions within the business or through our subcontractors and partners. This approach
supports our skilled teams, addresses skills shortages and opens up this very important sector as a great career opportunity to them.
We work in partnership with Collab Group to source our apprentices and they have also supported us with the development of our Sales
Development Programme which leads to a formal qualification.

**Diversity and Equality**

We are also keen to encourage diversity. The house building industry is not known for being the most diverse or gender equal and there
is often a lack of candidates for certain roles from diverse backgrounds. We now have two female Regional Managing Directors and our
approach to identifying and developing our talent will continue our focus in this important area.

There is still more to do however and as a company we take the role of promoting the industry to potential candidates who might not
have considered a career in our sector very seriously. We work closely with education providers and community groups to profile the
variety of roles available and are now working in partnership with YesSheCan to promote the industry to women. We also focus on family
friendly changes such as meeting start times to support our employees with children.

**Disability statement**

The Group is committed to achieving a balanced and diverse workforce and pursues an equal opportunities policy through all areas
including recruitment and selection, training and development, performance reviews, succession planning, promotion and ultimately,
retirement. It is our policy to ensure employee related decisions are made on the basis of merit and capability regardless of religion,
race, nationality, ethnic origin, gender, sexual orientation, marital status, age or disability. If members of staff become disabled, the
Group is committed to continue employment wherever possible and undertakes the necessary adjustments to facilitate ongoing
employment.

### Strategic Report – Making the most of our strengths

**Modern Slavery Act 2015**

In November 2019 the Group published its policy statement in accordance with the requirements of the Modern Slavery Act 2015. Our
policy sets out the processes and practices that we have implemented, to ensure that modern slavery has no place to survive within our
business, or within our supply chain. We monitor the effectiveness and review the implementation of this policy, regularly considering its
suitability, adequacy and effectiveness.

**Wellbeing**

We take the health and wellbeing of our employees seriously resulting in the launch of our Mental Health awareness campaign supported
by trained Mental Health first aiders and a real focus on Time to Talk to encourage our people to talk about this important topic without
feeling worried about opening up and sharing. We are developing this further into a KeepWell programme, which is being sponsored by
our CEO and will focus on various health and wellbeing areas. This scheme successfully launched in January 2020.

**Regional Autonomy**
As a business with 11 regions supported by Group Divisional and Central Services it is important that we all work together to support
our Vision and that this is underpinned by our Values and Behaviours. Ensuring we are all aligned with our Group wide governance
framework is also vital. Our Regional Autonomy model provides the framework for how this culture of responsibility and accountability
works in practice and our Leadership teams ensure it is communicated to all employees. Our vision, values and culture are at the core
of our business and form the basis of our corporate induction so new colleagues can be effective from day one.

**Investors in People (IIP)**

Our people-centric culture was recognised in our Investors in People (IIP) accreditation, with the assessor highlighting our effective
people centric culture and the positive impact that this has on our performance as a business.

“Organisations that meet the world-recognised Investors in People Standard reflect the very best in people management excellence.
_Underpinning the Standard is the Investors in People Framework. Based on 25 years of best practice, latest research and workplace_
_trends, the Investors in People Framework is organised around nine key indicators of high performance each with three underpinning_
_themes. To achieve accreditation, organisations are assessed against these themes and indicators carried out using desktop review,_
_interviews, meetings and observations._

_Keepmoat Homes provided various aspects of documentation to support the assessment and interviews and observations took place_
_with across three regions and head office involving meetings both individually, in small groups or by telephone with 48 (4.5%) of the_
_Keepmoat staff._

_The transformation which has taken place over the last 12 months is huge and quite amazing. Having been involved with Keepmoat for_
_many years now, I had anticipated the organisation to implement some changes and to have done enough to meet the requirements of_
_the Standard. I did not however expect or anticipate the level of commitment, the enormity of the changes or the level of progress that_
_has been made in a relatively short period of time._

_The bold changes that have been initiated to regain and re-establish an effective people centric culture are a credit to the leadership_
_team and have already seen significant improvement in the organisation’s performance. What is more the extent of the changes have_
_as yet not permeated to every area of the organisation and therefore the impact and benefit to the business have yet to be fully realised.”_

### Strategic Report – Making the most of our strengths

**Keeping People Safe Every Day**

We continued to significantly improve our performance and approach to managing Health and Safety (H&S) in the last financial year,
having restructured our operating and support models resulting in much improved risk management and outcomes. Our Group H&S
department was restructured to give enhanced support to each division in the form of Divisional H&S, Environmental & Sustainability
Business Partners who are experienced and professionally qualified in HSS and support the business in relation to policy, governance
and guidance.

Our focus on risk has been throughout all phases of a development with particular emphasis on site risks. We changed our system for
assessing and controlling risk, giving responsibility to site managers who have the best understanding of our developments. This has
resulted in greater ownership and improved management of H&S risks on site. We have also developed robust, clear performance
standards for higher risk activities such as timber frame construction, working around underground services, falls from height and plant
and pedestrian interface.

We have invested in new IT H&S systems and platforms to enable us to be more efficient and effective. One such initiative saw us
moving away from the traditional way of undertaking health and safety inductions, delivered on site by site managers, to these being
carried out off site and on line. This has resulted in a significantly improved understanding by operatives of the precautions to be taken
on site and has improved our resilience and compliance in this area.

Our H&S support model has changed, to the extent that we moved away from employing internal safety advisors to regularly inspect
sites to an outsourced model engaging NHBC to undertake site inspections monthly. This has provided independent and improved
monitoring of site standards.

**Leadership and Governance**

As part of our continuous improvement philosophy, we have constituted an ‘Executive H&S Committee’ that comprises the CEO,
Executive Members and the Group HSS Director.

The Committee meets bi-monthly and has clear terms of reference centered around reviewing performance, determining policy and
improvement initiatives. Our Due Diligence comprises; - periodic third-party ISO certification audits; annual internal audit of H&S
arrangements; monthly NHBC H&S site inspections and independent pre-qualification of sub-contractors through CHAS.

**Raising the Bar for Health & Safety Performance**

Our performance throughout the year has seen continuous sustainable improvement in all of our H&S KPI’s. Our primary KPI detailing
the Annual Injury Incidence Rate (AIIR) has improved by 51% and is at 7.5% of the peer group average based on the latest HBF AIIR
for the 12 months ended 31 March 2019.

- Our Lost Time Injury frequency rate has reduced by 48%

- All Accident frequency rate has reduced by 28%

- Utility strike rate has reduced by 52%

- 571 Director’s H&S Visits undertaken

- 3,025 Site Manager Inspections

- 2,643 actions raised

**Enforcement Authority Intervention**

The Health & Safety Executive visited our sites on nine occasions and took no enforcement action and in recognition of our performance
we were awarded the Gold Award by the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA).

**Sustainability**

During 2019 we continued our focus on sustainability. Through a detailed stakeholder consultation and materiality process we updated
our Sustainability Policy and Strategy to ensure it aligns with our stakeholder’s priorities, addresses material issues and is aligned to the
UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Whilst updating our Sustainability Strategy and priorities we have focussed on three key
environmental focuses:

1. Environmental Management Systems and Controls

2. Energy and Carbon

3. Waste Management and Recycling

15


-----

### Strategic Report – Making the most of our strengths

**1. Environmental Management Systems and Controls**
All Keepmoat Homes operations are included within our ISO 14001 certified management system, ensuring contemporary systems and
effective controls are in place for all environmental risks and opportunities.

As part of the updates to our Sustainability Strategy this year, we have worked to further embed our environmental controls, including:

- Undertaking a full management system review, updating key standards and processes;

- Delivering more than 1,200 hours of environmental training;

- Implementation of monthly environmental performance reports for all regional businesses; and

- Reinforcing the reporting of Environmental Incidents and Environmental Hazards Observed (HazObs), increasing ownership of
environmental issues and enabling greater focused support on key environmental risks and opportunities.

This activity has resulted in a significant increase in operational ownership of environmental issues, demonstrated by the increase in
reporting of Environmental HazObs, facilitating preventative measures before an environmental incident occurs. Moving forwards, we
will seek to further develop and roll-out environmental training on key risks and opportunities and continue to review environmental
standards and align to other business functions.

**2. Energy & Carbon**

Climate change and the reduction of carbon emissions is a key focus for Keepmoat and our stakeholders. During the last 12 months we
have reduced our carbon footprint by 2.5% by introducing monthly reporting on carbon emissions and focusing on reduction of key
sources and reducing site generator diesel consumption and plot utility consumption. Moving forward we will seek to drive further
improvements by setting carbon reduction targets to ensure continued contribution to climate change mitigation; procure renewable
electricity; implement opportunities identified in our 2019 ESOS energy efficiency audits and update our business travel and fleet policies
to encourage the uptake of low emission vehicles, car sharing and the use of public transport.

**3. Waste and Recycling**

Over the last year we have focussed on decoupling business output from the generation of waste. This focus has achieved an absolute
reduction of 11.2% in waste removal from site. This improvement has been achieved through monthly reporting and analysis of waste
cost and performance, increased use of material management plans facilitating the reuse of soils and aggregates and the development
of strategic waste partnerships, optimising waste controls and segregation. Moving forward we will continue to drive further improvements
by further developing our strategic waste management partnerships and looking for ways to embed circular economy opportunities to
design out waste and make greater use of recycled materials.

### Strategic Report – Making the most of our strengths

**Social Value**

Keepmoat Homes builds high quality and affordable homes for first time buyers and social landlords. A key theme in our approach is to
work with our public-sector partners to deliver real and meaningful social and economic impact aligned to local community priorities
around our sites. Over 80% of our sites are on public sector land and developed in close partnership with Local Authorities, and 80% of
our sites are brownfield in regeneration areas.

This development approach means that supporting our partners to deliver their social value priorities and build sustainable communities
is at the core of our business and integral to securing future land.

**How we** **measure social value**

During 2019 Keepmoat developed an online tool to support the calculation of social value and SROI from activities in surrounding
communities. This tool is used during:

**Bidding: to compare packages of social value activities, providing clients with options aligned to their key priorities, using SROI to**
quantitatively compare options,

**Delivery: to record and store activity, and track actual impacts, and;**

**Reporting: we report our performance** to regional teams via the Monday Matters,

**Keepmoat Social Value**

Through the last financial year Keepmoat has undertaken a wide range of community activities, it has fund raised over £80,000 for good
causes and have supported and mentored a significant number of young people. Through these activities we have facilitated the delivery
of £27million of evidenced social value.

**Examples of our Social Value Activities and Achievements**

**Kick Start Programme - Hull**

Bransholme in Hull is one of the most deprived wards in the city with high levels of unemployment. Keepmoat working in partnership
with Riverside (a national Registered Provider of Social Housing) has implemented a Pre-employment construction programme.

The programme is delivered over 12 days and includes:

Employability skills, Manual Handling, Working at Heights, On-site Fire warden, Banksman, COSHH, Health & Safety Level 2, CSCS
test and 4 days practical construction work.

Key outcomes:

   - 11 Residents have completed the full Kick Start Programme and now have the skills and qualification to enter in to the
construction industry

   - 6 Apprenticeship opportunities have been created (3 with Keepmoat direct and 3 with supply chain partners) including an
Apprentice Assistant Site Manager

   - 5 Residents have signed up onto construction training courses with Orchard Training

**Social Value - £127,000 of social value generated for the Local Authority and local community**

**NEET Summer Project - Salford**

**A group of Year 11 school leavers gave up their free time over the summer holidays to gain an insight into the construction**
**industry and learn new skills**

Keepmoat Homes worked in partnership with Salford City Council, Inspiring Communities Together, Connexions and Salix Homes to
coordinate and deliver the 7-week training programme.

The school leavers, at risk of becoming NEET, (not in education, employment or training) had all expressed an interest in pursuing a
career in the construction industry and were recruited to join the project to help them choose the right career path, develop their skills
and ensure they progressed on in to further education, training or employment.

**Social Value - £21,000 of social value generated (SROI £5.69 per £1 invested)**

### Strategic Report – Making the most of our strengths

**World of Work Programme – Leicester**

Working in partnership with Leicester City Council and Leicester College, Keepmoat has been supporting Level 1 Construction students
as part of Leicester College’s ‘World of Work (WOW) Experience Programme’.

Completed over one week, the programme provides students with the opportunity to develop key employability skills, learn more about
the construction industry and engage with local construction companies. This provides opportunities for lower level students and those
with additional needs to develop the skills and qualities employers are looking for including; self-confidence, resilience, problem solving
and a sense of community.

Construction is one of the country’s leading economic drivers, however the sector is facing a skills shortage. The WOW Programme
provides a great opportunity for local students to meet with prospective employers and learn more about the variety of career
opportunities available.

**Social Value - £63,000 of social value generated**

### Strategic Report – Chief Financial Officer’s review 

We have continued the trend of controlled growth seen in previous years, delivering significant growth in earnings and record plot
volumes this year. With the right management structure, land pipeline security and improvements in operational effectiveness, the Group
is well placed to deliver on its strategy going forward.

**Performance**

The business delivered revenue of £649.8m for the 12 months to 31 October 2019, 8.8% higher than the equivalent 12 months in the
prior year (12 months to 31 October 2018: £597.0m)[1]. The number of home sales increased over the same period by 1.2% to 4,035 (12
months to 31 October 2018: 3,988), with average selling price increasing by 7.3% to £161,000 (12 months to 31 October 2018:
£150,000).

Contribution margin increased significantly by 24.1% to £119.6m, (12 months to 31 October 2018: £96.4m) reflecting both increased
plot volumes and improved site level profitability, including continued growth in our newer regions. This has been achieved in conjunction
with an increase in our Registered Provider & Private Rented Sector tenure mix to 33.8% (12 months to 31 October 2018: 28.2%) in line
with our partnership model, providing resilience in the long term.

Adjusted EBIT increased 33.7% to £61.1m (12 months to 31 October 2018: £45.7m) largely as a result of the improvement in Contribution
with appropriate investment made in the structure of the business to build a scalable platform for future growth.

Adjusted operating profit for the 12-month period was £58.5m (12 months to 31 October 2018: £41.6m); an increase of 40.6%.

In order to provide clearer visibility of the underlying performance of the Group, the Board elect to measure profits on an adjusted basis

### Strategic Report – Chief Financial Officer’s review 

**Cashflow and Financial Position**

At 31 October 2019 the Group had net assets of £103.7m (2018: £73.4m) an increase of 41.3% (£30.3m) compared to the prior year.

Inventories have increased by 5.8% from £385.4m at 31 October 2018 to £407.9m at 31 October 2019, reflecting the continued growth
of the business, including in our newer regions in Scotland, the South and the South West. Land inventory represents approximately
half of the inventory balance.

The Group was cash generative, with £44.7m generated from operations before tax (7 months to October 2018: outflow £22.2m) after
investing £14.6m in working capital in the year and the Group ended the year with net cash (including bank overdrafts) of £35.2m (2018:
£5.9m).

**Refinancing**

On 11 December 2018, the Group put in place a new debt package for the next six years to support the Group’s growth. On that date
the Group drew down a £150.0m term loan facility attracting interest of 6.5% plus Libor due for repayment in December 2024 and on
the same date redeemed its £100.0m senior secured notes at par. The Group did not incur any repayment penalties on redeeming its
senior secured notes.

On 11 December 2018 the Group repaid in full its £37.5m revolving credit facility and on the same day drew down new debt in the form
of a £27.5m revolving credit facility. The new facility is a super senior revolving credit facility with a limit of £27.5m due for renewal in
June 2025 attracting interest at a rate of 3.0% plus Libor. On the same day the Group repaid its overdraft and drew down a new overdraft
as part of the super senior revolving credit facility giving a combined total facility of £55.0m.

The new facilities provide the Group with increased liquidity on lower interest rates. The outcome of the refinancing was that the Group’s
liquidity increased by £22m after refinancing costs.

**Financing costs**

External financing costs in the period were £22.5m (7 months to 31 October 2018: £12.3m) leading to a cash outflow of £12.5m (7
months to 31 October 2018: £11.2m). The charge includes non-cash amounts of £6.8m (7 months to 31 October 2018: £2.6m) in respect
of the unwind of discount on deferred land payments.

**Taxation**

The current period tax charge of £6.9m (7 months to 31 October 2018: £1.0m charge) is made up of a current tax charge of £5.2m and
a deferred tax charge of £1.7m.

**Working capital**

The amount of working capital required to service the Group’s operations is closely monitored and controlled and forms a key part of the
management information reviewed on a daily, weekly and monthly basis. Current assets mainly comprise trade receivables, work in
progress and land held for the development of private housing and affordable housing through partnership schemes. As the Group’s
trade receivables relate mainly to public sector and Housing Association clients, there is no significant history of bad or doubtful debts.

**Performance bond facilities**

The Group, like most construction businesses, may in some cases rely on the use of performance bonds issued by surety companies
to our clients. The directors are pleased to report that the Group has adequate performance bonding lines in place with surety companies
to meet the Group’s growth plans.

**Land pipeline**

At 31 October 2019, the number of plots within our land pipeline, including sites where we have been appointed as preferred developer
was 25,024 representing over 6 years of delivery at current volumes, providing significant forward visibility for the Group.

**Impact of the new accounting standards**

IFRS16 “Leases” is effective for the Group from the 2020 financial year commencing on 1 November 2019. The Group has completed
a review of the impact of this standard and does not believe there will be a material impact on profit or net assets, although new offsetting
right of use assets of £7.0m and liabilities of £7.6m will be recognised. Further information on the impact of the change is described in
the principal consolidated accounting policies of the Group financial statements.

### Directors’ Report

The directors present their annual report and the consolidated audited financial statements of the Group for the year ended 31 October
2019.

**Principal activities**

Keystone Midco Limited is an investment holding company heading a group of companies, which are engaged in the construction of
residential dwellings and associated development contracts.

The Company’s subsidiaries are listed in note 22 to the financial statements.

**Business review and future developments**

The consolidated profit for the financial year was £30.3m, (7 month period ended 31 October 2018: £8.6m). The Company did not pay
a dividend during the year (7 month period ended 31 October 2018: £nil), no final dividend is proposed (7 month period ended 31 October
2018: £nil). A review of the results, performance and future developments for the Group are presented in the Strategic Report on pages
3 to 23 which forms part of this report.

**Going concern**

The directors have considered the adequacy of the Group’s financial resources through a review of the financial projections for the
business and taking into account the refinancing of the Group’s debt during the year. The Group drew down a £150m term loan and a
new RCF facility on 11 December 2018, for further details see note 15. After careful consideration the directors are satisfied that the
Group and Company have adequate resources to continue in operation for the foreseeable future being at least twelve months from the
date of signing the financial statements. For these reasons the directors continue to apply the going concern basis in preparing the
financial statements.

**Financial risk management**

In the course of its ordinary activities, the Group is exposed to financial risks which include liquidity, credit and interest rate risks. These
risks are monitored and managed through robust policies and procedures. Further details are included in Note 21 of the financial
statements.

Liquidity risk relates to the Group generating sufficient cash flow to meet its operational requirements while avoiding debt covenant
breaches or excessive debt levels. Total borrowings are a combination of long term loans and long term committed revolving working
capital credit facilities.

Credit risk is in relation to trade receivables from customers. Given that the majority of trade receivables are with public and regulated
organisations, the exposure to credit risk is very limited.

Interest rate risk relates to the impact of interest rate increases on the Group’s floating rate borrowings. Following the Group’s refinancing
on 11 December 2018 the Group’s term loan, revolving credit and overdraft facilities are all on floating rates. The Group’s interest rate
risk has increased following completion of refinancing.

### Principal consolidated accounting policies for the year ended 31 October 2019

**General information**

Keystone Midco Limited (the Company) is a private limited company incorporated and domiciled in the UK. The address of the registered
office is Keystone Midco Limited, The Waterfront, Lakeside Boulevard, Doncaster, DN4 5PL. The nature of the Group’s operations and
its principal activities are set out in the directors report.

The financial statements are presented in pounds sterling because the Group operates exclusively in the United Kingdom. All financial
information is rounded to the nearest thousand (£’000) except where otherwise indicated.

**Basis of preparation**

These consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)
and IFRS Interpretations Committee (IFRS IC) interpretations as adopted by the European Union and the Companies Act 2006 as
applicable to companies reporting under IFRS.

The financial statements have been prepared under the historical cost convention except investment property, available for sale financial
assets and retirement benefit assets and liabilities which have been measured at fair value.

The principal accounting policies applied in the preparation of these consolidated financial statements have been consistently applied
to all the periods presented, unless otherwise stated. The Group previously changed its reporting date from March to October and as a
result the comparative period presents performance for the 7 month period to 31 October 2018.

**Prior year restatement**

During the current financial year, the disclosure of certain contract assets and liabilities have been restated from Trade receivables and
Accruals within Trade and other receivables to Contract assets and Contract Liabilities within Trade and Other payables respectively to
more appropriately reflect the nature of the assets and liabilities. Also during the current financial year, the disclosure of the contingency
fund asset has been restated from Other receivables to Prepayments and the balance has been split between current and non-current
classification to more appropriately reflect the nature of the asset.

The consolidated balance sheet as at 31 October 2018 has therefore been restated accordingly to reflect the same basis of classification
of Trade and other receivables and Trade and other payables balances. There was no change to the reported financial performance,
total assets or total liabilities position or cash flows of the Group for either restatement. Refer to Note 12 and Note 14 for further detail.

**Going concern**

The directors have considered the adequacy of the Group’s financial resources through a review of the financial projections for the
business and taking into account the refinancing of the Group’s debt during the year. The Group drew down a £150m term loan and a
new RCF facility on 11 December 2018, for further details see note 15. After careful consideration the directors are satisfied that the
Group and Company have adequate resources to continue in operation for the foreseeable future being at least twelve months from the
date of signing the financial statements. For these reasons the directors continue to apply the going concern basis in preparing the
financial statements.

**Adoption of new and revised standards**

At the date of approving these financial statements, the following new and revised standards and interpretations were in issue but were
not yet effective (and in some cases had not been adopted by the EU). None of these revised standards and interpretations have been
adopted early by the Group.

- IAS 19 (Amended) – Employee benefits

- IAS 27 (Amended) - Separate financial statements

- IAS 28 (Amended) - Investments in associates and joint ventures

- IFRS 7 (Amended) - Financial instruments: Disclosures

- IFRIC 23 – Uncertainty over income tax treatments

- IFRS 3 (Amended) – Definition of a business

With the exception of those mentioned below, the directors do not anticipate that the adoption of these standards and interpretations in
future periods will have a material effect on the financial position or performance of the Group and Company.

**IFRS 16 – Leases**

The IASB issued IFRS 16 Leases in January 2016. The standard sets out principles for the recognition, measurement, presentation and
disclosure of leases. The standard is effective for periods commencing on or after 1 January 2019, for the Group transition to IFRS 16
will take place on 1 November 2019. The Group will adopt the new standard taking advantage of the modified retrospective approach
and thereby not restate its comparative period.

IFRS 16 removes the long-standing distinction between finance leases and operating leases and introduces a single lessee accounting
model, with some limited exemptions for short-term leases of less than 12 months and leases of low-value assets, based on a ‘right to
use’ principle.

34


-----

### Principal consolidated accounting policies for the year ended 31 October 2019

The Group is in the process of quantifying the implications of the new standard and, utilising discount rates calculated during the year,
the following impacts are shown below if the standard had been used at 31 October 2019:

   - There would be an increase in total assets of £7.0m, as leased assets, currently accounted for off balance sheet (i.e.
classed as operating leases under IAS 17) will be recognised on balance sheet as right to use assets. The biggest asset
category impacted for the Group is expected to be land and buildings.

   - There would be an increase in debt, as liabilities relating to operating leases are recognised on balance sheet. The
impact being an additional liability of £7.6m

   - Operating lease expenditure will be reclassified and split between depreciation and finance costs. Therefore, operating
profit would have seen an increase of £0.6m if the standard was in use.

The composition of the Group’s lease commitments will change over time and the discount rates applied are required to be updated to
reflect the prevailing economic environment.

**Basis of consolidation**

The Group financial statements incorporate the results of Keystone Midco Limited, its subsidiary undertakings and the Group’s share of
the results of joint ventures and associates.

(a) Subsidiaries

Subsidiaries are all entities over which the Group has control. The Group controls an entity when the Group is exposed to, or has rights
to, variable returns from its involvement with the entity and has the ability to affect those returns through its power over the entity.
Subsidiaries are fully consolidated from the date on which control is transferred to the Group. They are deconsolidated from the date
that control ceases.

Business combinations are accounted for using the acquisition method. The consideration transferred for the acquisition of a subsidiary
is the fair value of the assets transferred, the liabilities incurred, and the equity interests issued by the Group in exchange for control of
the acquiree. Consideration transferred also includes the fair value of any asset or liability resulting from a contingent consideration
arrangement. Acquisition related costs are expensed in administrative costs as incurred. All identifiable assets and liabilities acquired,
and contingent liabilities assumed are initially measured at their fair values at the acquisition date.

The excess of the consideration transferred and the amount of any non-controlling interest as compared with the Group’s share of the
identifiable net assets are recognised as goodwill. Where the Group’s share of identifiable net assets acquired exceeds the total
consideration transferred, a gain from a bargain purchase is recognised immediately in the income statement after the fair values initially
determined have been reassessed.

Inter-company transactions, balances and unrealised gains on transactions between Group companies are eliminated. Unrealised
losses are eliminated in the same way as unrealised gains but only to the extent that there is no evidence of impairment. Accounting
policies of acquired subsidiaries are changed where necessary to ensure consistency with accounting policies adopted by the Group.

(b) Joint ventures

Joint ventures are accounted for using the equity method. Under the equity method of accounting, interest in joint ventures is initially
recognised at cost and adjusted thereafter to recognise the Group’s share of the post-acquisition profits or losses and movements in
other comprehensive income.

Where the Group’s share of losses exceeds its equity accounted investment in a joint venture, the carrying amount of the equity interest
is reduced to nil and the recognition of further losses is discontinued except to the extent that the Group has incurred legal or constructive
obligations. Appropriate adjustment is made to the results of joint ventures where material differences exist between a joint venture’s
accounting policies and those of the Group.

The Group determines at each reporting date whether there is any objective evidence that the investment in the joint venture is impaired.
If this is the case, the Group calculates the amount of the impairment as the difference between the recoverable amount of the associate
and its carrying value and recognises the amount in the income statement adjacent to its share of profit/(loss) from associates.

Unrealised gains on transactions between the Group and its joint ventures are eliminated to the extent of the Group’s interest in the joint
ventures. Unrealised losses are also eliminated unless the transaction provides evidence of an impairment of the asset transferred.

(c) Associates

Associates are all entities over which the Group has significant influence but not control, generally accompanying a shareholding of
between 20% and 50% of the voting rights. Investments in associates are accounted for using the equity method, applying the same
policy as set out for joint ventures above.

### Principal consolidated accounting policies for the year ended 31 October 2019

**Segmental reporting**

Operating segments are reported in a manner consistent with the internal reporting provided to the chief operating decision maker. The
chief operating decision maker who is responsible for allocating resources and assessing performance of the operating segments has
been identified as Keepmoat Group’s executive directors.

**Revenue and profit recognition**

Revenue is recognised based on indicators of control, rather than solely when risks and rewards are transferred. This can lead to
differences in revenue recognition on certain sites, based on the specific contractual arrangements in place. Primarily, for those sites in
respect of which stage payments are received from registered providers for the provision of housing or where the Group undertakes
development contracts, revenue is recognised based on stage of completion rather than on legal completion. The directors consider the
provision of land and residential properties to represent a single performance obligation which represents a judgement taken in the
application of IFRS 15.

_Sale of housing to open market customers_

Revenue and profits associated with the sale of housing to private open market customers are recognised in the statement of
comprehensive income on legal completion.

Revenue in respect of the sale of residential properties is recognised at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable on legal
completion. Open market sale plots are recognised at the agreed sales price deemed to be fair value.

_Sale of housing to registered provider customers and associated development contracts with stage payments_

The Group constructs and sells residential properties and undertakes associated development activities under long-term contracts with
customers. Such contracts are entered into before construction of residential properties or associated development activities begin.
Under the terms of the contracts, the Group is continually restricted from redirecting the properties or development works to another
customer and has an enforceable right to payment for work done. Revenue from construction of residential properties and associated
development activities is therefore recognised over time based on a certified monthly valuation of work performed or the assessed
physical stage of completion at the balance sheet date. The directors consider that this method is an appropriate measure of the progress
towards complete satisfaction of these performance obligations under IFRS 15.

On the balance sheet, the Group reports the net contract position for each contract as either an asset or a liability. A contract represents
an asset where costs incurred plus recognised profits (less recognised losses) exceed progress billings; a contract represents a liability
where the opposite is the case.

_Sale of housing to registered provider customers without stage payments_

Revenue and profits associated with these activities are recognised in the statement of comprehensive income on legal completion as
this is the point at which control is passed from the Group to the purchaser.

_Profit recognition_

Gross profit is recognised for all house sales (to open market customer and to registered providers) and associated development
activities, when the related revenue is recognised in accordance with the Group’s revenue recognition policy, based on the latest forecast
for the gross margin expected to be generated over the life of the development or phase of the development. The expected gross margin
to be generated from each development is calculated as an output of a development valuation completed using latest selling prices and
forecasts of all land and construction costs associated with that development. The application of a whole site margin to determine
development profitability is a judgement taken in the application of IFRS 15.

The estimation methodology used to determine the gross profit margin recognised on each development was refined during the year,
this change in methodology did not have a material effect on the gross profit recognised in the year, of £119.2m.

36
